revision.comment: A recent study about violence in films.
revision.text:
{{redirect|Extreme violence|the computer game|Extreme Violence}} {{Multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=April 2007}} {{Original research|date=September 2016}} }}
'''Graphic violence''' is the depiction of especially vivid, brutal and realistic acts of [[violence in the media|violence]] in visual media such as [[literature]], [[film]], [[television]], and [[video game]]s. It may be real, simulated [[live action]], or [[animated]].
The "graphic" in graphic violence is a synonym for "explicit", referring to the clear and unabashed nature of the violence portrayed; this is what differentiates true graphic violence from lesser forms of violence in media productions, including "real" violence, "cartoon" violence and "fantasy" violence.
==Media== Graphic violence generally consists of any clear and uncensored depiction of various violent acts. Commonly included depictions include murder, assault with a deadly weapon, accidents which result in death or severe injury, suicide, and torture. In all cases, it is the explicitness of the violence and the injury inflicted which results in it being labeled "graphic". In fictional depictions, appropriately realistic plot elements are usually included to heighten the sense of realism (i.e. [[Blood squirt|blood effects]], [[Troy weapon|prop weapon]]s, [[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]]). In order to qualify for the "graphic" designation, the violence depicted must generally be of a particularly unmitigated and unshielded nature; an example would be a video of a man being shot by me, bleeding from the wound, and crumpling to the ground calling for his mother.
Graphic violence arouses strong emotions, ranging from titillation and excitement to utter revulsion and even terror, depending on the mindset of the viewer and the method in which it is presented. A certain degree of graphic violence has become ''de rigueur'' in adult "action" genre, and it is presented in an amount and manner carefully deliberated to excite the emotions of the target demographic without inducing disgust or revulsion. Even more extreme and grotesque acts of graphic violence (generally revolving around mutilation) are often used in the horror genre in order to inspire even stronger emotions of fear and shock (which the viewing demographic would presumably be seeking).
It is a highly controversial topic. Many believe that exposure to graphic violence leads to [[desensitization (psychology)|desensitization]] to committing acts of violence in person. It has led to [[censorship]] in extreme cases, and regulation in others. One notable case was the creation of the US [[Entertainment Software Rating Board]] in 1994. Many nations now require varying degrees of approval from television, movie, and software rating boards before a work can be released to the public.
On the other hand, some critics claim that watching violent media content can be cathartic, providings "acceptable outlets for anti-social impulses."<ref name="bruder">{{cite web |url= http://www.gradnet.de/papers/pomo2.archives/pomo98.papers/mtbruder98.htm |title= Aestheticizing Violence, or How To Do Things with Style |accessdate=2007-06-08 |last= Bruder |first= Margaret Ervin |year= 1998 |publisher= Film Studies, Indiana University, Bloomington IN |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20040908094032/http://www.gradnet.de/papers/pomo2.archives/pomo98.papers/mtbruder98.htm |archivedate= 2004-09-08 }}</ref>
===Film=== Graphic violence is used frequently in [[horror film|horror]], [[action film|action]], and [[crime film]]s. Several of these films were banned from certain countries for their violence. The [[snuff film]] takes horror to its furthest extreme as [[torture]] and murder are not simulated.
Violence in films is not an old topic, recently a study presented in an annual American Academy of Pediatrics conference showed that the "good guys" in superhero movies were on average more violent than the villains, potentially sending a strongly negative message to young viewers.[https://www.thenewstribe.com/2018/11/03/good-guys-more-violent-than-bad-ones-in-superhero-films-study/]
==News media== [[News media]] on television and online video frequently cover violent acts. The coverage may be preceded with a warning, stating that the footage may be disturbing to some viewers.
Sometimes graphic images are censored, by blurring or blocking a portion of the image, cutting the violent portions out of an image sequence or by removing certain portions of film footage from viewing. However, more and more throughout the years, it has been a ploy for media companies to attract more and more viewers by trivializing various events like the ones mentioned above for shock appeal.
==Music videos== Graphic and gory violence has started appearing in [[music video]]s in recent times, an example being the controversial music video for the song "[[Rock DJ]]" by British rock vocalist [[Robbie Williams]], which features self-mutilation. Another example of a music video containing strong violence is the music video for the song "[[Hurricane (Thirty Seconds to Mars song)|Hurricane]]" by American rock band [[Thirty Seconds to Mars]] and "[[Happiness in Slavery]]" by American industrial rock group [[Nine Inch Nails]]. The music video for "[[Monolith of Inhumanity|Forced Gender Reassignment]]" by American [[deathgrind]] band [[Cattle Decapitation]] displays such intense graphic violence that it is not hosted by many popular video hosting sites like [[YouTube]] and [[Dailymotion]] and is only hosted by [[Bloody Disgusting]].
==Video games== Violent content has been a central part of [[video game controversy]]. Because violence in video games is interactive and not passive, critics such as [[Dave Grossman (author)|Dave Grossman]] and [[Jack Thompson (attorney)|Jack Thompson]] argue that violence in games hardens children to unethical acts, calling [[first-person shooter]] games "murder simulators", although no conclusive evidence has supported this belief.
An example is the display of "[[Gib (video gaming)|gibs]]" (short for giblets<ref>Mahood, Andy, [http://uk.pc.gamespy.com/pc/half-life-2/682881p1.html Modify - Issue 12: Half-Life 2 on Steroids (PC)] ''GameSpy'', Jan. 26, 2006, Retrieved on Feb 27 2008</ref>), little bits or giant chunks of [[internal organ]]s, [[flesh]], and [[bone]], when a character is killed.<ref>[http://uk.pc.ign.com/mail/1999-07-28.html Reply to Letter to the Editor], ''IGN'', Jul 28, 1999, Retrieved Feb 27 2008</ref>
==Internet== On the internet, several sites dedicated to recordings of real graphic violence, referred to as "gore", exist, such as [[Bestgore.com]] and [[Goregrish.com]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://globalnews.ca/news/1617578/luka-magnottas-gore-video-why-is-the-court-seeing-it/ |title=Luka Magnotta’s gore video: Why is the court seeing it? |last1=Minsky |first1=Amy|date=16 October 2014 |website= |publisher= |access-date=28 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/luka-magnotta-trial-jury-watches-infamous-video-1.2800822 |title=Luka Magnotta trial: Jury watches 'infamous' video |last1=Shivji|first1=Salimah |date=16 October 2014 |website= |publisher= |access-date=28 March 2015}}</ref> Furthermore, many content-aggregator sites such as [[Reddit]] or [[imageboard]]s and [[4chan]] have their own subsites which are dedicated to or allow that kind of content. Some of those sites also require that gore material to be marked as it, often by the [[internet slang]] "[[Not safe for life|NSFL]]" ([[shorthand]] for "not safe for life"). This kind of media might depict reality footage of war, car crashes and other accidents, decapitations, suicide, terrorism, murder, or executions. <!-- [[LiveLeak]] -->
==See also== * [[Aestheticization of violence]] * [[Media influence]] * [[Media violence research]] * [[Motion picture rating system]] * [[Snuff film]] * [[Splatter film]] * [[Television rating system]] * [[Violence in the media]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Film and video terminology]] [[Category:Violence]]

{{Infobox company | name = Imagination Games | type = Private | foundation = 1984 | location = [[Adelaide]], [[Australia]] | industry = [[Game]]s | key_people = Shane Yeend, CEO | homepage = [http://www.imaginationgames.com www.imaginationgames.com] }} '''Imagination Games''' is a multi-platform game company that creates, produces and distributes interactive entertainment.
==History== {{no footnotes|date=May 2012}}
Imagination Game is a subsidiary of Imagination Entertainment and part of the Imagination Group of Companies.
Imagination is a global games and media company with offices and distribution in United States, Canada, United Kingdom, Europe, Australia and New Zealand. Imagination manages a portfolio of companies and investments that range from Aviation to Property. Imagination was awarded Most Innovative Company in America under 2000 employees and the same year Most Innovative Company in Asia Pacific under 2000 employees. Imagination’s Co-founder and CEO awarded Deloitte Innovator of the Year in 2002 and was Ernst & Young Australian Entrepreneur of the Year in 2007.
Imagination Ventures have donated more than $7 million to charities in Australia since 2004, with over $5 million going to the McGuiness McDermott foundation for Women’s & Children’s Hospital projects in South Australia. In 2012 Imagination purchased the rights to Humphrey B Bear one of Australia’s longest running Children’s Preschool Properties. The much-loved bear has signed on to become the Women's & Children's Foundation's "Ambassabear".
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * http://www.americanexpress.com/australia/pdfs/BEXP_Online_Cover-Story.pdf * http://gamesindustry.biz/press_release.php?aid=12941 * http://www.imaginationgames.com * http://www.austrade.gov.au/A-little-Imagination-goes-a-long-way-/default.aspx * http://boardgames.about.com/b/a/257447.htm?terms=imagination+games * https://www.forbes.com/businesswire/feeds/businesswire/2007/07/24/businesswire20070724005535r1.html * http://www.toynewsmag.com/news/28856/Imagination-catches-Catchphrase * http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/hooray-humphrey-b-bear-is-back/story-e6frf96f-1226339174981 * http://city-messenger.whereilive.com.au/news/story/north-adelaide-hospital-fundraiser/ * http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/entertainment/humphrey-b-bear-is-back-out-of-hibernation/story-e6fredpu-1226339281391
[[Category:Game manufacturers]]

{{Infobox sportsperson | name = Joseph Darby | image = File:Joe Darby - geograph.org.uk - 396713.jpg | image_size = | caption = Statue of Joseph Darby in Netherton | birth_date = {{birth date|1861|08|06}} | birth_place = [[Netherton, West Midlands|Netherton]], United Kingdom | death_date = {{death date and age|1937|12|22|1861|08|06}} | death_place = | height = 5 ft 8¼ in | weight = 175 lb | sport = Athletics | event = standing high jump, standing long jump and multiple jumps from standing start. | club = | pb = sHJ – 12 ft 2 ½ in(1889) }} '''Joseph Darby''' (1861–1937) was a renowned jumper from the [[Black Country]] village of [[Netherton, West Midlands|Netherton]]. He specialised in spring jumping (jumping starting from a stationary position) often using weights in his hands to help propel him. After taking part in competitive jumping at venues in the [[The Midlands|Midlands]] and North of England in the 1880s, he went on to perform at theatres in London and Paris and crossed the Atlantic to exhibit in North America. He entertained crowds by performing trick jumps and earned money in wagers with competitors. Highlights in his career included defeating the American World Champion spring-jumper in 1887 and appearing before the future King Edward VII in Covent Garden, London. After finishing his jumping career, he became a publican in the English town of [[Dudley]].
==Early life== [[File:Windmill End, Netherton - geograph.org.uk - 1474388.jpg|thumb|left|Windmill End, pictured in 2011]] Joseph Darby was born in Windmill End, Netherton on August 6, 1861. His parents were Abraham Darby, a maker of nails for shoeing horses, and Martha Darby (née Foley).<ref name="BCB Joe Darby Birth">{{cite news|last1=Workman|first1=John|title=Dudley's Joe Darby's birth certificate comes to light|url=http://www.blackcountrybugle.co.uk/the-birth-certificate-of-a-black-country-legend-comes-to-light/story-29658374-detail/story.html|accessdate=7 September 2016|work=Black Country Bugle|publisher=Local World|date=31 August 2016}}</ref>
When interviewed in 1889 he said that he had only received ten months' schooling at the most "and only half-time at that." He also said that he started work at the age of seven, making nails.<ref name="Brisbane Telegraph">{{Cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/185524087?searchTerm=joseph%20darby%20jump&searchLimits=|title=Jumping Joseph|last=|first=|date=2 February 1889|work=The Telegraph (Brisbane, Queensland)|access-date=15 July 2016|via=}}</ref> When asked when he started jumping he replied "I was always at it when a bit of a kiddy, jumping against the other lads, and I could always beat them fair and easy."<ref name="Brisbane Telegraph"/>
According to an interview he gave whilst on a tour in the U.S., he commenced his working life making nails for horseshoes, before working in a colliery and subsequently unloading boats.<ref name="Pittsburgh Press">{{cite news|title=Joe Darby. The Marvel|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1144&dat=18931118&id=yg4bAAAAIBAJ&sjid=c0gEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7100,747257&safe=vss&hl=en|accessdate=19 May 2016|work=The Pittsburgh Press|date=18 November 1893}}</ref>
==Early sporting career== At the age of 18 he took up athletics, firstly as a professional runner over distances of 100 and 120 yards.<ref name="Interview Cricket and Football">{{cite news |title=Joe Darby, The Jumper |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/BL/0000979/18891102/069/0008 |accessdate=4 October 2018 |work=Cricket and Football Field |via=The British Newspaper Archive |date=2 November 1889|page=8|subscription=yes}}</ref> He reportedly had success as a runner, competing 22 times and only suffering one defeat.<ref name="Interview Cricket and Football"/> He took up competitive jumping when aged 20 or 21.<ref name="Brisbane Telegraph"/><ref name="Pittsburgh Press" /> He specialised in [[Standing long jump|spring-jumping]] where he launched himself from a standing position. He often used [[Dumbbell|dumbbell-shaped weights]] in his hands to help propel himself for the spring jumps.
In a promotional pamphlet produced by Darby or his agent, the first competitive jump listed is a defeat of T. Hartshorn of Netherton for a £20 wager.<ref name="Bugle feats">{{cite news|last1=Jasper|first1=Josephine|title=Joe Darby - Netherton's Legendary Leaper|url=http://www.blackcountrybugle.co.uk/Joe-Darby-Nethertons-Legendary-Leaper/story-20155479-detail/story.html|accessdate=8 June 2016|work=Black Country Bugle|publisher=Local World|date=29 May 2013}}</ref> This competition took place at the Lea Brook Grounds, Wednesbury on 8 January 1883.<ref name="Sporting Life 10 Jna 1883">{{cite news |title=BIRMINGHAM AND DISTRICT. LEA BROOK GROUNDS, WEDNESBURY. |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/BL/0000893/18830110/045/0004?browse=False |accessdate=10 November 2018 |work=Sporting Life |via=The British Newspaper Archive |date=10 January 1883|page=4|subscription=yes}}</ref> The contest involved a sequence of 5 standing jumps and Darby beat Hartshorn by over 2 ft., covering a distance of 20 yards 1in.<ref name="Sporting Life 10 Jna 1883"/>
Darby's next jumping competition took place on 14 May 1883, at the same sporting grounds as for his first competition, and was against W. Hughes of [[Kates Hill]], Dudley. Darby again proved the winner in a contest where he took 15 "rising jumps" against his opponents 15 "rising hops".<ref name="Sporting Life 16 May 1883">{{cite news |title=BIRMINGHAM AND DISTRICT. LEA BROOK GROUNDS, WEDNESBURY |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/BL/0000893/18830516/052/0004?browse=False |accessdate=10 November 2018 |work=Sporting Life |via=The British Newspaper Archive |date=16 May 1883|page=4|subscription=yes}}</ref>
Darby's third contest was against Kirk of Ilkstone, Derbyshire, again at the Lea Brook Grounds on 24 September 1883.<ref name="Sporting Life 26 September 1883">{{cite news |title=BIRMINGHAM AND DISTRICT. LEA BROOK GROUNDS, WEDNESBURY |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/BL/0000893/18830926/071/0004?browse=False |accessdate=10 November 2018 |work=Sporting Life |via=The Briish Newspaper Archive |date=26 September 1883|page=4|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref name="Early competitions"/> In his third victory, this time for £40 stakes, Darby jumped 35ft. 8in. in a sequence of three spring jumps.
Darby now took a break from competition, working as a collier and unloader of canal boats, <ref name="Interview Cricket and Football"/> only returning to jumping in November 1885 when he defeated W. Fillingham of Wigan, Lancashire for £100 at the Queen's Ground, [[Barnsley]].<ref name="Sporting Life 4 July 1887">{{cite news |title=JUMPING. J. DARBY AND T. BURROWS. FOR £200. MARVELLOUS RECORDS |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000893/18870704/084/0004 |accessdate=10 November 2018 |work=Sporting Life |via=The British Newspaper Archive |date=4 July 1887|page=4|subscription=yes}}</ref>
On 7 December 1885, Darby lost a match to Tom Pollitt of Openshaw at the Moorfield Grounds near Manchester. For the contest, involving two forward spring jumps, Pollitt jumped first and was given a 12in start. Darby was unable to reach his opponent's mark after three jumps and so Pollitt won the £20 stake money.<ref name="Sporting Life 8 Dec 1885">{{cite news |title=Moorfield Grounds, Failsworth |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000893/18851208/080/0004 |accessdate=14 November 2018 |work=Sporting Life |via=The British Newspaper Archive |date=8 December 1885|page=4|subscription=yes}}</ref>
On 27 February 1886, Darby took on and beat John Holland of Middleton, the contest taking place at the Moorfield Grounds, Failsworth, near Manchester. For the contest, Darby took 7 forward stand jumps against Holland's "five run hops and a jump". At this time, Darby was being trained by T. Walker of the Windmill Inn. Darby won the contest by 12 inches.<ref name="Sporting Life 1 March 1886">{{cite news |title=MOORFIELD GROUNDS, FAILSWORTH, NEAR MANCHESTER |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000893/18860301/040/0001 |accessdate=14 November 2018 |work=Sporting Life |via=The British Newspaer Archive |date=1 March 1886|page=1|subscription=yes}}</ref>
Subsequent victories for Darby were recorded<ref name="Lea Brook Ground"/>. On 26 April 1886, he avenged his previous defeat by Tom Pollitt. The event took place at the Moorfield Grounds, Failworth near Manchester for total stakes of £100. The competition involved 4 standing jumps, with Pollitt being given a yard start.<ref name="Sporting Life 24 April 1886">{{cite news |title=MOORFIELD GROUNDS, FAILSWORTH, NEAR |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000893/18860424/080/0003 |accessdate=18 November 2018 |work=Sporting Life |via=The British Newspaper Archive |date=24 April 1886|page=3|subscription=yes}}</ref>
On 19 March 1887, he defeated William Brown of Leeds, Yorkshire, for £50, the jumping completion taking place at the Cardigan Grounds, Leeds.<ref name="Yorkshire Post 19 March 1887">{{cite news |title=Cardigan Grounds |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000687/18870319/185/0010 |accessdate=18 November 2018 |work=Yorkshire Post and Leeds Intelligencer |via=The British Newspaper Archive |date=19 March 1887|page=10|subscription=yes}}</ref> The competition involved Darby taking ten forward spring jumps against Brown's nine hops and a jump, Darby's winning margin being 3in despite Brown being given a 1 yard start.<ref name="Sporting Life 24 March 1887">{{cite news |title=Leeds and Neighbourhood |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000893/18870324/059/0004 |accessdate=18 November 2018 |work=Sporting Life |agency=The British Newspaper Archive |date=24 March 1887|page=4|subscription=yes}}</ref>
On 30 April 1887, he defeated Bill Brown of Bradford for £50 at the Victoria Grounds, Wolverhampton, the event involving two backward jumps.<ref name="Sporting Life 4 May 1887">{{cite news |title=Wolverhampton and District |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000893/18870504/056/0003 |accessdate=18 November 2018 |work=Sporting Life |via=The British Newspaper Archive |date=4 May 1887|page=3|subscription=yes}}</ref>
On 2 July 1887 he defeated Thomas Burrows, of Nelson, Lancashire, for £50 a-side.<ref name="Sporting Life 4 July 1887"/><ref name="Early competitions">{{cite news |title=Special Engagement of Joseph Darby |work=Sporting Life |page=1 |date=5 November 1888}}</ref> The competition took place at the Moorfield Grounds, Failsworth and involved Darby taking seven standing forward spring jumps against Burrows' six run hops and a jump. Darby won the contest by 3ft 5¾in.
On 29 October 1887, Darby was beaten by Daniel Dearden of Haydock, at the Swan Inn Grounds, St. Helens. For the competition, involving three jumps, Dearden had the advantage of using weights whilst Darby jumped without. However, Darby was given a two feet start.<ref name="Dearden competition">{{cite news |title=Lancashire Grounds |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0001055/18871031/037/0003 |accessdate=29 August 2018 |work=The Sportsman |agency=British Newspaper Archive |date=31 October 1887|page=3|subscription=yes}}</ref>
===Defeat of the American jumper Hamilton=== Between December 1887 and March 1888, he defeated George W. Hamilton,{{efn-lr|The American jumper's name is spelt Hamlington in some publications.<ref name="tump"/>}} then the World Champion spring-jumper in three competitive matches.<ref name="tump">{{cite book |last=Tump |first=Aristotle |title=A Memorable Medley of Great Black Country Characters |publisher=A Bugle Publication |year=1986}}</ref><ref name="Darby vs Hamilton">{{cite news|title=Great Jumping Match in the Midlands|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/227680443?searchTerm=darby%20hamilton%20jumping&searchLimits=|accessdate=21 July 2016|work=Sportsman (Melbourne, Victoria)|publisher=Sportsman (Melbourne, Victoria)|date=14 March 1888}}</ref><ref name="Darby vs Hamilton 2">{{cite news|title=Jumping Match for £50.|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/229932459?searchTerm=darby%20hamilton%20jumping&searchLimits=|accessdate=21 July 2016|work=The Australian Star (Sydney, NSW)|date=20 April 1888}}</ref> Hamilton, born in Frederica, New York on 28 October 1856, had jumped 14 ft 5½in with weights at Rome, Michigan, USA on 3 October 1879.<ref name="Lea Brook Ground"/> The American had come to England with [[Buffalo Bill's Wild West|Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show]], in which he performed under the guise of "Mustang Jack".<ref name="Hamilton - Buffalo Bill show">{{cite news |title=Darby v. Hamilton |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000893/18871228/109/0007 |accessdate=3 October 2018 |work=Sporting Life |via=The British Newspaer Archives |date=28 December 1887|page=7|subscription=yes}}</ref> The first meeting was at the Moorfield Grounds, Manchester on 24 December 1887. The match was for £100 a-side stake money and involved ten forward spring jumps with the use of weights.<ref name="Sporting Life 1887">{{cite news |title=£200 Jumping Match |work=Sporting Life |issue=4192 |page=7|date=26 November 1887}}</ref> Darby won the match comfortably in front of around 600 spectators, leaping over 4 ft. 5in. beyond the American's mark.<ref name="Nottingham Journal 1887">{{cite news |title=Great Jumping Match |work=Nottingham Journal |page=7|date=28 December 1887}}</ref> The second of these meetings took place at the Leabrook Grounds, [[Wednesbury]] on 21 January 1888.<ref name="Darby vs Hamilton"/> At this match, the jumpers competed for £100 a side, each jumper alternately performing two stand spring forward jumps. It was reported that Darby was trained for the competition by his own brother Abel of the Malt Shovel Inn, Dudley.<ref name="Lea Brook Ground">{{cite news |title=Jumping |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000893/18880124/049/0004 |accessdate=17 August 2018 |work=Sporting Life |via=British Newspaper Archive |page=4|date=24 January 1888|subscription=yes}}</ref> Darby won this competition by a distance of 2 ft 6in. For the third meeting, which took place on 10 March 1888 at the Moorfield Grounds, Manchester, the American was given a 6-inch start for the contest which involved two stand spring forward jumps but he failed three times to match Darby's distance.<ref name="Darby vs Hamilton 2"/> Darby's feats led to him being presented with championship belts including one proclaiming him to be champion of the world, which was awarded at the Dudley Fetes in 1889.<ref name="Joe Darby Belt inscription">{{cite web|title=Joe Darby Belts and Jumps|url=http://blackcountryhistory.org/collections/getrecord/GB145_p_2423/|publisher=Black Country History|accessdate=19 June 2015}}</ref>
Two of his championship belts and other memorabilia are on display at Dudley Museum <ref name="Museum display">{{cite web|title=Joe Darby Belts and Jumps|url=http://blackcountryhistory.org/collections/getrecord/GB145_p_2418/|publisher=Black Country History|accessdate=19 June 2015}}</ref>
On 21 April 1888, Darby avenged his previous defeat by Daniel Dearden at a competition held at the Larkhill Grounds, Farnsworth. The event, for stakes of £50 a-side, involved three forward spring jumps. Darby jumped 39 ft. 2in. and Dearden was only able to land two inches behind Darby's mark despite being given a 2 ft start.<ref name="Rematch Dearden">{{cite news |title=Jumping Match for £100 |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000181/18880423/087/0007 |accessdate=2 September 2018 |work=Sheffield Independent |agency=British Newspaper Archive |date=23 April 1888|page=7|subscription=yes}}</ref>
==Stage performer and sportsman== [[File:RoyalAcquarium1876.png|thumb|Joseph Darby topped the bill at the Royal Aquarium, London in November and December, 1888]] On 6 February 1888, Joseph Darby appeared on at [[Bingley Hall]], Birmingham as part of a testimonial benefit evening given in honour of the boxer [[Jem Carney]].<ref name="Carney benefit birmingham">{{cite news |title=TESTIMONIAL BENEFIT TO JEM CARNEY, OF BIRMINGHAM |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000893/18880207/066/0004 |accessdate=30 September 2018 |work=Sporting Life |via=The British Newspaper Archive |date=7 February 1888|page=4|subscription=yes}}</ref>
On 10 September 1888, Darby appeared in his home village at the Friendly Societies Gala on Netherton Cricket Ground in front of 4,000 people including the local MP, [[Brooke Robinson]].<ref name="Friendly Soc Gala">{{cite news |title=FRIENDLY SOCIETIES GALA AT NETHERTON |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/BL/0002179/18880915/073/0003?browse=False |accessdate=4 November 2018 |work=County Advertiser & Herald for Staffordshire and Worcestershire |via=The British Newspaper Archive |date=15 September 1888|page=3|subscription=yes}}</ref> After performing a number of trick jumps, Darby then broke the record for 20 successive spring jumps that had stood at 79yards 6in., although he only required 17 jumps to pass this distance, leaping 81 yards, 1ft 6in in the process.<ref name="Friendly Soc Gala"/>
According to an interview he gave in a French newspaper, Darby's first stage appearance before a paying public took place in October 1888, when he jumped at the [[Canterbury Music Hall]] in London again as part of a performance given for the benefit of the boxer, Jem Carney.<ref name="Le Temps interview">{{cite news|title=Un Homme Rare|url=http://www.theeuropeanlibrary.org/tel4/newspapers/issue/3000115171725?hp=2&page=2&query=joe+darby&decade=1890-1899|accessdate=5 August 2016|work=Le Temps|date=9 October 1893}}</ref> For the performance, which took place on 18 October 1888, in front of over 3,700 spectators, Darby took the stage after several boxing bouts had been completed and reportedly "gave the most marvellous display of jumping feats ever seen on a Metropolitan stage".<ref name="Carney benefit">{{cite news |title=JEM CARNEY’S BENEFIT AT THE CANTERBURY HALL |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000893/18881019/073/0004 |accessdate=26 September 2018 |work=Sporting Life |via=The British Newspaper Archive |date=19 October 1888|page=4|subscription=yes}}</ref>
On 29 October 1888, Darby appeared at the Grand Circus, adjoining the Molineux Grounds, Wolverhampton.<ref name="Molineux Grounds">{{cite news |title=Molineux Grounds, Wolverhampton |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000893/18881031/055/0002 |accessdate=3 October 2018 |work=Sporting Life |via=The British Newspaper Archives |date=31 October 1888|page=2|subscription=yes}}</ref> Despite losing his jumping clogs on the way to the venue, he still "succeeded in astonishing those present".<ref name="Molineux Grounds"/>
From 5 November 1888 to 12 January 1889, Joseph Darby performed at the [[Royal Aquarium]], a place of entertainment in London.<ref name="The Times Royal Aquarium">{{cite news|title=Royal Aquarium - Joseph Darby|work=The Times|issue=32563|publisher=The Times|date=7 December 1888}}</ref><ref name="Royal Aquarium Engagement">{{cite news |title=J. DARBY, CHAMPION JUMPER. |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000893/18890114/065/0003 |accessdate=3 October 2018 |work=Sporting Life |via=The British Newspaper Archives |date=14 January 1889|page=3|subscription=yes}}</ref> On his debut, he took to the stage clad in a white singlet and scarlet trousers before starting with a jump over a chair from a brick placed on end without knocking over the brick.<ref name="Aquarium debut">{{cite news|title=Marvellous Jumping|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/71114498?searchTerm=jumping%20match%20darby&searchLimits=|accessdate=20 September 2016|work=Australian Town and Country Journal|date=26 January 1889}}</ref> As part of his show at the Royal Aquarium, he challenged all-comers to compete with him for a bet of between £50 to £1000.<ref name="Royal Aquarium Notice">{{cite news|title=Royal Aquarium - Notice - Special Engagement of Joseph Darby|work=The Times|issue=32536|publisher=The Times|date=6 November 1888}}</ref> In the newspaper advertisement for his performance, 17 separate trick jumps were listed, including forwards, backwards and sideways jumps over chairs; jumping off and onto bricks placed on end without knocking them down; jumping onto and off a man's face without hurting him; jumping onto and off a seated man's head without hurting him; jumping onto a man's hat and off again without doing any damage and jumping over a horse.<ref name="Royal Aquarium Jumps">{{cite news |title=Royal Aquarium |work=Sporting Times |issue=1311 |page=4|date=3 November 1888}}</ref> In addition he stated that he would break jumping records set by anyone in the world.
It was reported that during his performances at the Royal Aquarium, Darby suffered a serious injury whilst jumping over tables, snapping ligaments above and below the knee.<ref name="Injury Aquarium">{{cite news |title=Athletic notes |url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/200357845?searchTerm=joseph%20darby%20sprinter%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20&searchLimits=# |accessdate=23 August 2018 |work=The Colonist |via=National Library of Australia |page=7|date=25 May 1889}}</ref>
===Awarded championship belt=== On the 11 and 12 June 1889, Joseph Darby performed at the Dudley Castle Fetes.<ref name="Castle Fetes">{{cite news |title=Dudley Castle Fetes |work=Dudley Mercury, Stourbridge, Brierley Hill, and County Express |volume=3|issue=126|page=3 |date=15 June 1889}}</ref> After his display of jumping, he was awarded a belt by Alderman Walker of Dudley Council. The belt, made of silver and with enamelled pictures on it was stated to be of £70 value and was made by Messrs. Elkington and Co. Limited of Birmingham.<ref name="Castle Fetes"/> The money for the belt was raised by subscription and included an enameled picture of Dudley Castle, crossed dumb-bells on ivy leaves, representations of Darby as a jumper, red cornelians mounted on gilded bosses, and the jumper's monogram.<ref name="Castle Fetes 2">{{cite news |title=Dudley Castle Fetes |work=County Advertiser & Herald for Staffordshire and Worcestershire|volume=35|issue=1751| page=6|date=15 June 1889}}</ref>
In 1889, he wrote to the editor of the Sporting Life newspaper, challenging the jumper Jose Parker to a contest for stakes between £50 and £200, with the gate money to be used for the benefit of the Guest Hospital, Dudley.<ref name="Jose Parker">{{cite news |title=Joseph Darby to Jose Parker |url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/127597587|accessdate=20 July 2018 |work=Referee |date=14 August 1889}}</ref> The two jumpers competed in May 1890 at Dudley Castle Grounds before a crowd estimated at over 20,000. Darby's jumping pupil Short also competed at the event, which involved a variety of stand jumps. Darby won all of the events.<ref name="Parker contest">{{cite news |title=Jumping |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000893/18900531/104/0008 |accessdate=17 August 2018 |work=Sporting Life |via=British Newspaper Archives |page=8|date=31 May 1890|subscription=yes}}</ref>
In November 1889, it was reported that he had broken three jumping records at the Ashton-Under-Lyne Skating Rink towards the end of October. In the single stand jump without weights, he achieved 11ft. 8½in., beating the record by 7½in. He also broke the record for two stand jumps and for the high jump by clearing 5ft. 6in.<ref name="Ashton records 1889">{{cite news |title=Sport |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000150/18891102/094/0008 |accessdate=24 September 2018 |work=Worcester Journal |via=The British Newspaper Archive |date=2 November 1889|page=8|subscription=yes}}</ref>
On 30 November 1889, an newspaper advertisement stated that he was playing to packed houses and that he had only one available open date for the rest of the year. His sole agent was stated to be John Taylor of Windmill End, Dudley.<ref name="Advert">{{cite news |title=Wanted |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000053/18891130/113/0023 |accessdate=26 August 2018 |work=The Era |via=British Newspaper Archives |date=30 November 1889|page=23|subscription=yes}}</ref>
In December 1889, Darby was being billed as the "Champion Jumper of the Word", the "Ninth Wonder of the World" and as the "Flying Man".<ref name="The Era 28 December 1889">{{cite news |title=JOSEPH DARBY |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000053/18891228/085/0022 |accessdate=21 November 2018 |work=The Era |via=The British Newspaper Archive |date=28 December 1889|page=22|subscription=yes}}</ref>
In 1890 it was reported that: "Darby goes through no exceptional training unless for a special contest. He keeps himself trim by a little boxing, careful diatary, and keeping clear of alcohol almost to the extent of teetotalism."<ref name="Training">{{cite news|title=Athletics. Darby the Jumper.|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=34&dat=18900604&id=qA8IAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xDYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5518,2091168&safe=vss&hl=en|accessdate=9 June 2016|work=The Toronto Daily Mail|publisher=The Toronto Daily Mail|date=4 June 1890}}</ref>
===Performs in England, Ireland and Scotland===
In early May 1890, Darby was performing at [[Olympia Theatre, Dublin|Dan Lowrey's Star Theatre]] in Dublin. Darby's shoes were kept on display at the theatre bar in order to show they contained no springs.<ref name="Dan Lowrey">{{cite news |title=Dan Lowrey's Star Theatre |work=Freeman's Journal |page=4 |date=9 May 1890}}</ref><ref name="Dublin performance">{{cite news|title=An Athletic Phenomenon|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2329&dat=18900628&id=ULwoAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1gUGAAAAIBAJ&pg=3024,1872265&hl=en|accessdate=13 July 2016|work=Aurora Daily Express|issue=2024|publisher=Aurora Daily Express|date=28 June 1890}}</ref>
In the middle of May 1890, Darby performed at the Bradford and West Riding Gala held at Peel Park, Bradford.<ref name="Bradford Gala">{{cite news |title=Bradford and West Riding Galas |work=Shipley Times and Express|page=1 |date=17 May 1890}}</ref>
In June 1890, Darby performed at the annual sports meeting held at the [[Netherton Cricket Club|Netherton Cricket Club's]] ground.<ref name="Darby at NCC">{{cite news |title=ATHLETIC SPORTS AT NETHERTON |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0002184/18900628/062/0003 |accessdate=31 October 2018 |work=County Express |via=The British Newspaper Archive |date=28 June 1890|page=3|subscription=yes}}</ref>
In late December of the same year he performed at Mr. Moss' Xmas and New Year Carnival held at Waverley Market, Edinburgh.<ref name="Waverley Market">{{cite news |title=Waverley Market |work=The Scotsman |issue=14,816 |page=1|date=29 December 1890}}</ref>
On 14 June 1891, Darby made a return to competitive jumping, defeating Temple Jones of Bolton at the Belle Vue Gardens, Stockton.<ref name="Jones of Bolton">{{cite news |title=The Jumping Championship |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000893/18910316/022/0001 |work=Sporting Life |via=British Newspaper Archive |page=1|date=16 March 1891|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref name="Temple Jone contest">{{cite news |title=Jumping match for £100 and the championship |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000500/18910316/090/0008 |accessdate=2 September 2018 |work=York Herald |agency=British Newspaper Archive |date=16 March 1891|page=8|subscription=yes}}</ref>
In February 1892, Darby was performing at Rowland's Circus, Wolverhampton, where his act included jumping 36 feet in three jumps ending with a jump over a chair placed on a table; jumping over a tank of water, lowering his feet to touch the surface of the water as he passed over the tank and springing over eight chairs placed back to back.<ref name="Rowland's Circus">{{cite news |title=Wolverhampton |work=The Stage |issue=568 |page=15|date=4 February 1892}}</ref> It was at this venue where Darby performed one of his most famous trick jumps: that of clearing a full sized billiard table (minus cushions). In fact, an authentic billiard table was not available at the occasion, so a dummy table was erected. Darby was hampered in his attempt by lack of space and could only take two stand spring jumps prior to leaping the table, which he succeeded in doing on his fifth attempt.<ref name="Billiard table jump">{{cite news |title=Marvellous Jumping Performances |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000893/18920210/161/0008 |accessdate=17 August 2018 |work=Sporting Life |publisher=British Newspaper Archive |page=8|date=10 February 1892|subscription=yes}}</ref>
[[File:London Empire Theatre EFA.jpg|thumb|left|In 1892, Joseph Darby appeared at the Empire Theatre, Leicester Square on the same bill as the celebrated musical-hall performer Marie Lloyd]] In October 1892 he performed as part of a variety show at the [[Empire, Leicester Square|Empire Theatre]], London alongside the celebrated musical-hall performer, [[Marie Lloyd]].<ref name="The Times 1892">{{cite news|title=Empire Theatre Tonight|date=28 October 1892|work=The Times|publisher=The Times|issue=33781}}</ref> [[George Bernard Shaw]] attended one of the performances and wrote: "Now is it not odd that at a music-hall to which, perhaps, half the audience have come to hear Marie Lloyd sing Twiggy voo, boys, twiggy voo? or to see Mr Darby jump a ten-barred gate, you get real stage art".<ref name="GBS">{{cite book|last1=Shaw|first1=George Bernard|title=Music in London 1890-94 Volume 2|date=1932|publisher=Constable and Company|location=London|page=168}}</ref> According to an American newspaper: "English athletes are just now flocking to the Empire theater, London, to witness the high and broad jumping feats of Joseph Darby, the champion jumper and holder of the championship belt." The same source reported: "one of his favorite tricks is to place six chairs in a row and spring from a brick at one end of the line to a corresponding brick at the other. His flying feats include a leap over a chair placed on a table and over eight chairs in a row, a length of eighteen feet. He goes over a horse seventeen hands high with his ankles tied. Among his phenomenal performances are a backward spring over three chairs and a leap over a tank of water ten feet long, during which he lightly skims the water with his foot. His most unique feat is a jump over a chair, alighting on a man's face and jumping back again without injuring his assistant. As the latter is generally a choice specimen of the London tough the escape of his cheek is not to be wondered at. Darby concludes his sensational performance with a leap over a six-foot hurdle lined at the top with a bristling row of spikes."<ref name="Empire show">{{cite news |title=An English jumper who surpasses all records |url=https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn90059522/1892-10-30/ed-1/seq-13/#date1=1887&index=4&rows=20&words=Darby+Joseph+jumping&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1900&proxtext=joseph+darby+jump&y=12&x=20&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1 |accessdate=20 July 2018 |work=St. Paul daily globe |date=30 October 1892}}</ref>
In November 1892, a newspaper reported that he had won over £30,000 in jumping matches.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/61247511?searchTerm=%22jumping%20match%22%20darby&searchLimits=dateFrom=1886-01-01|||dateTo=1901-01-01|title=A Wonderful Jumper|last=|first=|date=15 November 1892|work=Clarence and Richmond Examiner|access-date=21 September 2016|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
In January 1893, an Australian newspaper acclaimed Darby with the words: "no athlete can boast of such a brilliant record of achievements in his own particular department as Mr Darby, who for the last eleven years can show an unbroken series of triumphs gained with the utmost ease from those pseudo-champion jumpers of all countries who have considered themselves foemen worthy of his steel."<ref name="Telegraph Tasmania">{{cite news|title=JOSEPH DARBY, THE CHAMPION JUMPER OF THE WORLD|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/153360194?searchTerm=joseph%20darby&searchLimits=|accessdate=14 July 2016|work=Daily Telegraph (Launceston, Tasmania)|publisher=Daily Telegraph (Tasmania)|date=21 January 1893}}</ref> The same source stated: "Mr Darby is a married man, thirty-one years of age, and is living at a small village about two miles from Dudley, in Worcestershire, in the same house in which he was born and brought up."<ref name="Telegraph Tasmania"/>
On 22 July 1893, Darby took on another remarkable jumper of the age, John (Jack) Higgins of [[Blackburn]]. The competition was held at the Moorfield Ground, [[Failsworth]] and involved both athletes performing a "hop, two strides and a jump" for a stake of £100. On the day, Higgins broke the world record for this event and Darby was defeated.<ref name="Higgins">{{cite news|last1=North|first1=Oswald|title=The Champion Jumper of the World|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1302&dat=18980108&id=C34QAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WpUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7256,357378&hl=en|accessdate=2 August 2016|work=The Sydney Mail|issue=1957|date=8 January 1898}}</ref>
===Performs in France, Germany and North America=== [[File:Paris - Cirque d'hiver 01.jpg|thumb|right|In October 1893, Joseph Darby performed at the Cirque d'Hiver in Paris]] On 23 September 1893, it was reported that Darby was in his fifth week at an engagement at the "Winter Gardens" in Berlin<ref name="Darby in Berlin">{{cite news |title=Joe Darby |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000053/18930923/114/0025 |accessdate=16 September 2018 |work=The Era |via=British Newspaper Archive |date=23 September 1893|page=25|subscription=yes}}</ref>
In October 1893, Darby performed at the [[Cirque d'Hiver]] in Paris.<ref name="Le Temps interview"/>
Later in the same month, he was described as the 'greatest phenomenon in the jumping line in the world' by the ''Montreal Daily Witness'' as he set out on a tour of the USA.<ref name="Montreal">{{Cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=125&dat=18931025&id=2WdSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PmcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1549,6294285&safe=vss&hl=en|title=English Champion Darby|last=|first=|date=25 October 1893|work=Montreal Daily Witness|access-date=20 May 2016|via=}}</ref> The same source described him as being 5 ft 8¼ in tall with a 40 in chest, weighing 175 lb. In addition, it was stated that 'the muscle of his arm measures 15½ in, and the thick of the leg 28 in but the calf is remarkable for its iron quality rather than anything else'.<ref name="Montreal" /> He reportedly set out for the USA on 21 October 1893.<ref name="New York Tribune Oct93">{{cite news |title=Plenty of Good Plays |url=https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1893-10-22/ed-1/seq-19/#date1=1887&index=2&rows=20&words=champion+Darby+Joseph&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1900&proxtext=joseph+darby+champion&y=12&x=18&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1 |accessdate=27 July 2018 |work=New-York tribune| page=19| date=22 October 1893}}</ref> arriving aboard the [[RMS Umbria]] at New York on October 30.<ref name="Stark County">{{cite news |title=The Greatest Jumper Alive |url=https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84028490/1893-11-02/ed-1/seq-2/#date1=1893&index=12&rows=20&words=champion+Darby&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1894&proxtext=darby+champion&y=16&x=13&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1 |accessdate=27 July 2018 |work=The Stark County Democrat |page=2 |date=2 November 1893}}</ref> In November 1893, he issued a challenge to "jump any man either backward or forward with or without weights for from $5,000 to $10,000 a side".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=18931102&id=8OkZAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aSAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2665,2490750&safe=vss&hl=en|title=Scraps of Sport|last=|first=|date=2 November 1893|work=The Milwaukee Journal|access-date=16 June 2016|via=}}</ref>
In October and November 1893, Darby was performing with a troupe in the play "The Country Circus" at the Grand Opera House, Brooklyn.<ref>{{cite news |title=At the Brooklyn Theatres |url=https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1893-11-04/ed-1/seq-5/#date1=1887&index=0&rows=20&words=champion+Darby+Joseph&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1900&proxtext=joseph+darby+champion&y=12&x=18&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1 |accessdate=27 July 2018 |work=The evening world |page=5|date=4 November 1893}}</ref> The opening night was on 30 October 1893.<ref name="Opening America">{{cite news |title=Grand Opera-House |url=https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1893-10-31/ed-1/seq-5/#date1=10%2F20%2F1893&index=3&date2=12%2F31%2F1893&searchType=advanced&language=&sequence=0&words=Darby+Joseph&proxdistance=5&state=&rows=20&ortext=&proxtext=&phrasetext=joseph+darby&andtext=&dateFilterType=range&page=1 |accessdate=5 September 2018 |work=The evening world |via=Library of Congress|date=31 October 1893|page=5}}</ref> Later the troupe performed the play at other venues: on 26 December 1893, Darby performed at the Olympic, [[St Louis]]<ref name="St Louis 1893">{{cite news |title=From Other Points |url=http://idnc.library.illinois.edu/cgi-bin/illinois?a=d&d=NYC18931230.2.8&srpos=8&e=01-01-1893-01-05-1894--en-20-NYC-1--txt-txIN-joseph+darby------- |accessdate=5 September 2018 |work=New York Clipper |via=Illinois University Library Digital Collections |date=30 December 1893}}</ref> and in January 1894, the troupe had moved on to Washington, where they performed at Albaugh's.<ref name="Evening star Washington">{{cite news |title=Amusements |url=https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1894-01-16/ed-1/seq-8/#date1=1887&index=6&rows=20&words=champion+Darby+Joseph&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1900&proxtext=joseph+darby+champion&y=12&x=18&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1 |accessdate=27 July 2018 |work=Evening star |page=8 |date=16 January 1894}}</ref>
Darby returned to England in February 1894, again taking the steamer ''Umbria'' for the crossing.<ref name="Return to England">{{cite news |title=Sporting Notes |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000273/18940209/008/0003 |accessdate=12 September 2018 |work=Yorkshire Evening Post |via=British Newspaper Archive |date=9 February 1894|page=3|subscription=yes}}</ref> After his arrival at Liverpool with his manager, Jack Jones, on 17 February 1894, Darby went on to Dudley where he received an "enthusiastic reception".<ref name="Return to Dudley 1894">{{cite news |title=Sporting Notes |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000273/18940220/009/0003 |accessdate=12 September 2018 |work=Yorkshire Evening Post |via=British Newspaper Archive |date=20 February 1894|page=3|subscription=yes}}</ref>
In April 1894, whilst performing at Ohmy's Grand Circus, Longton, Darby issued a challenge for all comers to compete for between £500 and £1000 a-side with a choice of between 1 and 20 jumps. Darby offered competitors a 5 ft start over 10 jumps and 10 ft start over 20 jumps.<ref name="Darby's challenge">{{cite news |title=Joe Darby |work=The Era |volume=56 |issue=2899 |page=26| date=14 April 1894}}</ref>
In May 1894, Darby was performing at Hengler's Grand Cirque, Rotunda Gardens, Dublin<ref name="Hengler's Grand Cirque">{{cite news |title=Hengler's Grand Cirque |work=Dublin Daily Express |issue=13076 |page=4 |date=5 May 1894}}</ref>
In June and July 1894, Darby was performing in Paris again, this time at the [[Cirque d'Été]].<ref name="L'écho de Paris 1894">{{cite news|title=GAZETTE THEATRALE|url=http://www.theeuropeanlibrary.org/tel4/newspapers/issue/3000114855267?hp=4&page=4&query=joe+darby&decade=1890-1899|accessdate=9 August 2016|work=L'écho de Paris|date=5 July 1894}}</ref>
===Second championship belt and sporting retirement=== Darby announced his retirement from competitive jumping (although not from exhibitions) on 23 July 1894 after winning a competition held at [[Dudley Castle|Dudley Castle Grounds]].<ref name="Sortsman">{{cite news|title=THE JUMPING CHAMPION SHIP|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/227718933?searchTerm=joe%20darby%20jump&searchLimits=|accessdate=15 July 2016|work=Sportsman (Melbourne, Victoria)|date=4 September 1894}}</ref> The [[Sporting Chronicle|Manchester Sporting Chronicle]] awarded Darby a Championship belt as a result of winning this contest.<ref name="Hull Dail Mail">{{cite news |title=Champion Jumper of the World |work=Hull Daily Mail |issue=3003|page=3|date=2 May 1895}}</ref> The belt was presented at the conclusion of the two day sports fête by the [[William Ward, 2nd Earl of Dudley|Earl of Dudley]].<ref name="Dudley fetes 1894">{{cite news |title=FETES AT THE PRIORY, DUDLEY |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0002179/18940728/050/0006 |accessdate=26 August 2018 |work=County Advertiser & Herald for Staffordshire and Worcestershire |via=British Newspaper Archive |date=28 July 1894|page=6|subscription=yes}}</ref>
===Further performances=== In March 1895, he interrupted a tour of France to appear at the Empire Theatre, Coventry, the stage having been specially strengthened for his act.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Coventry's Forgotten Theatre|last=Bottle|first=Ted|publisher=The Badger Press|year=2004|isbn=0952607670|location=Westbury, UK|pages=164}}</ref>
In a newspaper interview given in May 1895, Darby stated that he had performed in "France, Germany, Holland, in fact nearly all over the Continent".<ref name="Hull Dail Mail"/> He also stated that he had performed in front of royalty in many nations, including the Prince of Wales. According to an obituary article, written much later, a special command performance had been arranged before the Prince of Wales by [[Lord Henry Arthur George Somerset|Lord Arthur Somerset]] at Evans' Rooms, Covent Garden.<ref name="Birmingham Daily Gazette">{{cite news |title=Dudley Jumper who Astonished World Dead |work=Birmingham Daily Gazette |issue=29228 |page=5|date=23 December 1937}}</ref>
In August 1895, Darby gave performances at Tudor's Circus in Cambridge.<ref name="Cambidge 1895">{{cite news |title=The Town and County |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000421/18950816/154/0008 |accessdate=2 September 2018 |work=Cambridge Chronicle and Journal |via=British Newspaper Archive |date=16 August 1895|page=8|subscription=yes}}</ref>
In December 1897, Darby had a benefit performance at Walsall, taking on local jumper Arthur Boyce.<ref name="Benefit">{{cite news|title=On the occasion of Joe Darby's benefit|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/227744362?searchTerm=jumping%20match%20darby&searchLimits=|accessdate=20 September 2016|work=Sportsman (Melbourne, Victoria)|date=4 January 1898}}</ref> For this match, it was decided that Boyce would jump in a forward direction without weights against Darby jumping backwards with weights. Before the match started, Darby entertained the crowds by leaping over a horse-drawn carriage. A newspaper reported on the event : "on Darby entering the arena he met with a magnificent reception. A covered [[Brougham (carriage)|brougham]] was brought from the nearest cab stand, and at the second attempt, amid deafening cheers, Darby was over like a bird."<ref name="Benefit"/> Darby went on to win the match.
In 1898, he featured in a short film made by Riley Brothers entitled 'Joe Darby in his Various Jumps'.<ref>{{Cite book|title=British Film Catalogue: Two Volume Set - The Fiction Film/The Non-Fiction Film|last=Gifford|first=Dennis|publisher=Routledge|year=2001|isbn=978-1579581718|location=|pages=}}</ref> The film showed Darby "leaping the horse - Jumping over a man and just touching his face - Jumping over water and just skimming the surface - Jumping over a large number of chairs placed near together - &c. &c."<ref name="Pioneers of British Film">{{cite book|last1=Barnes|first1=John|title=Pioneers of the British film|date=1983|publisher=Bishopsgate|isbn=9781852190125|page=189}}</ref>
On 30 August 1898, Darby suffered an injury whilst attempting to jump over a brougham at Scarborough, catching the top of the carriage as he passed over and falling forward onto his head.<ref name="Injury at Scarborough">{{cite news |title=ACCIDENT TO DARBY, THE JUMPER |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0001005/18980903/157/0012 |accessdate=29 August 2018 |work=Dudley Herald |via=British Newspaper Archive |date=3 September 1898|page=12|subscription=yes}}</ref>
===Brief return to competitive jumping and final performances=== On 12 November 1898, Darby briefly returned to competitive jumping when he took on Thomas Colquitt of St Helens at the Wellington Grounds, [[Bury, Greater Manchester|Bury]], in front of 2000 spectators. The competition involved a sequence of 10 forward spring jumps without weights. Colquitt won the event and the £100 stake.<ref name="Colquitt">{{cite news|title=Jumping Match for £100|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/121527451|accessdate=2 August 2016|work=Referee (Sydney, New South Wales)|date=28 December 1898}}</ref>
On the plinth of his statue in Netherton, it is recorded that on 19 November 1898 he was summoned for a 'Royal Command Performance' at Covent Garden where he performed in front of the Prince of Wales, the future [[Edward VII|King Edward VII]].
In March 1899, Darby was again performing at the Cirque d'Hiver in Paris, where his performance included leaping over a horse-drawn carriage.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theeuropeanlibrary.org/tel4/newspapers/issue/3000114888537?hp=4&count=10&page=4&query=joe%2Bdarby&decade=1890-1899|title=Au Cirque d'Hiver|last=|first=|date=7 March 1899|work=L'écho de Paris|access-date=20 September 2016|via=The European Library}}</ref>
In August 1899, Darby was reported as appearing at the "Milford Flower Show and Sports", where his performance included jumping over a cab and over 14 chairs.<ref name="Milford Sports">{{cite news |title=Milford Flower Show and Sports |work=Belper News |volume=4 |issue=164 |page=7 |date=4 August 1899}}</ref>
In July 1900, Darby performed again at the Milford Flower Show, when it was reported that he was unable to do one of his most popular jumps, leaping over a cab, because the vehicle did not arrive in time. It was also reported that his 9 year old son made his debut at this event.<ref name="Milfor Flower Show 1900">{{cite news |title=Milford Flower Show |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000327/19000723/019/0002 |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=Derby Daily Telegraph |via=British Newspaper Archives |date=23 July 1900|page=2|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref name="Milford Flower Show2">{{cite news |title=Milford Flower Show |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0001536/19000727/089/0008 |accessdate=9 September 2018 |work=Belper News |via=British Newspaper Archive |date=27 July 1900| page=8|subscription=yes}}</ref>
==Career after jumping== Despite Darby's fame, he never lived far from his birthplace in Netherton. In 1900 he was listed by a local trade directory with the profession of "Champion Jumper", living at 23 High Street, Netherton.<ref name="Blocksidge 1900">{{cite book|title=Blocksidge's Illustrated Dudley Almanack|date=1900|publisher=E. Blocksidge|location=Dudley, UK|page=137}}</ref>
In later life he became the landlord of the Albion Inn, Stone Steet, [[Dudley]]. He advertised on 9 June 1900 that he had taken over this pub<ref name="Albion Hotel">{{cite news |title=Joseph Darby, Champion Jumper of the World |work=Dudley Herald |issue=1712 |page=7 |date=9 June 1900}}</ref> and he was listed as being a "Licensed Victualler" there from 1901 onwards.<ref name="Blocksidge 1901">{{cite book|title=Blocksidge's Illustrated Dudley Almanack|date=1901|publisher=E. Blocksidge|location=Dudley, UK|page=60}}</ref> In September 1900 it was reported that he had entered a lion's cage set up on Dudley Market Place in order to settle a bet of £10.<ref name="Lion's cage stunt">{{cite news |title=Notes of the Week |url=https://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0001005/19000908/079/0007 |accessdate=26 August 2018 |work=Dudley Herald |via=British Newspaper Archive |date=8 September 1900|page=7|subscription=yes}}</ref>
In 1934, Darby attended the civic reception given to the Dudley-born Wimbledon tennis champion, [[Dorothy Round]].<ref name="Dorothy Round">{{cite news |title=Welcome home to Miss Dorothy Round |work=Staffordshire Advertiser |page=2 |date=21 July 1934}}</ref>
He died in Dudley on the 22nd of December, 1937
==Jumps==
Joseph Darby performed his jumps at a number of venues including sports grounds, circuses and concert halls.<ref name="Athletic feats">{{cite news|title=A few of the athletic feats achieved by Joe Darby, Achilles of the Black Country|url=http://www.blackcountrybugle.co.uk/athletic-feats-achieved-Joe-DarbybrAchilles-Black-Country/story-20140447-detail/story.html|accessdate=25 November 2015|work=Black Country Bugle|date=5 August 2004}}</ref> He received money for performing, often from betting on the outcome of competitions with other jumpers.<ref name="Nethertons Legend">{{cite news|last1=Jasper|first1=Josephine|title=Joe Darby - Netherton's Legendary Leaper|url=http://www.blackcountrybugle.co.uk/Joe-Darby-Nethertons-Legendary-Leaper/story-20155479-detail/story.html|accessdate=25 November 2015|work=Black Country Bugle|date=29 May 2013}}</ref> The jumps themselves involved forwards and backwards spring jumps (often multiple jumps) and high jumps. In addition to competitive jumping, Darby developed a repertoire of "trick jumps" for entertainment purposes. Some of these jumps were over obstacles such as chairs at regular spacings.<ref name="Nethertons Legend"/> Others required dexterity such as taking off or landing on a brick. He also developed the ability to briefly touch down his feet before his actual landing, which made possible some of his more famous "trick jumps". For one such trick jump, a volunteer would lie on the ground in the path of the jump and Joseph Darby would appear to land on and jump off the person's face.<ref name="Nethertons Legend"/> Another such trick jump would involve jumping over a tank of water and briefly touching the surface of the water with his shoes.
To achieve jumps of greater distances or heights, Darby would sometimes employ dumb-bell shaped weights held in both hands. These could be used to provide extra momentum. It was reported in 1893 that he was using weights of 9 lb each.<ref name="Pittsburgh Press"/> It was also reported that he made his jumps wearing steel-tipped [[Clog (British)|clogs]],<ref name="Training"/> albeit "very thin and beautifully made" ones.<ref name="Pittsburgh Press"/> However it was reported that when jumping in a backwards direction he wore [[Plimsoll shoe|pumps]].<ref name="Pittsburgh Press"/>
Darby's single forward spring-jump of 12 ft 2 ½ in, achieved without weights on October 24, 1889,<ref name="Police Gazette"/> stands comparison with the best achieved since then. The world (amateur) record for this event when it was still an Olympic sport in the early 20th century was 3.47m (about 11 ft 4 ½ in) achieved on 3 September 1904 by [[Ray Ewry]].<ref name="Ray Ewry">{{cite web|title=Ray Ewry|url=http://www.usatf.org/halloffame/TF/showBio.asp?HOFIDs=52|website=USA Track & Field|publisher=USA Track and Field|accessdate=2 September 2016}}</ref>
Some of his most famous achievements include: jumping over a full sized billiard table, a six-foot high jump performed with ankles tied, and leaping over a horse 13 hands high.<ref name="Athletic feats"/><ref name="Nethertons Legend"/>
===Long and high jumps=== Joseph Darby's jumping record can be found in a number of sporting annuals from his era.<ref name="Police Gazette"/><ref name="New York Clipper 1892">{{cite book|title=The New York Clipper Annual for 1892|date=1892|publisher=The Frank Queen Publishing Company|location=New York|page=98|url=http://www.columbia.edu/cu/lweb/digital/collections/cul/texts/ldpd_5655288_004/ldpd_5655288_004.pdf|accessdate=5 September 2016}}</ref><ref name="Sporting Records">{{cite book|last1=Morgan-Browne|first1=H.|title=Sporting and Athletic Records|date=1897|publisher=Methuen & Co.|location=London|pages=181–184|url=https://archive.org/stream/sportingandathl00browgoog#page/n9/mode/2up|accessdate=6 September 2016}}</ref> In the [[National Police Gazette|Police Gazette]] Sporting Annual for 1897, Joseph Darby is listed as holding the following professional jumping records:<ref name="Police Gazette">{{cite book|title=The Police Gazette Sporting Annual for 1897|date=1897|editor=Sam C. Austin|publisher=Richard K. Fox|location=New York|pages=34–35|url=https://archive.org/details/policegazettes189718aust}}</ref>
Standing High Jump — 6 ft, with ankles firmly bound together, achieved on June 13, 1892.
Standing High Jump with weights — 6 ft 3 in, at the third stand jump, achieved on November 6, 1891.
Standing Back Jump — 12 ft 11 in, achieved on September 14, 1891.
Standing Wide Jump (with weights) — 14 ft 9 in, achieved on September 19, 1890;
Standing Wide Jump(without weights) 12 ft 2 ½ in, achieved on October 24, 1889.
Running High Jump — 6 ft 5 ½ in, achieved on February 5, 1892
Longest Flying Jump (third of three stands) — 16 ft 4 in, achieved on November 8, 1888.
Two Standing Jumps (with 19 lb weights) — 28 ft, achieved on November 6, 1891.
Three Standing Jumps with weights — 42 ft 6 in, achieved on March 4, 1892;
Three Standing Jumps (without weights), 35 ft 11 in, achieved on November 6, 1891.
Four Forward Spring Jumps (with weights) — 56 ft 2 in, achieved on August 19, 1889.
Five Forward Jumps (with weights) — 76 ft 3 in, achieved on August 19, 1889.
Five Forward Jumps (without weights) 61 ft 5 ½ in, achieved on May 28, 1890.
Seven Standing Jumps (with weights) — 96 ft 4 in, achieved on Julv 2, 1887.
Ten Standing Jumps (with weights) — 137 ft 7 in, achieved on August 10, 1889.
Six Back Spring Jumps (with weights) — 58 ft, achieved on June 13, 1892.
Stand, Two Hops and Jump (with weights)— 36 ft 7 in, achieved on March 14, 1891.
Stand, Five Hops and Jump — 71 ft 3 ½ in, achieved on June 11, 1892.
Three Backward Jumps — 30 ft 9 in, achieved on October 26, 1894.
===Trick Jumps===
The Pittsburgh Press in November 1893 listed the following jumps in Darby's repertoire:<ref name="Pittsburgh Press"/>
Jumps over twenty chairs placed ten feet apart.
Jumps over six chairs in one jump.
Clears two chairs 18 ft apart.
Jumps off one brick, end up, over a chair, lands on another brick end up, and backwards without knocking the bricks down.
Jumps on to a man's face while lying down and off again without hurting the man.
Jumps 36 ft in three successive jumps and in the third jump lands on a man's back, whilst he is lying across the edge of two chairs, and off again without hurting him.
Jumps off one brick, end up, over a horse 15 hands high.
Darby's leap over a full sized billiard table lengthwise in Wolverhampton was mentioned in several editions of the [[Guinness World Records|Guinness Book of World Records]].<ref name="GBR 1974">{{cite book|last1=Biggar|first1=Suzi|title=Guinness Book of Records|date=1974|publisher=Guinness Superlatives|isbn=0900424222|page=224}}</ref> For this jump he took a running start and leapt from a 4 in wooden block, clearing the 12 ft long, 2 ft 10 in high table in one bound. This was achieved on 5 February 1892.
In 1893, a Canadian newspaper reported that: "he has thirty-nine feats in his performance or act, the most sensational of which is his great water jump, representing a jump from England to America. In accomplishing this feat he will alight on the water and off again without wetting the upper leather of his boots. This marvellous feat has never been accomplished by any artist in this world." <ref name="Montreal"/> More detail of this jump was given in an Australian publication: "a tank is set in the middle of the stage, and is filled to the brim with water. Mr Darby takes a flying leap, and as he passes over the water be descends slightly. By this downward motion he, as it were, alights on the top of the water, and flies off again without wetting the upper leather of his boots." When asked how he managed this feat, he replied: "I really don't know, it comes naturally to me, though when I think of it myself it seems almost an impossibility."<ref name="Telegraph Tasmania"/>
==The'Spring-heeled Jack' Legend==
Joseph Darby has been linked to the [[Spring-heeled Jack]] legend. In Victorian times, the legendary character known as 'Spring-heeled Jack' was reportedly spotted at a number of locations in Britain, including the Black Country. The creature was often described as having blazing eyes and had the ability to leap great distances. Joseph Darby supposedly started a local 'Spring-heeled Jack' scare when he was spotted practising his jumping by leaping over a local canal at night time, using a miner's lighted helmet to see his way.<ref name="Spring heeled jack">{{cite web|last1=Upton|first1=Chris|title=Spring-Heeled Jack|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/legacies/myths_legends/england/black_country/article_3.shtml|website=BBC - Legacies - Myths and Legends|publisher=BBC|accessdate=13 August 2015}}</ref>
==Commemoration==
Joseph Darby is commemorated by a statue in the centre of his native town of Netherton. The statue shows Darby in a crouched position about to leap holding weights in either hand. It is mounted on a plinth which describes some of his exploits. The statue, designed by Steve Field and fabricated by D.R. Harvey, was installed on 29 November 1991.<ref name="Joe Darby Obelisk">{{cite book|last1=Noszlopy|first1=George|last2=Waterhouse|first2=Fiona|title=Public Sculpture of Staffordshire and the Black Country|date=2005|publisher=Liverpool University Press|location=Liverpool|isbn=978-0853239994|pages=89–90}}</ref>
There is an exhibition of Joe Darby memorabilia in Dudley Museum at the Archives, including his championship belts.<ref name="Treasures">{{cite web |title=Treasures of the Museum |url=http://www.dudley.gov.uk/see-and-do/museums/dudley-museum-at-the-archives/treasures-of-the-museum/ |website=Dudley MBC |publisher=Dudley MBC |accessdate=24 July 2018}}</ref> Joseph Darby is also commemorated in a bronze plaque set into the pavement of Dudley's marketplace as part of the "Dudley Time Trail" designed by Dudley borough artist, Steve Field.<ref name="Time Trail">{{cite web|title=Work begins on Dudley Time Trail|url=http://www.dudley.gov.uk/media/media-releases/july-2015/31-work-begins-on-dudley-time-trail/|website=Dudley MBC|publisher=Dudley MBC|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref>
A radio play, entitled, "The Astounding Joseph Darby" written by John Edgar and directed by Nigel Bryant was broadcast on BBC Radio 4 on 4 July 1991.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/730a045cba934c9c80dcf6b14939c4e2|title=The Astounding Joseph Darby|last=|first=|date=2006|website=Genome BETA Radio Times 1923-2009|publisher=BBC|access-date=16 June 2016}}</ref>

revision.comment: Removing [[:c:File:Kattaikkuttu_Theatre-HD.webm|Kattaikkuttu_Theatre-HD.webm]], it has been deleted from Commons by [[:c:User:JuTa|JuTa]] because: [[:c:COM:OTRS|No permission]] since 7 February 2017.
revision.text:
'''Kattaikkuttu''' is a rural theatre form practiced in the State of [[Tamil Nadu]] in South [[India]].<ref name="Jackie1999">{{cite book | author=Jackie Assayag | title=The Resources of history: Tradition, narration and nation in South Asia | year=1999 | publisher=École française d'Extrême-Orient | isbn=978-2-85539-607-1 }}</ref> The performers – by tradition only men - sing, act and dance and the musicians accompany them on the [[Pump organ|harmonium]], the ''[[mridangam]]'' and the ''mukavinai''. The terms '''[[Terukkuttu]]''' and Kattaikkuttu are often used interchangeably. However, historically the two terms appear to have distinguished, at least in certain villages, between two different kinds of performance: while ''Terukkuttu'' referred to mobile performances by two actors participating in a procession for the village deity [[Mariamman]], ''Kattaikkuttu'' denotes overnight, narrative performances at a fixed performance space acted by an ensemble of about fifteen actors and musicians.<ref name="Hanne_flexibility">{{cite book | last = Bruin | first = Hanne M de | title = Kattaikkuttu: The flexibility of a south Indian theatre tradition | publisher = E. Forsten | year = 1999 | isbn = 978-90-6980-103-2 | oclc = 42312297 | pages = 85–99 }}</ref>
==History==
Kattaikkuttu derives its name from the word ''kattai'', which refers to the special ornaments worn by the actors during performances; ''kuttu'' refers to theatre. The audience recognizes the various characters by the shapes of their head wear and their make-up.<ref name="Hanne_flexibility"/>
Kattaikkuttu has been performed in rural Tamil Nadu for years. In November 1990, a group of seventeen rural actors and musicians founded, on the initiative of Kattaikkuttu actor Perungattur ''P. Rajagopal'', an organization to promote their theatre in the town of [[Kanchipuram]] in Tamil Nadu. They called this grassroots collective the ''Tamil Nadu Kattaikkuttu Kalai Valarcci Munnerra Sangam'' using the name of Kattaikkuttu rather than one of the current terms of ''Kuttu'' or ''Terukkuttu''. The main objectives of the ''Sangam'' – an officially registered society - were to promote Kattaikkuttu as a theatre form in its own right and to further the interests of professional performers. Since its inception more than twenty years ago, the Sangam has developed into an umbrella organization with a number of activities including educating and training a future generation of young, talented Kattaikkuttu performers (''the Kattaikkuttu Gurukulam''), opening up the theatre to rural girls and women, organization of an annual theatre festival and production of new and often innovative plays. In 2009 the organization shortened its name into ''Kattaikkuttu Sangam''.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Bruin | first = Hanne M. de | year = 2000 | title = Naming a theatre in Tamil Nadu | journal = Asian Theatre Journal | volume = 17 | issue = 1 | pages = 98–122 | doi=10.1353/atj.2000.0001 }}</ref>
==Repertory== Many traditional performances center on the enactment of parts of the [[Mahabharata]]; a few plays have [[Purana]] stories as their theme.<ref>{{cite book | last = Bruin | first = Hanne M de | title = Kattaikkuttu: The flexibility of a south Indian theatre tradition | publisher = E. Forsten | year = 1999 | isbn = 978-90-6980-103-2 | oclc = 42312297 | pages = 113–124 }}</ref> To cater to a renewed interest in the theatre from urban audiences and cultural institutions, new plays of shorter and all-night duration have also been created. These plays have been successfully performed in Indian metros and abroad and have been assimilated into the repertory of the Kattaikkuttu Gurukulam’s Young Professionals Company.
A few of the core plays of the traditional Kattaikkuttu repertory are: * ''The Bending of the Bow'' or ''[[Draupadi]]’s Marriage'' * ''[[Subhadra]]’s Marriage'' * ''The Royal Sacrifice'' * ''The Disrobing of Draupadi'' * ''[[Arjuna]]’s Penance'' * ''Kichaka’s Battle'' * ''[[Krishna]]’s Embassy'' * ''[[Karna]] Moksham''<ref>{{cite journal | last = Bruin | first = Hanne M. de | year = 1998 | title = Karna Moksham or Karna's Death: A Play by Pukalentippulavar | publisher = du Département d'Indologie }}</ref> *''The Eighteenth Day (featuring [[Duryodhana]]’s death on the battlefield of [[Kurukshetra]])'' *''Dakshya’s Sacrifice'' *''HiranyaVilasam''
Kattaikkuttu is usually performed in a religious setting and performances take place overnight: they start around 10pm and run until 6am the next morning. The occasions for Kattaikkuttu performances can be divided into the following categories:<ref>{{cite book | last = Bruin | first = Hanne M de | title = Kattaikkuttu: The flexibility of a south Indian theatre tradition | publisher = E. Forsten | year = 1999 | isbn = 978-90-6980-103-2 | oclc = 42312297 | pages= 111–113 }}</ref>
#Paratam (Mahabharata) festivals in honor of the Goddess #Other village festivals such as those for Mariyamman, Ankalamman, Shiva and Vishnu #Rites of individuals such as death rites #Secular occasions e.g. cultural festivals The Kattaikkuttu Gurukulam is regularly visited by prominent scholars in the theatre world--for example, Bennington College professor Sue Rees regularly visits the school to produce [https://vimeo.com/user5142370 short videos and documentaries] which feature various Kattaikkuttu works.
==Style== Kattaikkuttu derives its name from the fact that a specific category of actors wear the so-called ''kattai'' or ''kattai samankal''. Kattai are wooden head, shoulder and the breast ornaments inlaid with mirror work. The kattai represent power, heroic qualities and royalty. The kattai-wearers represent [[superhuman]] – divine or demonic – warriors who are the main agents in the mythological battles around which the performances are built.
The ''acting arena'' is an open rectangular ground and the audience sits on three sides of the ground. The singers and the instrument players occupy the rear of the stage. The play begins with a musical introduction and songs in praise to several different deities. The first character to appear on stage is the [[clown]] or ''Kattiyakkaran'' (literally ''Praise Maker''). The Kattiyakkaran is central to Kattaikkuttu performances: he provides entertainment, serves as the guardian of and opposite number for the principal characters and translates events from the epic and Puranic stories into everyday life experiences of the rural audiences. After his comic introduction, the Kattiyakkaran announces the title of the play to be performed and the entry of one of the principal characters. The stage entry of most kattai characters takes place behind a curtain held across the stage by two assistant performers. Such a ''curtain entry'' requires the actor to perform a prescribed routine of songs and dance. All Kattaikkuttu actors sing themselves, supported by the chorus.
==About the Gurukulam==
The ''Kattaikkuttu Gurukulam'' was founded in October 2002 by actor, playwright and director ''P. Rajagopal'' and ''Dr. Hanne M. de Bruin'' to preserve and enhance the scope of the Kattaikkuttu theatre and safeguard the artistic and economic position of its future exponents. The students are marginalized, young rural people between 5 and 20 years with a keen interest in the theatre form. Located 8 kilometers away from Kanchipuram in a small village called Punjarasantankal, the Kattaikkuttu Gurukulam follows the [[Guru-shishya tradition|guru-shishya system]] of transmission. This means that students and teachers are in constant close contact with each other in formal and non-formal settings. The Gurukulam's students are tutored in life and in all aspects of the Perungattur style of Kattaikkuttu apart from receiving a formal education.
The Kattaikkuttu Gurukulam comes under the auspices of the Kattaikkuttu Sangam. It runs its own theatre company, the Kattaikkuttu Young Professionals consisting of senior students and graduates of the Gurukulam. The girl students of the Kattaikkuttu Gurukulam have their own ensemble, the Kattaikkuttu All-Girls Company, which serves as a laboratory to experiment with gender sensitive issues.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Bruin | first = Hanne M. de | year = 2009 | title = Kattaikkuttu Girls | journal = Theatre in Colonial India: Play-House of Power | pages = 241–269 | publisher = Oxford University Press }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading== {{cite book | last = Frasca | first = Richard Armando | title = Theatre of the Mahabharata: terukkuttu Performances in South India | publisher = University of Hawaii Press | year = 1990 | isbn = 978-0-8248-1290-4 | oclc = 21147946 }}
==External links== * [http://www.kattaikkuttu.org/katinfo1.html Kattaikkuttu Sangam ]
