revision.text:
{{update|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox television |show_name = Pure Pwnage |image = Purepwnage.jpg |caption = ''Pure Pwnage'' title screen |genre = [[Mockumentary]]
[[Comedy]] |runtime = 10–50 minutes (web series)
22 minutes (TV series) |creator = Jarett Cale
Geoff Lapaire |starring = Jarett Cale
Geoff Lapaire
Joel Gardiner |executive_producer = [[Derek Harvie]]
Catherine Tait
[[Ron Mann]] |producer = Jarett Cale
Geoff Lapaire |country = Canada |language = English |location = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] |network = [[Showcase (Canadian TV channel)|Showcase]] (TV series) |first_aired = Web series: {{Start date|2004|5|11}} – {{End date|2008|8|23}}
Television series: {{Start date|2010|3|12}} – {{End date|2010|4|30}} |last_aired = |num_seasons = 2 (web series)
1 (TV series) |num_episodes = 18 (web series)
8 (TV series) |list_episodes = List of Pure Pwnage episodes |website = http://www.purepwnage.com }} '''''Pure Pwnage''''' (pronounced "pure ownage")The word "pwnage" can be pronounced several different ways. The show's creators pronounce it "ownage". Jeremy justifies this pronunciation with the following statements: "When people say [[Pwn|{{IPA|/ˈpoʊn/}}]], they sound like a complete fag, and I'm not cool with being a fag, so I pronounce it {{IPA|/ˈoʊn/}}." {{" '}}Pwn' was originally a typo of 'own', because the 'P' is near the 'O' on the keyboard. The person is still trying to say 'own'." [TeamSpeak chat, December 13, 2005]. was a Canadian [[web series|Internet-distributed]], [[mockumentary]] series from ROFLMAO Productions. The fictional series purports to chronicle the life and adventures of Jeremy (played by Jarett Cale), a [[Canadians|Canadian]] and self-proclaimed "[[pro gamer]]". In 2010, an adaptation of the web series began airing on [[Showcase (Canadian TV channel)|Showcase]], a [[Television in Canada|Canadian]] [[cable television]] [[specialty channel|channel]], but the series failed to be picked up for a second season. == Premise == Jeremy (played by Jarett Cale) also known as "teh_pwnerer" is extremely proficient at [[video games]] but inexperienced when it comes to [[Norm (sociology)|normal social interactions]]. Jeremy is only interested in "[[pwn]]ing [[noob|n00bs]]" and making it as a [[pro gamer]] and often comes off as lazy and narcissistic to other people. Kyle (played by Geoff Lapaire) is Jeremy's brother and an aspiring film-maker. Kyle decides to film a documentary of Jeremy's exploits as a [[gamer]] and his interactions with the gaming and non-gaming world. In 2012, it was announced that the crew are making a Pure Pwnage film with funding by their fans. == Cast == {{main|List of Pure Pwnage characters}} == Episodes == {{main|List of Pure Pwnage episodes}} There are currently eighteen web episodes available to the public and eight TV episodes. {{:List of Pure Pwnage episodes}} == History == ''Pure Pwnage'' was created by Geoff Lapaire and Jarett Cale who also play the show's main protagonists. Originating in 2004, eighteen Internet-distributed episodes of the series have been released to date. In 2007, the series creators estimated their current viewer base to be over three million.{{cite web | title = The Infancy of Internet Television | author = Geoff Lapaire | publisher = Pure Pwnage | url = http://www.purepwnage.com/index.php?GUID=19150 | accessdate = 2007-11-17 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071215065150/http://www.purepwnage.com/index.php?GUID=19150 | archivedate = 2007-12-15 | df = }} The series is filmed primarily in [[Toronto]], Ontario, but has also included scenes filmed in [[Calgary]], Alberta; [[Montreal]], Quebec; [[Aurora, Ontario]]; [[Hamilton, Ontario]]; and the [[Netherlands]]. During an interview, director Geoff Lapaire (although as "Kyle"; Lapaire maintained his "Kyle" identity among fans and media) insisted that all of the characters on the show are not acting.Starting with Episode 8, the ''Pure Pwnage'' cast and crew hold a public [[TeamSpeak]] interview soon after the release of each episode, revealing many details about the show and the personalities involved in its creation. The recordings of each episode are linked in a [http://www.purepwnage.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=54783 post] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927010003/http://www.purepwnage.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=54783 |date=2007-09-27 }} on the forums. He suggested that the personalities on ''Pure Pwnage'' display their true-to-life abilities and eccentricities, and the characters took great pains to maintain that the ''Pure Pwnage'' world is simply an extension of the real world. Lapaire has finally admitted that they are in fact actors. The sixth fanchat with the crew was out-of-character, where the fact that the characters within ''Pure Pwnage'' are exaggerated versions of the actors was confirmed. On August 6, 2009, it was announced that a ''Pure Pwnage'' TV series had been commissioned by [[Showcase (Canadian TV channel)|Showcase]].https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tV6cjKxZFOM Upon the announcement, many members of the ''Pure Pwnage'' fan community raised concerns. The main complaints were that the series was only announced to be airing in Canada, and the assumption that it would be changed in order to appeal to viewers not familiar with [[internet culture]]. Jarett Cale, who writes the show and plays Jeremy, tried to quell the complaints on the ''Pure Pwnage'' forums, saying "We're doing our best to get it broadcast in the USA, UK, Australia, etc., but it's really up to each country's respective broadcasters. ''[...]'' Geoff and I are still the main creative force – we're producers and writers. We've also brought on many new people with experience in traditional television to help us out both story-wise and production-wise. FPS Doug will still be there, and he will still be played by Joel Gardiner."{{cite web|url=http://www.purepwnage.com/forums/index.php?s=&showtopic=92459&view=findpost&p=1770140 |title=''Pure Pwnage'' forum post |last=Cale |first=Jarett |date=2009-08-06 |publisher=ROFLMAO Productions |accessdate=2009-08-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100616054549/http://purepwnage.com/forums/index.php?s= |archivedate=June 16, 2010 }} In response to a user asking if the TV series meant there would be no more web episodes, he said "Nope, it only means there's a new TV series."{{cite web|url=http://www.purepwnage.com/forums/index.php?s=&showtopic=92541&view=findpost&p=1772872 |title=''Pure Pwnage'' forum post |last=Cale |first=Jarett |date=2008-08-10 |publisher=ROFLMAO Productions |accessdate=2009-08-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100616054549/http://purepwnage.com/forums/index.php?s= |archivedate=June 16, 2010 }} Despite this, the future of the web series was uncertain. Geoff Lapaire, director of all previous episodes of ''Pure Pwnage'', left the show in September 2008 to focus on the then-unannounced TV series, and Troy Dixon, who played T-Bag in the series, died in a car accident on December 6, 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.purepwnage.com/forums/index.php?s=&showtopic=84552&view=findpost&p=1600457 |title=''Pure Pwnage'' forum post |date=2008-12-09 |publisher=ROFLMAO Productions |accessdate=2009-08-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100616054549/http://purepwnage.com/forums/index.php?s= |archivedate=June 16, 2010 }} Jarett Cale announced in January 2009 that work on the next web episode had begun, with him as the director, however the episode has not been released.{{cite web|url=http://www.purepwnage.com/index.php?GUID=86392 |title=''Pure Pwnage'' news post |last=Cale |first=Jarett |date=2009-01-27 |publisher=ROFLMAO Productions |accessdate=2009-08-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090720025702/http://www.purepwnage.com/index.php?GUID=86392 |archivedate=July 20, 2009 }} In a short Livestream cast on March 15, 2010, a user posted a comment regarding the web series and Jarett replied that the web series is back in production and is in progress. He has not given out an ETA. On January 19, 2011, Jarett made an announcement on the Pure Pwnage forums that the TV series had not been picked up for a second season. Additionally, the web series has been put on indefinite hold. In his own words, "My hope that Pure Pwnage will see a proper ending to its illustrious web series has nearly vanished. I've let Geoff know that should he be willing at any time to resume some of his traditional, critical roles on the web series I will fly home to Toronto in a heartbeat to help make it happen." On September 18, 2012 The Pure Pwnage YouTube channel uploaded a video titled "010100100100010101010100010101010101001001001110" which is a binary encoding of the word "Return", signalling the return of the Pure Pwnage. ==Pure Pwnage Teh Movie== On September 19, 2012, an official [[crowd funding]] campaign was announced to aid in the funding of a Pure Pwnage movie.http://www.indiegogo.com/purepwnage The $75,000 goal was raised in just over 24 hours, due to overwhelming support from fans all over the world. At the end of the campaign, a total of $211,300 was raised. On November 22, 2015, the official trailer was released. The movie premiered in Toronto on January 23, 2016 at the Bloor Cinema. Further screenings took place around the US and in the UK. On May 7, 2016, Pure Pwnage Teh Movie was released for streaming and digital download via Vimeo. === Reception and awards === Pure Pwnage Teh Movie received the Canadian Comedy Awards 2016 award for best feature film.{{Cite web|url=http://canadiancomedyawards.org/awards.php|title=Awards {{!}} Canadian Comedy Awards|website=canadiancomedyawards.org|access-date=2016-11-22}} The film was well-received by general audiences.{{Citation|last=Lapaire|first=Geoff|title=Pure Pwnage|date=2016-02-03|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4682866/|accessdate=2016-11-22}} == Spin-offs == === TV series === On August 6, 2009, it was announced that a ''Pure Pwnage'' TV series had been commissioned by [[Showcase (Canadian TV channel)|Showcase]].{{cite web|url=http://www.purepwnage.com/index.php?GUID=92459|title=Pure Pwnage announcement: "Project X Revealed"|publisher=ROFLMAO Productions|accessdate=2009-08-16|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090811220757/http://www.purepwnage.com/index.php?GUID=92459|archivedate=2009-08-11|df=}} The announcement was made in the form of a mini-episode where Kyle tries to convince Jeremy to stop playing on his [[Nintendo DS Lite]] and make the announcement. The series had been teased for several months under the name "Project X". The TV series premiered on [[Showcase (Canadian TV channel)|Showcase]] March 12, 2010, and premiered on Australia's [[ABC2]] on October 4, 2010. According to creator Jarett Cale, the TV series itself takes place in a fictional world within the Pure Pwnage universe (webseries) where Kyle ironically got a TV series, thus explaining the lack of consistency between shows.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/guide/abc2/201010/programs/ZX1389A001D2010-10-04T210600.htm?program=Pure%20Pwnage|title=Pure Pwnage - Life Of A Pro Gamer|accessdate=2010-09-27}} === Jeremy's Mail Sac === Starting in March 2010, the ''Pure Pwnage'' website began letting fans send Jeremy questions via e-mail. Jeremy then answered the fan questions in video segments posted on the website titled, ''Jeremy's Mail Sac''. === Pro at Cooking === {{Main|Pro at Cooking}} Starring Dave (Dawei) as himself, ''Pro at Cooking'' is a spin-off of ''Pure Pwnage''. A cooking show for gamers with Dave hosting as the main chef. When his female assistants do not perform as expected, Dave constantly fires each one of them usually after every episode. Directed by Davin, it has only aired seven 5- to 10-minute episodes. No other characters from ''Pure Pwnage'', excluding Dave, Davin, and Geoff, appear on the show. === ''Pure Pwnage: The Comic'' === From February 28, 2006 to March 7, 2007, the ''Pure Pwnage'' website featured a regularly issued comic, of which a new page was released once every two to three weeks. Apparently set in the "real world" rather than in the fictional world of ''Pure Pwnage'', the comic breaks most of the [[fourth wall]] of the show. For example, Dave said in the show that he was leaving it due to unfinished business in China, the comic claims that the real reason was that he had found a new job in [[Vancouver]]. However, both the show and comic clearly contain elements that are either symbolic representations of reality (for example, [[pwn]]ing an opponent with "micro balls" as a possible metaphor for pwning them in an actual video game) or are not based in reality whatsoever. === Pure Pwnage: Teh Movie === In September 2012, series creators Jarett Cale and Geoff Lapaire announced an indiegogo campaign to raise funds for a Pure Pwnage feature-length film. Within 24 hours of the campaign being launched, the project had received their goal of $75,000, and by the end of the campaign, they had reached a total of $211,300. Despite this being a relatively small film budget, Jarett Cale and Geoff Lapaire have said that with their experience of making the web series with an extremely limited amount of funds, they are confident that they would be able to make a quality film shot in countries across the world, mentioning hopes of filming in South Korea. Pre-production began in earnest in early 2013, with weekly twitch.tv livestreams in which Lapaire, Cale, and guests such as Joel Gardiner (fps_doug) and Miranda Plant (Tagi) discuss the film and interact with fans. The film premiered on January 23, 2016, in Toronto, Ontario. Following this, Cale and Lapaire took the film to the road, screening the project around the world in a touring limited release. On May 7, 2016, Pure Pwnage Teh Movie was released for streaming and digital download on Vimeo. == Notes == {{more footnotes|date=February 2008}} {{reflist}} == External links == {{portal|Television in Canada}} {{wikiquote}} * {{official website|http://www.purepwnage.com}} * [http://www.ppartchive.com ''Pure Pwnage Artchive''] {{Showcase programming (Canada)}} [[Category:2004 web series debuts]] [[Category:2008 web series endings]] [[Category:2010 Canadian television series debuts]] [[Category:2010 Canadian television series endings]] [[Category:2010s Canadian satirical television series]] [[Category:2010s Canadian sitcoms]] [[Category:Comedy web series]] [[Category:Canadian mockumentary television series]] [[Category:Showcase network shows]] [[Category:Works about video games]] [[Category:Canadian web series]]

<!--[[File:Reinald Werrenrath (August 7, 1883 – September 12, 1953) in 1917.jpg|thumb]]--> [[File:Reinald Werrenrath in 1917 at his piano.jpg|thumb|Werrenrath in 1917 at his piano]] '''Reinald Werrenrath''' (August 7, 1883 – September 12, 1953) was an [[United States|American]] [[baritone]] [[opera]] singer, who also recorded [[popular music|popular songs]] and appeared regularly on [[radio]] in the early decades of the twentieth century.<ref name=findagrave/>
==Biography== He was born in [[Brooklyn, New York]], the son of George Werrenrath, an operatic [[tenor]] born in [[Denmark]]. He studied at [[New York University]], and made his operatic debut in 1907 in ''[[Die Meistersinger]]''. He also recorded for [[Edison Records]] in 1907, before a long recording career with the [[Victor Talking Machine Company]]. He sang on several hundred Victor recordings between 1906 and 1929, both as a soloist and as part of various vocal ensembles such as the Orpheus Quartet and the Victor Opera Quartet.<ref name="whitburn memories"/><ref name=jukebox>[https://www.loc.gov/jukebox/artists/detail/id/1151/ Library of Congress: National Jukebox]. Retrieved 15 May 2013</ref> His most commercially successful recordings included "As Long As The World Rolls On" (1907), "Hello Frisco!" (from ''"[[Ziegfeld Follies]] of 1915"''), and "[[Smilin' Through (song)|Smilin' Through]]" (1919).<ref name="whitburn memories">{{cite book| last1 = Whitburn | first1 = Joel| title = Pop Memories 1890-1954: The History of American Popular Music| location = Menomonee Falls, Wisconsin| publisher = Record Research, Inc. | year= 1986| pages = 445| isbn = 0-89820-083-0}}</ref>
Werrenrath made his debut at the [[Metropolitan Opera]] in 1919, in ''[[Pagliacci]]'', in a cast that also included [[Enrico Caruso]].<ref name=findagrave/> He also toured widely, and made over 3,000 concert appearances.<ref name="whitburn memories"/> He was one of the first singing stars to appear regularly on [[radio]], notably on radio station [[WNBC (AM)|WEAF]] in New York. In 1930, he made a private recording of [[Christmas]] greetings accompanied by [[Harpo Marx]] and others.<ref>[http://nationaleducationsolutions.com/2012/02/20/alexander-woollcott-harpo-marx-reinald-werrenrath-1930/ National Education Solutions: Alexander Woollcott, Harpo Marx, Reinald Werrenrath] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130706012858/http://nationaleducationsolutions.com/2012/02/20/alexander-woollcott-harpo-marx-reinald-werrenrath-1930/ |date=2013-07-06 }}. Retrieved 15 May 2013</ref> In 1932, he became a member of [[NBC]]'s music staff, and in later years devoted himself mainly to teaching, at the [[Peabody Conservatory]] in [[Baltimore, Maryland]] and elsewhere.<ref name=jukebox/> He also ran a regular summer music school at [[Dannemora (town), New York|Chazy Lake, New York]].<ref name=findagrave/>
He was married three times. He died on September 12, 1953 in [[Plattsburgh, New York]], after suffering a [[heart attack]] while at Chazy Lake.<ref name=findagrave>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Werrenrath Dies; Radio Singing Star. Baritone Who Was Heard in 20's Made Concert Appearances, Owned Music School Plattsburg, N.Y. |url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/57226723 |quote= |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date= 13 September 1953 |accessdate=2015-01-12 }}</ref>
His home on Chazy Lake, [[Werrenrath Camp]], was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 2010.<ref name="nris">{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/listings/20101210.htm|title=National Register of Historic Places|date=2010-12-10|work=Weekly List of Actions Taken on Properties: 11/29/10 through 12/03/10|publisher=National Park Service}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commonscat}} *[http://victor.library.ucsb.edu/index.php/talent/detail/28479/Werrenrath_Reinald_vocalist_baritone_vocal Victor Records discography] '''Streaming audio''' *[https://www.loc.gov/jukebox/search/results?q=Reinald%20Werrenrath Reinald Werrenrath] on [[Victor Talking Machine Company|Victor Records]] *[http://cylinders.library.ucsb.edu/search.php?queryType=%40attr+1%3D1016+&query=Reinald+Werrenrath Reinald Werrenrath] on [[Edison Records]] *[https://archive.org/search.php?query=Reinald%20Werrenrath%20AND%20mediatype%3Aaudio Reinald Werrenrath] at the [[Internet Archive]]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Werrenrath, Reinald}} [[Category:1883 births]] [[Category:1953 deaths]] [[Category:American operatic baritones]] [[Category:Edison Records artists]] [[Category:Pioneer recording artists]] [[Category:Victor Records artists]] [[Category:American people of Danish descent]] [[Category:20th-century American singers]]

{{about|the TV series}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Saturday Night at the Movies | show_name_2 = | image = | caption = | genre = [[films]] | creator = | director = | developer = | presenter = [[Elwy Yost]] (1974-1999)
[[Shelagh Rogers]] (1999-2000)
[[Johanna Schneller]] (2004-2006)
Thom Ernst (2006-2013) | starring = | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = Canada | language = English | num_seasons = 39 | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | executive_producer = | producer = Risa Shuman (1974-2005) | supervising_producer = | asst_producer = | co-producer = | editor = | story_editor = | location = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada | camera = | runtime = | network = [[TVOntario]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = March 30, 1974 | last_aired = August 31, 2013 | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = }} '''''Saturday Night at the Movies''''' was a weekly [[television]] series on [[TVOntario]], the public educational television network in [[Ontario]], [[Canada]]."TVO's Saturday Night transcended the eras". ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', November 15, 2012. The series presented classic [[film|movies]], followed by interviews and feature segments with [[film director|directors]], [[actor]]s and other people involved in making the films presented."Remembering nearly 40 years of Saturday Night at the Movies: As the series' last broadcast draws near, former hosts and staff share memories". ''[[Toronto Star]]'', August 29, 2013. The show was initially formatted in this way due to requirements that all programming shown on TVO (including dramatic programming) needed to contain educational elements, which was usually accomplished by including interviews and analysis of the programming. Nevertheless, even after these requirements were dropped, the format was maintained; all told, the series presented almost 1,500 films and over 1,000 interviews. The show was produced for much of its run by Risa Shuman.Richard Ouzonian, [https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/2011/07/24/ouzounian_the_secret_to_elwy_yosts_success.html "The secret to Elwy Yost’s success"]. ''[[Toronto Star]]'', July 24, 2011. ==Broadcast history== ===Elwy Yost era=== First aired on March 30, 1974, the program was originally hosted by [[Elwy Yost]]. The first film shown was [[Ingmar Bergman]]'s ''[[Through a Glass Darkly (film)|Through a Glass Darkly]]''. During Yost's 25-year tenure as host, he showed a variety of foreign films, but tended to concentrate on Hollywood-produced films from the 1930s through the 1950s, slowly expanding into also showing films from the 1960s and 1970s as the series progressed. For a number of years, however, the show was not able to broadcast films from the [[Warner Bros.]] studio, as TVOntario's transmitter in [[Windsor, Ontario|Windsor]] created a programming rights conflict with stations in [[Detroit]]."TVO prepares for a revamp ; But so far no host to replace Elwy Yost". ''[[Toronto Star]]'', July 19, 2000. In his final decade hosting the show, Yost lived in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], and would travel to Toronto to prepare many episodes of the show at once. Yost retired as host of the series in 1999.Changing faces: Taking over Elwy Yost's host job bittersweet for Shelagh Rogers". ''[[Waterloo Region Record]]'', October 9, 1999. The last film he presented was, atypically, a recent Hollywood blockbuster: ''[[Speed (1994 film)|Speed]]'' was personally chosen by Yost to conclude his run as host, as it was written by his son, screenwriter [[Graham Yost]]. Around the same time as his retirement, he was inducted into the [[Order of Canada]]."Munsch, Yost, Egoyan named to Order". ''[[Welland Tribune]]'', July 8, 1999. ===After Yost=== Soon after Yost's retirement, the [[Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario|Progressive Conservative]] government of [[Mike Harris]] appointed [[Isabel Bassett]] as chair of TVOntario, with a mandate to refocus the network's broadcast schedule more clearly on education."Isabel Bassett, the made-for-TV mover: The former culture minister is getting high marks in her tough new assignment at TVO". ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', May 9, 2000. Although there was some concern that the network would lose ''Saturday Night at the Movies'', its highest-rated program,"Isabel Bassett 'delighted' to be named TVO head ; Former culture minister to put focus back on education". ''[[Toronto Star]]'', November 19, 1999. Bassett instead negotiated an agreement with [[York University]] to include the series in its [[film studies]] curriculum."Elwy 101: TVO and York collaborate on film studies". ''[[Guelph Mercury]]'', February 21, 2004. Yost was replaced as host for one season by [[Shelagh Rogers]], concurrently with her continuing role as host of [[CBC Music|CBC Stereo]]'s classical music program ''Take Five''. When Rogers became the host of CBC Radio's morning news program ''[[This Morning (radio program)|This Morning]]'' in 2000, she left ''Saturday Night at the Movies'', which briefly changed to a hostless format."Saturday Night at the Movies goes hostless". ''[[Ottawa Citizen]]'', September 29, 2000. At this time, the series added a Sunday night companion series, ''Sunday Night at the Cinema'', which focused more on international film. The program was then hosted by [[Johanna Schneller]] for two seasons beginning in 2004."Intelligence quotient". ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', September 18, 2004. The show's final host, for the remainder of its run, was Thom Ernst."Curtain prepares to close on TV show: Saturday Night at the Movies wraps up on TVO after 39 years". ''[[Toronto Star]]'', August 23, 2013. On November 13, 2012, it was announced that TVO would cancel ''Saturday Night at the Movies'' as of the end of the 2012-2013 season, amidst budget cuts incurred by the network.[http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/1069963/tvo-announces-plan-that-looks-to-future "TVO Announces Plan That Looks to Future"]. ''[[Canada Newswire]]'', November 13, 2012. The final edition of ''Saturday Night at the Movies'' was broadcast on August 31, 2013, featuring two foreign films as its last movies: ''[[The Lives of Others]]'' (at 8 P.M.), and ''[[Black Book (film)|Black Book]]'' (starting at 10:50 P.M.) Peter Howell, [https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/movies/2013/08/23/saturday_night_at_the_movies_when_going_to_the_movies_meant_staying_in_howell.html "Saturday Night at the Movies, when going to the movies meant staying in"]. ''[[Toronto Star]]'', August 23, 2013. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{portal|Television in Canada}} *{{IMDb title | id=0171011 | title=Saturday Night at the Movies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Saturday Night At The Movies}} [[Category:TVOntario shows]] [[Category:1974 Canadian television series debuts]] [[Category:Motion picture television series]] [[Category:2013 Canadian television series endings]] [[Category:1970s Canadian television series]] [[Category:1980s Canadian television series]] [[Category:1990s Canadian television series]] [[Category:2000s Canadian television series]] [[Category:2010s Canadian television series]]

{{Multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=May 2017}} {{COI|date=May 2017}} }} {{Infobox model | name = Stacey Roy | image = Stacey on Stage.png | caption = Stacey Roy on stage | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Banff, Alberta]], Canada | nationality = Canadian | citizenship = Canadian | ethnicity = | years_active = 2006–present (Acting)
2011–present (Cosplaying)
2012–present (Hosting) | occupation = [[Film producer|Producer]], [[Talk show host|Host]], [[Actor]], [[Streaming media|Streamer]], [[YouTuber]], [[Voice actor]], [[Cosplayer]] | measurements = | height = 5’6 | weight = | hair_color = Dark Brown | eye_color = Hazel }} '''Stacey Roy''' (born February 9) is a Canadian [[actor]], [[Film producer|producer]], [[Talk show host|host]], live broadcaster and [[content creator]]. She runs Whabam Media with her partner Mike Parkerson.{{cite web|title=Whabam About Page|url=http://www.whabammedia.com/about|website=Whabam Media|accessdate=20 April 2017}}{{cite web|title=Konami Interview with Stacey Roy|url=http://uk-blog.konami-europe.com/2014/11/11/whabams-silent-hill-fan-film|website=Konami Blog UK|publisher=Konami|accessdate=20 April 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151006212340/http://uk-blog.konami-europe.com/2014/11/11/whabams-silent-hill-fan-film|archivedate=6 October 2015|df=}} ==Early life== Roy was born in [[Banff, Alberta]], Canada to Teresa and Kurtis Roy. She was crowned Miss Teen Red Deer and Miss Teen Calgary in 2005.{{cite news|title=Strathmore Girl Crowned|url=http://www.strathmorestandard.com/2005/04/21/strathmore-girl-crowned|accessdate=20 April 2017|publisher=Strathmore Standard|date=April 21, 2005}} She later moved to [[Vancouver, British Columbia]] where she graduated from [[Vancouver Film School]] in Acting for Film and Television. ==Career== Roy's screen debut was in 2010 with the role of Jane in [[30 Days of Night: Dark Days]].{{cite web|title=30 Days of Night: Dark Days (2010 Video) Full Cast & Crew|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1320304/fullcredits?ref_=tt_cl_sm#cast|website=IMDB|accessdate=10 May 2017}} Between 2010 and 2012, she acted and auditioned for several roles while learning the art of bartending at Uva Wine Bar, which inspired her first show, The Nerdy Bartender.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} Roy met Mike Parkerson in 2012 and they created a film production company called Whabam Media. In 2013, she designed her costume for her second fan film ''[[Starcraft]]: Hunt for Kerrigan'', which was nominated for Best Action Short at the Geeksboro Film Fest in 2015.{{cite news|title=Geekboro Film Festival|url=http://www.thetimesnews.com/20150402/fan-film-fest-set-for-may-1-7/304029861|accessdate=20 April 2017|agency=Gatehouse Media|publisher=The Times News}} Roy's first [[cosplay]] convention was in 2013 at Vancouver Anime Revolution where she dressed as Princess Daisy from her [[Smash Bros]] fan film. Her next short film, [[Silent Hill]], was inspired by the [[P.T trailer]] released in 2014. Shortly after release, she was interviewed by [[Konami]] where she revealed her other company Vancosplay Photography which she ran with Ryan Cooper Vancosplay focused on high quality composites rather than typical convention photography but closed in 2016.{{cite web|last1=Cooper|first1=Ryan|title=Vancosplay Photography|url=http://vancosplay.com/|website=Vancosplay Photography|accessdate=20 April 2017}} In 2015, Whabam Media released the trailer for [[Overwatch (video game)|Overwatch]] Legacy. Roy submitted the video for the [[Blizzcon]] Video Contest but it didn’t place. It did gain attention from [[IGN]]{{cite web|title=7 OVERWATCH COSPLAYERS YOU NEED TO SEE - IGN ACCESS|url=http://ca.ign.com/videos/2015/11/08/7-overwatch-cosplayers-you-need-to-see-ign-access|website=IGN|accessdate=20 April 2017}} and [[Kotaku]] for her cosplay as Tracer and she was named one of the top cosplayers alongside [[Jessica Nigri]], by IGN.{{cite web|last1=Vas|first1=Gergo|title=People Are Already Making Overwatch Fan-Movies|url=http://kotaku.com/people-are-already-making-overwatch-fan-movies-1719919813|website=Kotaku|accessdate=20 April 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Macy|first1=Seth|title=8 AWESOME COSPLAYERS AND THEIR AMAZING WORK|url=http://in.ign.com/metal-gear-solid-5/88304/feature/8-awesome-cosplayers-and-their-amazing-work|website=IGN|accessdate=20 April 2017}} In 2016, co-hosted episode 150 of The Attack with Alex Corea.{{cite web|title=The Attack (2015– ) Full Cast & Crew|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6127996/fullcredits?ref_=tt_cl_sm#cast|website=IMDB|accessdate=17 May 2017}} Between 2014 and 2015, Roy worked with YouTubers IFHT both in acting and producing capacities. The videos include How to be a DJ, How to be a Filmmaker and Bad Ways to Get Rid of Your Girlfriend. She also worked with YouTubers [[Film Riot]] shooting behind the scenes for a series of [[DJI (company)|DJI]] commercials.{{cite web|last1=Maher|first1=Michael|title=DJI and Film Riot Launch an Online Film School|url=https://www.premiumbeat.com/blog/dji-film-riot-launch-online-film-school/|website=Premium Beat|accessdate=20 April 2017}} Later in 2015, Roy played [[Harley Quinn]] in the [[Leo Award]] nominated fan film Nightwing: The Darkest Knight directed by Matthew Campbell.{{cite web|title=The Nominees for Best Cinematography in a Short Drama|url=http://www.leoawards.com/2016/nominees/by_name.php#Short_Drama-Cinematography|website=Leo Awards|accessdate=20 April 2017}} Her work with the character was praised.{{cite web|title=Review: NIGHTWING: THE DARKEST KNIGHT|url=http://www.mercwithamovieblog.com/2016/01/review-nightwing-darkest-knight.html|website=Merc with a Movie Blog|accessdate=20 April 2017}}{{cite web|title=3 EPIC VANCOUVER-MADE FAN-FILMS|url=https://604now.com/3-epic-vancouver-made-fan-films/|website=604 Now|accessdate=20 April 2017}} ===WHABAM.tv=== [[File:Stacey on the Whabam Studio for a Halloween Themed Nerdy Bartender.jpg|thumb|Stacey on the Whabam Studio for a Halloween Themed Nerdy Bartender]] In 2016, Roy began to switch from [[YouTube]] to [[Twitch.tv|Twitch]]. She launched several shows on the channel such as The Nerdy Bartender (a talk show featuring special guests and thematic crafted drinks), Heads Up (a [[Virtual Reality]] talk show with industry guests and gameplay interaction), Table of Terror (a seasonal, tabletop [[Dungeons and Dragons]] experience with recurring guests), Winesday Gaming (a more traditional gaming show), “Cooking” with Stacey (a competition show with a different ingredient or theme each week) and The Stacey Roy Podcast.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} In 2016, Roy and Parkerson transformed their garage into a studio called the Whabam Studio.{{cite web|title=WHABAM.tv Studio|url=http://whabammedia.com/WhabamStudio|website=WHABAM.tv|accessdate=20 April 2017}} The technical multicam setup consists of [[Blackmagic Design]] cameras, wireless lavalier mics, color changing bulbs, and diffused box lighting and teleprompters. Each set wall is magnetic and designed to be easily swappable so the studio can be modified to suit the individual needs of each show. The construction of the studio was live streamed and much of the cost was covered by her fans. Roy has worked with charities since 2005 including the [[Leo Club]], Students Against Drunk Driving, [[the Chive]], and Operation Supply Drop.{{cite web|title=OSDTV Podcast with Filthy Casual, Darshelle and Stacey Roy|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-OYH37e9c7U|website=YouTube|publisher=Operation Supply Drop|accessdate=20 April 2017}} ==Filmography== ===Film, television and live broadcasts=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ List of performances in film, television and live broadcasts |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- |2013 |''[[Starcraft]] - Hunt for Kerrigan'' | Rain |Award nominated |- |2013 |''[[Smash Bros]]: The Early Years'' | Princess Daisy |- |2013 |''[[Package Deal]] - Danny Escapes to Prison | Kissing Diner #2 |- |2014 |''[[Silent Hill]] - The Cosplay Fan Film'' | Lead |- |2015 |''[[Overwatch (video game)|Overwatch]] Legacy'' | Tracer |- |2016 |''[[Nightwing]]: The Darkest Knight'' | Harley Quinn | Leo Award Nominated fan film |- |2016 |''The Attack'' | Host | Co-hosted with Alex Corea on Episode 150 |- |2017 |''[[Overwatch (video game)|Overwatch]] in REAL Life!'' | Tracer | High budget fan film by [[Devin Graham]] |- |2014–present |''The Nerdy Bartender'' | Host | Switch from YouTube to Twitch in Season 3 (Mid 2016) |- |2017–present |''"Cooking" with Stacey'' | Host |- |} ===Music videos=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role |- |2014 |"Hollywood"{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YO3lDqKh5Go |title=Abandon Paris - Hollywood (American Idol Parody) - Abandon Paris Official Music Video |publisher=YouTube |date=May 8, 2014 |accessdate=May 8, 2014 |author=Whabam Media}} |"Lead" |- |2012 |"Hey Lou"{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nTLz0V7FJM4 |title=Hey Lou (Canucks/Beatles Parody) - |publisher=YouTube |date=March 11, 2014 |accessdate=March 11, 2014 |author=Whabam Media}} |"Canuck Fan" |} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{youtube|user=rpwhabam|title=Stacey Roy}} * {{IMDb name|3826248}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Roy, Stacey}} [[Category:Canadian female models]] [[Category:Canadian voice actresses]] [[Category:Cosplayers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Canadian YouTubers]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

{{Infobox person | name = Stefan Kramer Solís | image = Premios Pulsar 2017 - Stefan Kramer - 03.jpg | image_size = 180px | caption = | birth_name = Stefan Kramer Solís | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1982|02|19|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Santiago]], {{flag|Chile}} | occupation = [[Impressionist (entertainment)|Impressionist]], [[actor]], [[tragasable]], [[announcer]] | years_active = 1997 - present | religion = | website = [http://www.stefankramer.cl stefankramer.cl]
[http://www.kramer.tv kramer.tv] | height = | spouse = [[Paloma Soto]] (2005 - present) | partner = | children = María Jesús (b. 2006)

''Best comedian'' | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | siblings = }} '''Stefan Kramer Solís''' (born 19 February 1982 in [[Santiago]]) is a [[Chilean people|Chilean]] [[impressionist (entertainment)|impressionist]], [[actor]], [[comedian]] and [[announcer]]. He comes from a descendant [[Languages of Switzerland#German|German Swiss]] family in [[Araucanía Region]],{{cite web | url=http://www.centroastrologicodechile.com/2013/08/stefan-kramer-el-hombre-de-las-mil_1.html | urltrad= | title=Stefan Kramer, the man of thousand faces and Hermes Mercurio | titletrad= | access-date=March 4, 2016 | subscription= | author= | surname= | author-link= | coauthors= | date=August 1, 2013 | year= | month= | website=[[Centro Astrológico de Chile]] | editor= | editorial= | location= | page= | pages= | language= | doi= | quote=Astrology information of Stefan Kramer.}} and he's married with the singer [[Paloma Soto]]. Kramer is better known in [[Chile]] by copying - with a great accuracy - the voice accents, gestures and expressions of dozens of characters from the Chilean media, like [[TV host]]s, [[singer]]s, [[politician]]s, [[sports player]]s, [[sportscaster]]s and celebrities, generally. == Biography == His first TV appearance was as a contestant on ''¿Cuánto vale el Show?'' on [[Chilevisión]]. Therefore, his debut as an impressionist would be in the [[Televisión Nacional de Chile|TVN]] television show ''Noche de Juegos'', in the comedy section of ''Ponce Candidato'', comedy character performed by [[Julián Elfenbein]]. He has participated in various TV shows like ''Mekano'' ([[Mega (Chilean television channel)|Mega]]), ''Amenaza Real'' ([[Canal 13 (Chile)|Canal 13]]) (performing ''Polimorphicuz'', a man who suffers multiple personalities), ''De Pe a Pá'' ([[Televisión Nacional de Chile|TVN]]), ''REC'' and ''¿Cuánto vale el show?'', both programs from [[Chilevisión]] and hosted by [[Leo Caprile]]. In 2006 Kramer has a great success in ''[[Huaso of Olmué's Festival]]''. He took part successfully in the second night of the [[Viña del Mar International Song Festival|Viña de Mar Festival]] in 2008. In a comedy routine that lasted almost 90 minutes, Kramer impersonated around 33 characters. The [[El monstruo (audience)|audience]] acclaimed and awarded him with two [[Antorcha (award)|Antorchas]] (Oro and Plata - ''English: Gold and Silver Torchs'') and a [[Gaviota (award)|Gaviota de Plata]] (''English: Silver Seagull'').{{cite journal | url = http://www.lun.com/modulos/catalogo/paginas/2008/02/22/LUCSTTL30LU2202.htm | title = Súper Kramer had no limits in the Quinta and he also participated with Vicente Salgado | journal = Las Últimas Noticias | date = February 22, 2008 | access-date = February 22, 2008 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080227234350/http://www.lun.com/modulos/catalogo/paginas/2008/02/22/LUCSTTL30LU2202.htm | archive-date = February 27, 2008 | deadurl = yes | df = }} Many Chilean TV shows have taken advantage of the good rating that produces Kramer's routine and they have repeated it in uncountable occasions, without the comedian receives some money remuneration.{{cite journal | url = http://www.terra.cl/entretencion/index.cfm?id_cat=2471&id_reg=934853 | title = Stefan Kramer angry for repeats of his successful show in Viña Festival on TV | journal = Terra | date = March 10, 2008 | access-date = March 11, 2008|archiveurl=http://www.terra.cl/entretencion/index.cfm?id_cat=2471*|archive-date=November 24, 2015}} One of his television appearances was on July 12, 2009, on the [[Televisión Nacional de Chile|TVN]]'s TV show, ''Animal Nocturno''. In this, he personified the most important presidential candidates, [[Marco Enríquez-Ominami]] as invited to the TV show, [[Eduardo Frei Ruiz-Tagle]] through a supposed live link, and to [[Sebastián Piñera]] though another alleged TV link. He also personified coach [[Marcelo Bielsa]], who was received with praise. In 2010, he co-hosted with [[Felipe Camiroaga]] on the TV show ''Halcón y Camaleón'' on [[Televisión Nacional de Chile|TVN]], with which he achieved great success. During one of the issues of the TV show, Kramer personified [[Marcelo Bielsa]], where he explained the alleged reasons for the impasse that he lived in [[La Moneda]] with the Chilean President [[Sebastián Piñera]]. Likewise, Kramer previously recorded an personification of Piñera, which caused displeasure within the Chilean Government, as it was held just when the ex-President [[Michelle Bachelet]] was invited.[http://www.lanacion.cl/agitado-debate-politico-por-imitacion-de-kramer-a-pinera-en-tvn/noticias/2010-07-07/105735.html Troubled political debate for personification from Kramer to Piñera on TVN] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100710200445/http://www.lanacion.cl/agitado-debate-politico-por-imitacion-de-kramer-a-pinera-en-tvn/noticias/2010-07-07/105735.html |date=2010-07-10 }} ''La Nación''. 7 de julio de 2010. Revised in August 3, 2010 On December 2, 2011, Kramer was again as he had done years earlier at the [[Telethon (Chile)|Telethon Theater]], as the first artist of the beginning of the Teletón that year, personified [[Miguel Piñera|Miguel "Negro" Piñera]], brother of Chilean [[President]] [[Sebastián Piñera]]. As usual, Kramer appeared in the 30th Anniversary of the [[Teletón (Chile)|Chilean Telethon]], but for the first time in the closing of the event in the Estadio Nacional (National Stadium), where he personified politicians and the Entertainer of the solidary crusade, [[Mario Kreutzberger]], the worldwide famous "[[Don Francisco (television host)|Don Francisco]]", the same of "[[Sábado Gigante]]". Kramer was recognized by ''Don Francisco'' himself and had a great time in the great show. He repeated presentations on the closures of the 2014, 2015 and 2016 versions. On May 26, 2016, Kramer became the announcer of his own first TV show, called ''Kamaleón, el show de Kramer'', and broadcast by [[Televisión Nacional de Chile|TVN]]. Also, he was invited by [[Chilevision]] in the new version of the TV show ''El Club de la Comedia''. == Filmography == {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #FFFFFF; border: 1px #0ABAB5 solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 95%;" |- bgcolor="#0ABAB5" align="center" ! width="70" rowspan="1"| Year ! width="140" rowspan="1"| Film ! width="140" rowspan="1"| Characters ! Country !! Reporter !! and ''Peter Veneno'') || |- | {{flag|Chile}} || [[Fernando Farías]]|| |} {| class=wikitable width=400px |colspan=3| {{center|'''Others'''}} |- ! Country !! Personified !! Nickname |- |{{flag|Chile}} || [[Leonardo Farkas]] || Leonardo Parkas / The pianist |- |{{flag|Chile}} || [[Roberto Dueñas]] || Teddy Dueñas |- |{{flag|Chile}} || [[Jordi Castell]] || Flordi Pastel |- |{{flag|Chile}} || Arturo Longton || Arturo Pichi / The Producer / Arturo London |- |{{flag|Chile}} || Rafael Garay || |} {{Columns-end}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb name|1842858|Stefan Kramer}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kramer, Stefan}} [[Category:1982 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Santiago]] [[Category:Chilean male television actors]] [[Category:Chilean male film actors]] [[Category:Impressionists (entertainers)]] [[Category:Chilean people of Swiss-German descent]]
