revision.text:
{{For|other people with this name}} {{Infobox snooker player | name = Steve Davis | honorific_suffix = [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] | image = Steve Davis at German Masters Snooker Final (DerHexer) 2012-02-05 16.jpg | caption = Davis at the [[2012 German Masters]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1957|8|22|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Plumstead]], [[London]], [[England]] | Sport country = {{ENG}} | Nickname = {{Unbulleted list|The Nugget|Interesting|Ginger Magician|Romford Robot}} The Master Cueman | Professional = 1978–2016 | High ranking = {{nowrap|[[List of world number one snooker players|1]] {{smaller|([[Snooker world rankings 1983/1984|1983/84]]–[[Snooker world rankings 1989/1990|1989/90]])}}}} | Prize money = [[Pound sterling|£]]5.5 million{{cite web|url=http://www.worldsnooker.com/steve-davis-retires-from-snooker/|title=Steve Davis Retires From Snooker – World Snooker|date=17 April 2016|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/snooker/36034458|title=Steve Davis: Snooker great retires after 38-year career|first=Shamoon |last=Hafez| publisher=[[BBC]]|date=17 April 2016|accessdate=22 April 2016 }} | High break = '''[[Maximum break|147]]''':
1982 Classic | Century break =355 | Ranking wins = 28 | Other wins = 55 | World champ = {{Hlist | [[1981 World Snooker Championship|1981]] | [[1983 World Snooker Championship|1983]] | [[1984 World Snooker Championship|1984]] | [[1987 World Snooker Championship|1987]] | [[1988 World Snooker Championship|1988]] | [[1989 World Snooker Championship|1989]]}} }} '''Steve Davis''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|OBE}} (born 22 August 1957){{cite web|url=http://www.thesportsjudge.co.uk/nextsnoo.htm |title=Snooker Questions Page 2 |accessdate=7 December 2010 |year=2002 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4HwxauF?url=http://www.thesportsjudge.co.uk/nextsnoo.htm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} is an English retired professional [[snooker]] player from [[Plumstead]], [[London]], who is generally viewed as one of the sport's greatest players as well as one of its most iconic figures. After turning professional in 1978, he dominated snooker during the 1980s, reaching eight [[World Snooker Championship|World Championship]] finals in nine years, winning six world titles, and holding the [[List of world number one snooker players|world number one]] ranking for seven consecutive seasons. He is remembered particularly for contesting the [[1985 World Snooker Championship final|1985 World Championship final]] with [[Dennis Taylor]], the black-ball conclusion of which still holds the record for the largest after-midnight television audience in British history, with 18.5 million viewers. His other achievements include winning the [[Masters (snooker)|Masters]] three times, the [[UK Championship (snooker)|UK Championship]] a joint record six times, the [[World Doubles Championship]] four times (with [[Tony Meo]]), and becoming the first player to complete snooker's [[Triple Crown (snooker)|Triple Crown]] by winning the UK Championship, Masters, and World Championship in the same season ([[Snooker season 1987/1988|1987/1988]]). He won a total of [[List of snooker players by number of ranking titles|28 ranking titles]], earned over £5.5 million in prize money, and compiled over 300 competitive century breaks, including the first officially recognised [[maximum break]] in professional competition, at the [[1982 Classic (snooker)|Classic]] in 1982. He was named the BBC's [[BBC_Sports_Personality_of_the_Year_Award|Sports Personality of the Year]] in 1988. Davis won his last world title in [[1989 World Snooker Championship|1989]], aged 31, and captured his last major title when he won the [[1997 Masters (snooker)|1997 Masters]] at age 39, but he continued to play snooker at a high level into his 50s. He reached the final of the [[2005 UK Championship (snooker)|2005 UK Championship]] at age 48 and was still ranked inside the top 16 when he turned 50 during the [[Snooker season 2007/2008|2007/2008]] season. In 2010, aged 52, he reached the televised stages of the [[2010 World Snooker Championship|World Championship]] for a record 30th time, also becoming the only player to compete in the tournament over five different decades, since his debut in [[1979 World Snooker Championship|1979]]. That was Davis's final competitive appearance at the Crucible. He slipped down the [[snooker world rankings|world rankings]] thereafter, dropping out of the top 64 and off the main tour in 2014. On 17 April 2016, aged 58, he announced his retirement after 38 seasons as a professional. He remains active as a television analyst and commentator for the [[BBC Television|BBC]]'s snooker coverage. Outside snooker, Davis has competed in [[Pool (cue sports)|pool]] tournaments, notably playing on [[Team Europe]] at the [[Mosconi Cup]] between [[1994 Mosconi Cup|1994]] and [[2004 Mosconi Cup|2004]], helping the team win the event in [[1995 Mosconi Cup|1995]] and [[2002 Mosconi Cup|2002]]. He is a noted [[poker]] player, having reached the final stages of several televised tournaments, and he has also developed a career as a radio and club DJ, often in collaboration with [[Kavus Torabi]], with whom he appeared at the [[Glastonbury Festival]] in 2016.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-36382248 |title=Snooker player Steve Davis to DJ at Glastonbury festival |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=19 October 2018 | date=25 May 2016}} A keen amateur [[chess]] player, he co-authored a chess book with grandmaster [[David Norwood]] and is a former president of the [[English Chess Federation|British Chess Federation]]. He has published several books on snooker, including three autobiographies, one technical book and one comedy book called ''How to Be Really Interesting''. He has appeared on a number of popular British TV shows, including [[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! (UK TV series)|''I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!'']] in 2013. He was made an MBE in the [[1988 Birthday Honours]] and an OBE in the [[2000 New Year Honours]]. ==Career== ===Early career=== Davis was introduced to snooker by his father Bill, a keen player, who took him to play at his local [[working men's club]] at the age of 12,{{cite news|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard-sport/interviews/article-23942836-steve-davis-if-ronnie-osullivan-was-a-greyhound-youd-put-him-down.do |title=Steve Davis: If Ronnie O'Sullivan was a greyhound, you'd put him down |first=Mihir |last=Bose |accessdate=12 May 2011 |work=London Evening Standard |location=UK |date=19 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGFD?url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard-sport/interviews/article-23942836-steve-davis-if-ronnie-osullivan-was-a-greyhound-youd-put-him-down.do |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and gave him [[Joe Davis]]' instructional book ''How I Play Snooker''.{{cite web|last=Kane|first=Desmond|title=The numbers add up for the golden Nugget|url=http://www.thenational.ae/sport/the-numbers-add-up-for-the-golden-nugget|publisher=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]|accessdate=4 January 2012}} They studied the book and built Steve Davis's own technique on it in the 1970s.{{cite web|last=Smith|first=David|title=Collecting on a Budget|url=http://www.cuesnviews.co.uk/Books/snookercollectbudget.htm|publisher=Cues n Views|accessdate=4 January 2012}} He started playing at the Lucania Snooker Club in [[Romford]], where at the age of 18 the manager of the club brought his talent to the attention of [[Barry Hearn]], chairman of the Lucania chain of [[Billiard hall|snooker hall]]s.{{cite news|last=Yates |first=Phil |title=Chairman wants players to become Barry Hearn's earners |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/more_sport/article7100158.ece |work=The Times |location=UK |accessdate=10 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGFW?url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/more_sport/article7100158.ece |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |date=17 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Hearn became Davis' friend and manager.{{cite web|title=Board of Directors |url=http://www.matchroomsport.com/aboutus/directors.htm |publisher=Matchroom Sport |accessdate=10 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yaKTE8jS?url=http://www.matchroomsport.com/aboutus/directors.htm |archivedate=10 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Paid £25 a match by Hearn, Davis toured the country, taking part in challenge matches against established professionals such as [[Ray Reardon]], [[John Spencer (snooker player)|John Spencer]] and [[Alex Higgins]]. Around this time he was given the nickname "Nugget" because, according to Hearn, "you could put your case of money on him and you knew you were going to get paid."{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/othersports/article-1237866/Can-Flash-Barry-turn-nation-snooker-loopy-Hearn-returns-love.html |title=Can Flash Barry turn the nation snooker loopy all over again? |first=Ivan |last=Speck |accessdate=10 May 2011 |work=Daily Mail |location=UK |date=23 December 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGFN?url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/othersports/article-1237866/Can-Flash-Barry-turn-nation-snooker-loopy-Hearn-returns-love.html |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis won the English Under-19 Billiards Championship in 1976. One of his last wins as an amateur was against another future professional [[Tony Meo]] in the final of the [[Spring Open|Pontin's Spring Open]] of 1978.{{cite web|url=http://matchroomsport.com/staticPage.asp?strPageName=Steve_Davis|title=Steve Davis profile|accessdate=25 February 2008|publisher=matchroomsport.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080218062413/http://matchroomsport.com/staticPage.asp?strPageName=Steve_Davis|archivedate=18 February 2008}} A year later he successfully defended his title, this time defeating another of his future rivals, [[Jimmy White]], 7–4 in the final.{{cite web|title=Pontin's Roll of Honour|url=http://www.globalsnookercentre.co.uk/files/Pontins/pontins-roll-of-honour.htm|publisher=Global Snooker Centre|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081223045648/http://www.globalsnookercentre.co.uk/files/Pontins/pontins-roll-of-honour.htm|archivedate=23 December 2008}} Davis turned professional on 17 September 1978Snooker Scene, September 1978, page 14–15 and made his professional television debut on [[Pot Black]], where he played against [[Fred Davis (snooker player)|Fred Davis]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sport/79178.stm |title=Tributes to cue king Fred Davis |date=16 April 1998 |accessdate=25 February 2008 |publisher=BBC News |location=London, UK |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4HwxavA?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/sport/79178.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He made his World Championship debut in [[1979 World Snooker Championship|1979]],{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2004/01/27/sosnoo27.xml |title=Snooker: Davis happy to return to elite |first=John |last=Dee |accessdate=25 February 2008 |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK |date=26 January 2004 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4HwxavO?url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/snooker/2371978/Snooker-Davis-happy-to-return-to-elite.html |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} losing 11–13 to [[Dennis Taylor]] in the first round.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/snooker-hicks-heaps-misery-on-erring-davis-1616285.html |title=Snooker: Hicks heaps misery on erring Davis |work=The Independent |location=UK |accessdate=25 February 2008 |date=19 April 1995 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxavc?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/snooker-hicks-heaps-misery-on-erring-davis-1616285.html |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ===Dominance of snooker=== Davis came to public prominence after his performance at the [[1980 World Snooker Championship|1980 World Championship]], where he reached the quarter-finals, defeating defending champion [[Terry Griffiths]] en route,{{cite web|url=http://www.terrygriffithsmatchroom.co.uk/terry_profile.html |title=A Profile for Terry Griffiths |publisher=Terry Griffiths Matchroom |accessdate=25 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxavr?url=http://www.terrygriffithssnooker.com/profiles/terry-griffiths-obe.aspx |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} before losing to Alex Higgins.{{cite web|title=1980 World Championships Results |url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=32 |publisher=Snooker Database |accessdate=5 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGFf?url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=32 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis won his first major title in the same year – the [[1980 UK Championship (snooker)|UK Championship]] – during which he beat Griffiths 9–0 in the semi-finals and Higgins 16–6 in the final.{{cite web|title=1980 UK Championship Results |url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=125 |publisher=Snooker Database |accessdate=5 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGFo?url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=125 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite news|last=Dee |first=John |title=Davis happy to return to elite |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/snooker/2371978/Snooker-Davis-happy-to-return-to-elite.html |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=24 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGFw?url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/snooker/2371978/Snooker-Davis-happy-to-return-to-elite.html |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |location=London |date=27 January 2004 |deadurl=yes |df= }} This began an 18-month period of dominance. He won the [[1980 Classic (1980/1981)|Classic]] and then the [[1981 International Masters|International Masters]] and [[1981 English Professional Championship|English Professional]] titles in 1981, and became the bookmakers' favourite to win the [[1981 World Snooker Championship|1981 World Championship]], despite being seeded only 15.{{cite web|url=http://betting.betfair.com/betting/the-betfair-contrarian-why-the-world-championship-wont-150408.html |title=The Betfair Contrarian: Why the World Championship won't have a new champion |accessdate=10 September 2008 |publisher=The Betfair Contrarian |year=2008 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4HwxawJ?url=http://betting.betfair.com/betting/the-betfair-contrarian-why-the-world-championship-wont-150408.html |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis reached the final by defeating [[Jimmy White]] in the first round, Higgins in the second round, Griffiths in the quarter-finals and defending champion [[Cliff Thorburn]] in the semi-final.{{cite web|title=1981 World Championships Results |url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=31 |publisher=Snooker Database |accessdate=5 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGG5?url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=31 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis's 18–12 victory over [[Doug Mountjoy]] in the final confirmed bookmakers' early predictions, and in celebration his manager [[Barry Hearn]] charged across the arena to lift him up in the air.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921233.stm |title=1981: Davis begins his reign |accessdate=25 February 2008 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 April 2002 |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4HwxawY?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921233.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He would go on to reach seven out of the next eight world finals.{{cite web|title=World Championships Winners |url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/TournamentDetails.aspx?TournKey=1 |publisher=Snooker Database |accessdate=24 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGGE?url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/TournamentDetails.aspx?TournKey=1 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Peculiarly, Davis's first four world finals were each against a player of a different nationality, something that had not occurred before and has not since. He followed up his world title win with a 9–0 final victory over Dennis Taylor in the [[1981 International Open|International Open]] and then retained the [[1981 UK Championship (snooker)|UK Championship]] with a 9–0 whitewash over White in the semi-finals and a 16–3 win over Griffiths in the final.{{cite web|title=1981 UK Championship Results |url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=124 |publisher=Snooker Database |accessdate=5 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGGN?url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=124 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} This began a period of six months in which Davis and Griffiths contested almost all the major tournament finals. During this run, in January 1982, Davis made snooker history when he compiled the first televised [[maximum break]] at the [[1982 Classic (snooker)|Classic]] at the Queen Elizabeth Hall, [[Oldham]], against [[John Spencer (snooker player)|John Spencer]].{{cite news|last=Wilson |first=Jeremy |title=Stephen Hendry progress in balance despite 147 maximum break |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/snooker/5238033/Stephen-Hendry-progress-in-balance-despite-147-maximum-break.html |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK |accessdate=14 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGGV?url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/snooker/5238033/Stephen-Hendry-progress-in-balance-despite-147-maximum-break.html |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |date=28 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis won a [[Lada]] car for the achievement.{{cite web| url = http://www.sportinglife.com/snooker/news/article/663/9062843/snookers-historic-maximum-breaks| title = Snooker's historic maximum breaks | accessdate = 14 February 2014| date = 7 December 2013| publisher=SportingLife}} Davis subsequently lost 9–8 in the final against Griffiths.{{cite web|url=http://www.oldhamadvertiser.co.uk/news/s/532301_piece_of_snooker_history_ended_up_at_rugby_club |title=Piece of snooker history ended up at rugby club |accessdate=25 February 2008 |date=5 September 2007 |publisher=Oldham Advertiser |first=Carl |last=Marsden |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxax0?url=http://menmedia.co.uk/oldhamadvertiser/news/s/532301_piece_of_snooker_history_ended_up_at_rugby_club |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In 1982, Davis won his first [[1982 Masters (snooker)|Masters]] title, defeating Griffiths 9–6 in the final.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/7174955.stm |title=Masters roll of honour |accessdate=25 February 2008 |date=7 January 2008 |publisher=BBC Sport |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4HwxaxE?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/7174955.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis's 18-month period of dominance ended at the [[1982 World Snooker Championship|1982 World Championship]], when he succumbed to the so-called "[[Crucible curse]]", losing 10–1 against [[Tony Knowles (snooker player)|Tony Knowles]] in the first round. Later that year, he could not win a third consecutive [[1982 UK Championship (snooker)|UK title]] as he lost in the quarter-finals against Griffiths.{{cite web|title=1982 UK Championship Results |url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=123 |publisher=Snooker Database |accessdate=5 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGGj?url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=123 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Following those two setbacks, he won the [[World Doubles Championship]] title with partner [[Tony Meo]]. In [[1983 World Snooker Championship|1983]] Davis regained the world title with a session to spare in the final, defeating an overwhelmed Thorburn 18–6; Thorburn had seen his previous three matches go to a deciding frame and a late finish.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921259.stm |title=1983: Davis's title but Thorburn's 147 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=25 February 2008 |date=12 April 2002 |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4HwxaxS?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921259.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis lost 16–15 to Higgins in the [[1983 UK Championship (snooker)|1983 UK Championship]] final, despite having led 7–0 at one point of the match.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/in_depth/2000/uk_championship_snooker/1044073.stm |title=Back from the dead |accessdate=25 February 2008 |date=28 November 2000 |publisher=BBC Sport |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxaxg?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/in_depth/2000/uk_championship_snooker/1044073.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In [[1984 World Snooker Championship|1984]], he became the first player to retain his world title at the [[Crucible Theatre]] by beating Jimmy White 18–16 in the final.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921273.stm |title=1984: Davis outshines White |accessdate=25 February 2008 |date=12 April 2002 |publisher=BBC Sport |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxaxv?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921273.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He also regained the UK title in [[1984 UK Championship (snooker)|1984]] defeating Higgins 16–8.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/2504783.stm |title=UK Championship history |date=28 November 2002 |accessdate=25 February 2008 |publisher=BBC Sport |location=London |first=Mark |last=Ashenden |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxaw5?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/2504783.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ===Black-ball final=== {{main article|1985 World Snooker Championship final}} At the [[1985 World Snooker Championship|1985 World Championship]], Davis dropped only 23 frames en route to the [[1985 World Snooker Championship final|final]], where his opponent was Dennis Taylor. He looked set for a third consecutive world title after an opening session of near-faultless snooker gave him a 7–0 lead, which he extended to 8–0 in the evening session, but Taylor recovered to trail only 7–9. From 11–11 the pair traded frames before Davis forged ahead to lead 17–15. Taylor won the next two frames to level the match at 17–17 and force a deciding frame. With the scores close, Taylor potted the final colours to leave the black as the winner-takes-all ball. After a series of safety shots and attempts at potting it, Davis over-cut the black, leaving Taylor with a reasonably straightforward pot to secure the championship. The nailbiting finale drew 18.5 million viewers, a record post-midnight audience on British television and a record audience for [[BBC Two]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921279.stm |title=1985: The black ball final |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=25 February 2008 |date=14 April 2002 |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxay9?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921279.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The {{Cuegloss|Black ball|black-ball}} finish was voted the [[100 Greatest/100 Worst|ninth greatest sporting moment of all time]] in a 2002 [[Channel 4]] poll, and the conclusion has been replayed on television countlesss times, showing Davis's disbelief and Taylor's triumphant pointing finger. {{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/entertainment/tv/microsites/G/greatest/sporting_moments/results.html |title=100 Greatest Sporting Moments – Results |publisher=Channel4.com |accessdate=16 April 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4HwxayN?url=http://www.channel4.com/entertainment/tv/microsites/G/greatest/sporting_moments/results.html |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ===1985–1989=== Davis and Taylor met again in the final of the [[1985 Grand Prix (snooker)|1985 Grand Prix]], but this time Davis won in the deciding frame. At 10 hours 21 minutes, it remains the longest one-day final in snooker history.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/snooker/3004553/Snooker-Ebdon-quick-to-sit-on-fence.html |title=Ebdon quick to sit on fence |publisher=[[The Sunday Telegraph]] |accessdate=29 August 2009 |date=1 May 2001 |location=London |first=John |last=Dee |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxayb?url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/snooker/3004553/Snooker-Ebdon-quick-to-sit-on-fence.html |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In the [[1985 UK Championship (snooker)|1985 UK Championship]] final Davis trailed 8–13 against [[Willie Thorne]], who missed a blue off the spot which would have given him a 14–8 lead. Davis won the frame and then seven of the next eight to win 16–14.{{cite web|last=Hendon |first=Dave |title=Meet The Misses |url=http://snookerscene.blogspot.com/2008/04/meet-misses.html |publisher=Snooker Scene Blog |accessdate=5 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGGt?url=http://snookerscene.blogspot.com/2008/04/meet-misses.html |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} At the [[1986 World Snooker Championship|1986 World Championship]], Davis defeated White 13–5 in the quarter-finals and Thorburn 16–12 in the semi-finals,{{cite web|title=1986 World Championships Results |url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=26 |publisher=Snooker Database |accessdate=5 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGH3?url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=26 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis's opponent in the final was [[Joe Johnson (snooker player)|Joe Johnson]], who had started the tournament as a 150–1 outsider. Davis lost the match 12–18.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921288.stm |title=1986: Johnson stuns snooker world |accessdate=25 February 2008 |date=14 April 2002 |publisher=BBC Sport |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxayq?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921288.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The result did not affect his position at the top of the world rankings, as he had won the UK Championship, the Grand Prix and the [[1986 British Open|British Open]] in the [[Snooker season 1985/1986|1985/1986 season]]. At the end of 1986 he beat [[Neal Foulds]] 16–7 to retain the [[1986 UK Championship (snooker)|UK Championship]]. Davis started 1987 by winning the [[1987 Classic (snooker)|Classic]], beating defending champion Jimmy White 13–12.{{cite web|title=Classic |url=http://www.snookerscene.co.uk/page.php?id=52 |publisher=Snooker Scene |accessdate=24 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGHB?url=http://www.snookerscene.co.uk/page.php?id=52 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} At the [[1987 World Snooker Championship|World Championship]], he defeated Griffiths 13–5 in the quarter-final, and White 16–11 in the semi-final.{{cite web|title=1987 World Championships Results |url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=25 |publisher=Snooker Database |accessdate=5 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGHK?url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=25 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In the final he again met Johnson, and established a 14–10 lead after three sessions. Johnson reduced Davis' lead to 14–13, but Davis won four of the next five frames to win the match 18–14 and regain the title.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921298.stm |title=1987: Davis's revenge on Johnson |accessdate=25 February 2008 |date=14 April 2002 |publisher=BBC Sport |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxaz4?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921298.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In beating Johnson he became the first player to win the [[Triple Crown (snooker)|UK Championship, Masters and World Championship]] in the same year.{{cite web|last=McHenry |first=Bruce |title=Williams clinches triple crown |url=http://sport.scotsman.com/snooker/Williams-clinches-triple-crown.2424796.jp |work=The Scotsman |location=UK |accessdate=5 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGHT?url=http://sport.scotsman.com/snooker/Williams-clinches-triple-crown.2424796.jp |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In December he retained his [[1987 UK Championship (snooker)|UK title]] with a 16–14 final win against White. In 1988, he retained the [[1988 Classic (snooker)|Classic]], claimed his second [[1988 Masters (snooker)|Masters]] title with a 9–0 final whitewash of [[Mike Hallett]] (the only final whitewash in the event's history), won the [[World Cup (snooker)|World Cup]] with England and won his fourth [[1988 Irish Masters|Irish Masters]] title. In the [[1988 World Snooker Championship|World Championship]] Davis defeated Hallett 13–1, [[Tony Drago]] 13–4 and Thorburn 16–8 en route to the final, where he met Griffiths. Davis established a 5–2 lead after the first session, but Griffiths levelled at 8–8 after the second. On the second day of the match Davis took ten out of thirteen frames to win 18–11 and claim his fifth world title.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921317.stm |title=1988: Davis does it again |accessdate=25 February 2008 |date=14 April 2002 |publisher=BBC Sport |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4HwxazL?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921317.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis won the first ranking event of the [[Snooker world rankings 1988/1989|1988/1989 season]] with a 12–6 win over White in the [[1988 International Open|International Open]]; in the same match, he became the first player to make three consecutive century breaks in a major tournament.{{cite book | last=Everton|first= Clive| title=The Embassy Book of World Snooker| publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing| year=1993| isbn=978-0-7475-1610-1 | page=129}} In October, Davis won the [[1988 Grand Prix (snooker)|Grand Prix]], beating Alex Higgins 10–6 in the final to hold the World, UK, Masters, Grand Prix, Classic and Irish Masters titles simultaneously. However, his four-year unbeaten run at the [[1988 UK Championship (snooker)|UK Championship]] came to an end in December with a 3–9 semi-final loss to Hendry.{{cite web|title=1988 UK Championship Results |url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=117 |publisher=Snooker Database |accessdate=5 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGHc?url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=117 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He did not win another major title that season until the [[1989 World Snooker Championship|1989 World Championship]], where he beat Hendry 16–9 in the semi-finals before going on to complete the heaviest victory in a world final of the modern era with an 18–3 win over [[John Parrott]], his last world championship.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921334.stm |title=1989: Davis makes it six |accessdate=25 February 2008 |date=14 April 2002 |publisher=BBC Sport |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxaza?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921334.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} This match in particular was regarded as one of his greatest performances, and was cited in the ''Guinness Book of Snooker'' as "The greatest display of potting, break building and safety play ever seen" with the further observation "no-one could have lived with Davis the way he played at the Crucible in 1989".''Guinness Book of Snooker'' match report In October he retained the [[1989 Grand Prix (snooker)|Grand Prix]], beating [[Dean Reynolds]] 10–0 in the final, the first [[Whitewash (sport)|whitewash]] in a ranking event final.{{cite web|title=Maguire makes White cross in Malta as he dominates final |url=http://sport.scotsman.com/snooker/Maguire-makes-White-cross-in.2509585.jp |work=The Scotsman |location=UK |accessdate=15 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ynfYizhE?url=http://sport.scotsman.com/snooker/Maguire-makes-White-cross-in.2509585.jp |archivedate=19 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} By the end of the 1980s, Davis was snooker's first millionaire.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsnookercentre.co.uk/files/Players/Global_Europe/Global_England/p_profile006.htm|title=Player Profile: Steve Davis|accessdate=11 April 2007|publisher=The Global Snooker Centre|year=2004|first=Chris |last=Turner|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090119142854/http://www.globalsnookercentre.co.uk/files/Players/Global_Europe/Global_England/p_profile006.htm|archivedate=19 January 2009}} ===1990–2005=== After demolishing John Parrott in the 1989 World Final, it seemed obvious that the new decade would see Davis and rising star Stephen Hendry battling for supremacy. However, the prospect of Davis v Hendry World finals never materialised. As with Ray Reardon and his successor Steve Davis, there was to be no World Final showdown between once and future kings. Instead, Hendry became the new king, with Jimmy White as his main rival. In the [[1990 World Snooker Championship|1990 World Championship]], Davis was denied an eighth consecutive appearance in the final by Jimmy White, who won their semi-final 16–14.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921463.stm |title=1990 – Cue Stephen Hendry |accessdate=25 February 2008 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 April 2002 |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxazo?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921463.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis was replaced as world number one by [[Stephen Hendry]] at the end of the [[Snooker world rankings 1989/1990|1989/90 season]]. He was ranked number 2 for the [[Snooker world rankings 1990/1991|1990/1991]], [[Snooker world rankings 1991/1992|1991/1992]], [[Snooker world rankings 1994/1995|1994/1995]] and [[Snooker world rankings 1995/1996|1995/1996]] seasons.{{cite web|title=Ranking History|url=http://www.snooker.org/rnk/history.asp?sort=1990/1991&order=asc|publisher=Snooker.org|accessdate=5 May 2011}} He reached the semi-finals of the World Championships in [[1991 World Snooker Championship|1991]] and [[1994 World Snooker Championship|1994]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921478.stm |title=1991: Parrott finally gets reward |accessdate=25 February 2008 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 April 2002 |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb02?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921478.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921526.stm |title=1994: Hendry beats White in classic |accessdate=25 February 2008 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 April 2002 |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb0G?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/world_champs_2002/1921526.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He also won the [[Irish Masters]] in [[1990 Irish Masters|1990]], [[1991 Irish Masters|1991]], [[1993 Irish Masters|1993]] and [[1994 Irish Masters|1994]], the [[1992 Classic (snooker)|Classic]] and the [[1992 Asian Open|Asian Open]] in 1992, the [[1993 European Open (1992/1993)|European Open]] in 1993, and consecutive [[Welsh Open (snooker)|Welsh Open]] titles in [[1994 Welsh Open (snooker)|1994]] and [[1995 Welsh Open (snooker)|1995]]. His successful defence of his Welsh Open title in 1995 was to be his last [[Snooker world rankings|ranking]] title.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/4174705.stm |title=Welsh Open: Previous winners |accessdate=25 February 2008 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 January 2005 |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb0U?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/4174705.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis's last victory in a major tournament came at the [[1997 Masters (snooker)|1997 Masters]]. Trailing his opponent [[Ronnie O'Sullivan]] 4–8 in the final, he won the next six frames to secure a 10–8 win. During this period, Davis had been clearly struggling with his game, displaying the classic symptoms of a confidence problem in his technique. His cue action, which was once regarded by his peers as the best in the game,Rex Williams commentary on the Fiat Snooker Pool Challenge 1987 was now in tatters, with Davis seemingly unable to settle on a feathering up drill, going from slow and deliberate in some matches to randomly speeding up in others. He also soon brought comments from commentators with regard to his overreliance on safety play, and over thinking his shots. It was clear that Davis had a serious problem and ultimately one he would never recover from. 1989 proved to be his last appearance in a World Final, unthinkable at the time. After a season which saw Davis reach only one ranking event quarter-final, Davis dropped out of the top 16 for the [[Snooker world rankings 2000/2001|2000/2001 season]], and failed to qualify for the World Championship for the next two years.{{cite web|title=2001 World Championships Results |url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=11 |publisher=Snooker Database |accessdate=5 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGHk?url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=11 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web|title=2002 World Championships Results |url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=10 |publisher=Snooker Database |accessdate=5 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGHt?url=http://www.snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=10 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} After failing to qualify for the World Snooker Championship for the first time in his professional career in [[2001 World Snooker Championship|2001]], Davis felt that retiring would be the easy thing to do, but as he still liked the challenge of snooker, he continued playing,{{cite news|last=Everton|first=Clive|title=Snooker now a young man's game|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/1202164.stm|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=5 July 2011|date=5 March 2001}} and regained his place in the top 16 for the [[Snooker world rankings 2003/2004|2003/2004 season]]. He was runner-up in the [[2004 Welsh Open (snooker)|2004 Welsh Open]] to O'Sullivan, losing 8–9 after having led 8–5.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/3428317.stm |title=O'Sullivan denies Davis |accessdate=5 May 2011 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 January 2004 |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb0U?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/4174705.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{failed verification|date=December 2013|reason=Archived article is not the same as the original article}} In [[2005 World Snooker Championship|2005]] he reached the quarter finals of the World Championship, losing to eventual winner [[Shaun Murphy (snooker player)|Shaun Murphy]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/4485425.stm |title=Murphy beats Davis to reach semis |accessdate=25 February 2008 |date=27 April 2005 |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Saj |last=Chowdhury |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb0w?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/4485425.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ===2005–2010=== At the [[2005 UK Championship (snooker)|2005 UK Championship]], held in [[York]], Davis reached his 100th major career final, and made his first appearance in the UK final since 1990. En route he beat defending champion [[Stephen Maguire]] 9–8, a win which included a 145 break; and then [[Stephen Hendry]] 9–6 in the semi-finals to reach the final, where he lost 6–10 against [[Ding Junhui]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sportinglife.com/snooker/worldchampionships2007/profiles/story_get.dor?STORY_NAME=snooker/07/01/08/manual_154221.html |title=World Snooker – Steve Davis |publisher=Sporting Life |accessdate=26 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb1A?url=http://www.sportinglife.com/snooker/worldchampionships2007/profiles/story_get.dor?STORY_NAME=snooker%2F07%2F01%2F08%2Fmanual_154221.html |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web|title=2005 UK Championship|url=http://www.globalsnookercentre.co.uk/files/Results/res05_6/05UK.htm|publisher=Global Snooker Centrwe|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060428011423/http://www.globalsnookercentre.co.uk/files/Results/res05_6/05UK.htm|archivedate=28 April 2006}} Before the [[2006 World Snooker Championship|World Championships]] Davis brushed off suggestions of retirement,{{cite news|title=Davis brushes off retirement talk|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/4885086.stm|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=5 July 2011|date=12 April 2006}} and he reached the second round, where he lost to Murphy.{{cite web|title=888.com 2006 World Championship|url=http://www.globalsnookercentre.co.uk/files/Results/2005-6/06world.htm|publisher=Global Snooker Centre|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070701190817/http://www.globalsnookercentre.co.uk/files/Results/2005-6/06world.htm|archivedate=1 July 2007}} Davis's performances through the [[Snooker season 2006/2007|2006/2007]] season, including reaching the [[2006 UK Championship (snooker)|UK Championship]] quarter-finals and the [[2007 Welsh Open (snooker)|Welsh Open]] semi-finals, ensured he was still a top 16 player at the age of 50.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/othersports/article-452872/Davis-rolls-years.html |title=Davis Rolls Back The Years |work=The Daily Mail |location=UK |accessdate=14 April 2011 |date=5 May 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xw7uu8xl?url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/othersports/article-452872/Davis-rolls-years.html |archivedate=14 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} [[File:Steve Davis at Sports Club Turku, Finland.jpg|thumb|right|Steve Davis during a match against Ville Pasanen in 2008]] He dropped out of the top sixteen a year later, but showed form in the [[Snooker season 2008/2009|2008/2009 season]] by reaching the quarter-finals of both the [[2008 Shanghai Masters|Shanghai Masters]] and [[2008 Grand Prix (snooker)|Grand Prix]], the first time he had reached consecutive ranking event quarter-finals since 1996.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldsnooker.com/royal_london_watches_grand_prix_news-8321.htm?tid=113 |title=Top Trump |publisher=Worldsnooker.com |date=18 September 2009 |accessdate=31 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb1d?url=http://www.worldsnooker.com/royal_london_watches_grand_prix_news-8321.htm?tid=113 |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} At the [[2009 World Snooker Championship|World Championship]] Davis lost in the first round 2–10 against Neil Robertson. After the match he again dismissed talk of his retirement.{{cite news|last=Speck|first=Ivan|title=Davis dismisses talk of retirement after being crushed at The Crucible|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/othersports/article-1172710/Davis-dismisses-talk-retirement-crushed-The-Crucible.html|publisher=[[Mail Online]]|accessdate=5 July 2011|location=London|date=22 April 2009}} In the first two tournaments of the [[Snooker season 2009/2010|2009/2010 season]] Davis failed to qualify for the televised stages as he lost 4–5 against [[Matthew Selt]] in the [[2009 Shanghai Masters|Shanghai Masters]] and 0–5 against [[Mark Davis (snooker player)|Mark Davis]] in the [[2009 Grand Prix (snooker)|Grand Prix]].{{cite web|url=http://www.global-snooker.com/Shanghai-Masters-2009-draw-and-results.asp |title=2009 Shanghai Masters Qualifying |publisher=Global Snooker |accessdate=17 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGIA?url=http://www.global-snooker.com/Grand-Prix-Snooker-2009-Schedule.asp |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.global-snooker.com/Grand-Prix-Snooker-2009-Schedule.asp |title=2009 Grand Prix Qualifying |publisher=Global Snooker |accessdate=17 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGI2?url=http://www.global-snooker.com/Shanghai-Masters-2009-draw-and-results.asp |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In the next tournament, the [[2009 UK Championship (snooker)|UK Championship]], he defeated [[Michael Judge]] 9–7 to set up a first round match against Hendry,{{cite news|title=Steve Davis books UK clash with Stephen Hendry |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/8387638.stm |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |accessdate=14 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ygFrezJR?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/8387638.stm |archivedate=14 May 2011 |date=30 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} which he lost 6–9.{{cite news|title=Stephen Hendry overcomes Steve Davis in UK Championship but finds the game is 'torture' |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/snooker/6746520/Stephen-Hendry-overcomes-Steve-Davis-in-UK-Championship-but-finds-the-game-is-torture.html |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK |accessdate=14 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ygGIn78B?url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/snooker/6746520/Stephen-Hendry-overcomes-Steve-Davis-in-UK-Championship-but-finds-the-game-is-torture.html |archivedate=14 May 2011 |date=6 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis started 2010 by failing to qualify for the [[2010 Welsh Open (snooker)|Welsh Open]] and the [[2010 China Open (snooker)|China Open]], losing 2–5 against [[Dominic Dale]] and 3–5 against [[Mike Dunn (snooker player)|Mike Dunn]] respectively in the final qualifying round.{{cite web|last=Kendal-Williams|first=Simon|title=Williams andcostill chasingthat elusive pot of Welsh gold; snooker's finest head for Wales: But will there be a home winner?|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Williams+andcostill+chasingthat+elusive+pot+of+Welsh+gold%3B+SNOOKER%27S...-a0217301835|publisher=[[Western Mail (Wales)|Wales on Sunday]] on [[TheFreeDictionary.com#TheFreeLibrary.com|TheFreeLibrary.com]]|accessdate=14 May 2011}}{{cite news|last=Hartley |first=John |title=Mike Dunn's world bid |url=http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/north-east-sport/sport-news/2010/02/10/snooker-mike-dunn-s-world-bid-84229-25798762/ |work=[[Evening Gazette (Teesside)|Evening Gazette]] |accessdate=14 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ygHMjPoZ?url=http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/north-east-sport/sport-news/2010/02/10/snooker-mike-dunn-s-world-bid-84229-25798762/ |archivedate=14 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In March he qualified for the [[2010 World Snooker Championship|World Championship]] for a record 30th time by defeating [[Adrian Gunnell]] 10–4.{{cite news|title=Veteran Steve Davis wins 30th place at snooker's Crucible world showdown|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/othersports/article-1256183/Veteran-Steve-Davis-wins-30th-place-snookers-Crucible-world-showdown.html|work=The Daily Mail |location=UK|accessdate=14 May 2011|archiveurl=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/othersports/article-1256183/Veteran-Steve-Davis-wins-30th-place-snookers-Crucible-world-showdown.html|archivedate=2 June 2011|date=9 March 2010}} In the first round Davis defeated [[Mark King (snooker player)|Mark King]] 10–9, becoming, at the age of 52, the oldest player to win a match at the Crucible since [[Eddie Charlton]] beat [[Cliff Thorburn]] in 1989.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2010/apr/21/steve-davis-snooker-world-championship |title=Steve Davis becomes oldest player in 21 years to win at world championships |date=21 April 2010 |work=Guardian |accessdate=24 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGIS?url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/sport/2010/apr/21/steve-davis-snooker-world-championship |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |location=London |first=Clive |last=Everton |deadurl=yes |df= }} In the second round against defending champion [[John Higgins (snooker player)|John Higgins]], a 1–20 favourite, Davis led 6–2 after the first session, 9–7 after the second session, and ultimately won 13–11, a win [[Clive Everton]] described as "the greatest upset in the 33 years the Crucible has been hosting the championship."{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2010/apr/25/steve-davis-world-championship-snooker |title=Eighties flashbacks inspire Steve Davis to Crucible's greatest upset |date=25 April 2010 |work=Guardian |accessdate=24 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGIb?url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/sport/2010/apr/25/steve-davis-world-championship-snooker |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |location=London |first=Clive |last=Everton |deadurl=yes |df= }} This made him the oldest world quarter-finalist since Charlton in 1983. In the quarter-final match against Australian [[Neil Robertson (snooker player)|Neil Robertson]], Davis recovered from a 2–12 deficit to force the match into the third session, eventually losing 5–13.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/8646438.stm |title=Neil Robertson beats Steve Davis to make world semis |date=28 April 2010 |work=BBC Sport |accessdate=28 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb25?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/8646438.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} On 29 April 2010, to mark the 25th anniversary of their black-ball final of 1985, Davis appeared with Taylor before the beginning of the first semi-final, to stage a humorous re-enactment of their historic final frame. Taylor entered the arena wearing a pair of comically oversized glasses, while Davis arrived sporting a red wig.{{cite web|url=http://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/index.php/news/content/view/full/89786 |title=Davis and Taylor rerun 1985 classic |date=29 April 2010 |work=[[Morning Star (UK newspaper)|Morning Star]] |accessdate=30 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb2J?url=http://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/index.php/news/content/view/full/89786 |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis started the [[Snooker season 2010/2011|2010/2011 season]] by qualifying to the televised stages of [[2010 Shanghai Masters|Shanghai Masters]], whitewashing Rod Lawler 5–0,{{Cite web|url=http://www.global-snooker.com/2010-Shanghai-Masters-Snooker-Qualifying-Rounds.asp |title=2010 Roewe Shanghai Masters Qualifying Matches and Results |publisher=Global Snooker |accessdate=27 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGIb?url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/sport/2010/apr/25/steve-davis-world-championship-snooker |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} but lost in the first round 3–5 against [[Jamie Cope]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.global-snooker.com/2010-Shanghai-Masters-Draw.asp |title=2010 Roewe Shanghai Masters Final Stage Matches and Results |publisher=Global Snooker |accessdate=27 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGIm?url=http://www.global-snooker.com/2010-Shanghai-Masters-Snooker-Qualifying-Rounds.asp |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He lost his qualifying matches in the next two tournaments, he lost 1–3 against [[Peter Ebdon]] in the last 64 of the [[2010 World Open (snooker)|World Open]]{{cite web|title=Ebdon defeats Davis in batlle of World Champs |url=http://www.110sport.tv/news/662 |publisher=110 Sport |accessdate=14 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGJ4?url=http://www.110sport.tv/news/662 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and 2–9 against [[Mark Joyce]] in the last 48 of the [[2010 UK Championship (snooker)|UK Championship]].{{cite web|title=2010 UK Championship Results |url=http://snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=264 |publisher=Snooker Database |accessdate=14 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGJD?url=http://snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=264 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He also participated at the [[Players Tour Championship 2010/2011|Players Tour Championship]], where his best results came at the [[Euro Players Tour Championship 2010/2011 – Event 1|Paul Hunter Classic]], where he reached the quarter-finals, but lost 1–4 against [[Shaun Murphy (snooker player)|Shaun Murphy]].{{Cite web| url=http://www.worldsnooker.com/page/NewsArticles/0,,13165~2363069,00.html | title=Euro Players Tour Championship 1 Drawsheet (Last 16 to Final)| publisher=[[World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association]] | accessdate=4 April 2012}} He finished 67 on the [[Players Tour Championship 2010/2011#Order of Merit|Order of Merit]].{{cite web|url=http://www.worldsnooker.com/staticFiles/87/64/0,,13165~156807,00.pdf |title=Order of Merit |work=worldsnooker.com |publisher=[[World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association]] |date=22 November 2010 |accessdate=5 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110626114052/http://www.worldsnooker.com/staticFiles/87/64/0%2C%2C13165~156807%2C00.pdf |archivedate=26 June 2011 |df= }} Davis also reached the final of the [[2010 World Seniors Championship|World Seniors Championship]], but lost in the final 1–4 against [[Jimmy White]]. He reached the third qualifying round of the [[2011 German Masters|German Masters]], but was whitewashed by Ryan Day 0–5.{{cite web|title=2011 German Masters Results |url=http://snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=276 |publisher=Snooker Database |accessdate=2 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8u5y4gs?url=http://snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=276 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis lost his first qualifying matches of the next two tournaments. He was beaten by [[Shailesh Jogia|Joe Jogia]] 3–4 in the [[2011 Welsh Open (snooker)|Welsh Open]]{{cite web|title=2011 Welsh Open Results |url=http://snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=277 |publisher=Snooker Database |accessdate=2 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8uCys5y?url=http://snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=277 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and 4–5 by [[James Wattana]] in the [[2011 China Open (snooker)|China Open]].{{cite web|title=2011 China Open Results |url=http://snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=279 |publisher=Snooker Database |accessdate=2 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8uHw54j?url=http://snookerdatabase.co.uk/EventResults.aspx?EventKey=279 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He narrowly reached the last qualifying round of the [[2011 World Snooker Championship|World Championship]], by defeating [[Jack Lisowski]] 10–9, but lost against [[Stephen Lee (snooker player)|Stephen Lee]] 2–10.{{cite web|title=2011 World
