|accessdate=15 April 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FtuCBQpA?url=http://3a43ed9bbf8e4c3a0092-e5ae3e47d460213726cd286f2f322a12.r38.cf3.rackcdn.com/b1d477d0-43ce-4f32-a3dd-4380fa926e5b.pdf |archivedate=15 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis started the [[Snooker season 2013/2014|2013/2014 season]] at [[Snooker world rankings 2013/2014|number 51]],{{cite web |title=The World Professional Billiards & Snooker Association official World Snooker ranking list for the 2013/2014 season |url=http://www.worldsnooker.com/staticFiles/48/bc/0,,13165~179272,00.pdf |publisher=[[World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association]] |work=worldsnooker.com |accessdate=8 May 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6GTFR8281?url=http://www.worldsnooker.com/staticFiles/48/bc/0,,13165~179272,00.pdf |archivedate=8 May 2013 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |df= }} and his first match was in the qualifying stages for the [[2013 Wuxi Classic|Wuxi Classic]], where he faced [[James Cahill (snooker player)|James Cahill]]. After Cahill levelled the match at 2–2, Davis won the next three frames in a row, along with a 131 break in the penultimate frame, to book his place for the main stage of the tournament in [[Wuxi]],{{cite web|title=Wuxi Classic qualifiers – Round 1 – Match 51 – Steve Davis v James Cahill |url=http://livescores.worldsnookerdata.com/Matches/Result/13369?matchId=180229 |work=worldsnookerdata.com |publisher=[[World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association]] |accessdate=28 May 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6GwnfJcXn?url=http://livescores.worldsnookerdata.com/Matches/Result/13369?matchId=180229 |archivedate=28 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} where he lost 1–5 against [[Andrew Higginson]] in the last 64.{{cite web|title=Wuxi Classic 2013: Schedule and results|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/snooker/22919548|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=17 June 2013}} Davis then lost at the qualifying stages of the next two ranking events he entered. He lost 2–5 against Higginson at the [[2013 Shanghai Masters|Shanghai Masters]],{{cite web|title=Shanghai Masters 2013 qualifiers results |url=http://3a43ed9bbf8e4c3a0092-e5ae3e47d460213726cd286f2f322a12.r38.cf3.rackcdn.com/ba3db8ea-33ef-4405-9a42-90a126fe7038.pdf |publisher=[[World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association]] |accessdate=11 August 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ImmZxerc?url=http://3a43ed9bbf8e4c3a0092-e5ae3e47d460213726cd286f2f322a12.r38.cf3.rackcdn.com/ba3db8ea-33ef-4405-9a42-90a126fe7038.pdf |archivedate=11 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and 1–4 against [[Thanawat Thirapongpaiboon]] at the [[2013 Indian Open|Indian Open]].{{cite web|title=Indian Open 2013 qualifiers results |url=http://livescores.worldsnookerdata.com/RoundList/Tournament/13539 |work=worldsnookerdata.com |publisher=[[World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association]] |accessdate=12 August 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6IpHZq30B?url=http://livescores.worldsnookerdata.com/RoundList/Tournament/13539 |archivedate=12 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He then qualified for the [[2013 International Championship|International Championship]] with a 6–2 win against [[Allan Taylor (snooker player)|Allan Taylor]],{{cite web|title=2013 International Championship Qualifiers Results |url=http://livescores.worldsnookerdata.com/RoundList/Tournament/13580 |work=worldsnookerdata.com |publisher=[[World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association]] |accessdate=2 October 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6KAphjjDX?url=http://livescores.worldsnookerdata.com/RoundList/Tournament/13580 |archivedate= 6 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} but lost at the venue 1–6 against [[Zhao Xintong]] in the wildcard round.{{cite web|title=International Open 2013: Schedule and results|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/snooker/24657112|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=30 October 2013}} Davis won his first [[2013 World Seniors Championship|World Seniors Championship]] title by defeating [[Nigel Bond]] 2–1 in the final.{{cite web|title=World Seniors Championship: Steve Davis beats Nigel Bond 2–1 in Portsmouth final|url=http://www1.skysports.com/snooker/news/12243/8983211|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|accessdate=20 October 2013|date=20 October 2013}} After a defeat by [[Craig Steadman]] 8–10 in the second round of the [[2014 World Snooker Championship]] qualification, Davis finished the season outside the top 64 in the money list and dropped off the professional main tour after 36 years. Given an invitational tour card to participate in tournaments for the 2014–15 season, Davis made his return to competitive snooker in the [[European Tour 2014/2015 – Event 1|Riga Open]] in August 2014, losing 1–4 to [[Robert Milkins]] in the last 64.{{cite web|title=European Tour Event One (2014)|url=http://www.snooker.org/res/index.asp?event=336|publisher=Snooker.org|accessdate=10 August 2014}} He then participated in the [[European Tour 2014/2015 – Event 2|Paul Hunter Classic]], losing 2–4 to [[Gary Wilson (snooker player)|Gary Wilson]] in the last 128.{{cite web|title=European Tour Event Two (2014)|url=http://snooker.org/res/index.asp?event=337|publisher=Snooker.org|accessdate=14 August 2014}} Davis played in the [[2014 Champion of Champions]] event after qualifying through winning the [[2013 World Seniors Championship]],{{cite web|url=http://www.matchroomsport.com/news/champion-champions-group-seeds-announced/|title=Champion of Champions Group Seeds Announced – Matchroom Sport|date=17 October 2014|publisher=}} losing 1–4 to [[Mark Selby]] in the group semi-final.{{cite web|title=Dafabet Champion of Champions (2014) |url=http://snooker.org/res/index.asp?event=352|publisher=Snooker.org|accessdate=16 May 2014}} He entered the 2016 World Championship qualifiers but was beaten by [[Fergal O'Brien]] in his final match as a professional snooker player. ===Retirement=== On 17 April 2016 Davis announced his retirement from professional snooker during a live BBC broadcast, citing the recent death of his father Bill as the main reason. Davis entered the Crucible Theatre holding the World Championship trophy and received a standing ovation by the audience.{{cite news| url = http://www.eurosport.co.uk/snooker/emotional-steve-davis-announces-retirement-after-glorious-38-year-career_sto5448403/story.shtml| title =Emotional Steve Davis announces retirement after glorious 38-year career| accessdate = 25 April 2016| date = 17 April 2016|publisher=[[Eurosport]]}} Davis continues to play exhibitions and commentate for the BBC's snooker coverage. ==Legacy== In the book ''Masters of the Baize'', a detailed comparison and ranking of snooker professionals, authors Luke Williams and Paul Gadsby rated Davis as the third greatest snooker player of all time behind [[Joe Davis]] and [[Stephen Hendry]].{{cite news|date=14 April 2005 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/4444185.stm |title=Hendry rated as best-ever player |publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]] |accessdate=2 January 2007 |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb2z?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/4444185.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite book|last1=Williams|first1=Luke|last2=Gadsby|first2=Paul|title=Masters of the Baize: Cue Legends, Bad Boys and Forgotten Men in Search of Snooker's Ultimate Prize|year=2005|publisher=Mainstream Publishing|isbn=1-84018-872-3}} Davis has won a record 81 professional titles and was the runner-up in 37 events. [[List of snooker players by number of ranking titles|28 of these titles were in ranking events]]. His record of six world titles in the modern era has been bettered only by Hendry and only Ronnie O'Sullivan has matched his tally of six UK titles. Davis has also compiled over 300 competitive centuries during his career. In 2011 he was inducted to World Snooker's newly created [[Hall of Fame (snooker)|Hall of Fame]] along with seven former World Champions.{{cite web|title=Higgins Voted Player Of The Year|url=http://www.worldsnooker.com/page/NewsArticles/0,,13165~2354226,00.html|work=worldsnooker.com|publisher=[[World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association]]|accessdate=11 May 2011}} ==Other sports== [[File:Steve Davis at German Masters Snooker Final (DerHexer) 2012-02-05 1.ogv|thumb|Steve Davis playing a [[trick shot]] potting a ball under a cloth]] From 1994 to 2007 Davis played in professional [[nine-ball]] [[Pool (cue sports)|pool]] events regularly. He was instrumental in the creation of the [[Mosconi Cup]],{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/general/an-email-conversation-with-steve-davis-snooker-has-real-strength-in-depth-its-not-like-it-used-to-be-761377.html |title=An email conversation with Steve Davis: 'Snooker has real strength in depth. It's not like it used to be' |work=The Independent |location=UK |accessdate=29 August 2009 |date=3 December 2007 |first=Nick |last=Harris |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb6p?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/general/an-email-conversation-with-steve-davis-snooker-has-real-strength-in-depth-its-not-like-it-used-to-be-761377.html |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and has represented Europe in the tournament on eleven occasions, and was a member of the team's [[1995 Mosconi Cup|1995]] and [[2002 Mosconi Cup|2002]] wins;{{cite web|url=http://2005.mosconicup.com/history.asp |title=History |work=2005.mosconicup.com |publisher=Matchroom Sport |accessdate=2 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8uYuXxO?url=http://2005.mosconicup.com/history.asp |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} his victory against the US's [[Earl Strickland]] clinched the 2002 competition for Europe.{{cite web|url=http://www.9ballpool.co.uk/news/story.html?id=87 |title=Europe Win Mosconi Cup For First Time Since 1995 |publisher=9ballpool.co.uk |accessdate=21 April 2007 |date=23 December 2002 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb3t?url=http://www.9ballpool.co.uk/news/story/Europe-Win-Mosconi-Cup-For-First-Time-Since-1995.html |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://2004.mosconicup.com/history.asp |work=2004.mosconicup.com |publisher=Mosconi Cup |title=History (1994–2003) |accessdate=2 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8v0QmXY?url=http://2004.mosconicup.com/history.asp |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{Cite web | title = Steve Davis: Mosconi 2002 Was One Of The Best Moments Of My Career - Matchroom Pool | author = | work = Matchroom Pool | date = | accessdate = 9 August 2018 | url = http://www.matchroompool.com/news/steve-davis-mosconi-2002-was-one-of-the-best-moments-of-my-career/ | quote = }} In 2001 Davis nearly won his first singles title in pool at the [[World Pool League]], however, [[Efren Reyes]] defeated him 9–5 the final.{{cite web|url=http://www.epbf.com/sportsite/2001/WPL2001/WPL%20Press5.htm |title=World Pool League Back In Poland |publisher=European Pocket Billiard Federation |accessdate=11 April 2007 |year=2001 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8v93M5F?url=http://www.epbf.com/sportsite/2001/WPL2001/WPL%20Press5.htm |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} [[Sid Waddell]] gave him the nickname "Romford Slim" and said he was Britain's answer to the famous American pool player [[Rudolf Wanderone|Rudolf "Minnesota Fats" Wanderone]]. Davis dislikes [[blackball (pool)|eight-ball pool]] as played on English-style tables in British [[public house|pubs]] and clubs, considering it a "[[Mickey Mouse (pejorative)|Mickey Mouse game]]" because of its undersized cue ball in relation to the other balls, but made it clear that he is only critical of the game when it is played with an undersized cue ball.{{cite web|url=http://www.uk8ball.com/article.php?sid=604|title=Uk8ball.com Interviews Steve Davis at the Nineball Worlds|work=UK8Ball.com|date=17 July 2002|accessdate=3 May 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927064914/http://www.uk8ball.com/article.php?sid=604 |archivedate = 27 September 2007}} Davis reached the last 16 of the [[2003 WPA World Nine-ball Championship]], where he faced three-time champion Strickland, held in [[Cardiff]], [[Wales]]. The match was notable for the behaviour the match was played under, with Strickland calling out members of the crowd for being biased towards Davis.{{Cite web | title = Strickland beats Davis and crowd to get to WPC Final 8 | author = | work = azbilliards.com | date = | accessdate = 9 August 2018 | url = http://www.azbilliards.com/news/stories/362-strickland-beats-davis-and-crowd-to-get-to-wpc-final-8/ | language = | quote = }} Referee [[Michaela Tabb]] warned Strickland, to which he replied that Tabb should "shut up".{{cite news |title=Mount St Earl Erupts, Wins! |url=http://www.billiardsdigest.com/tournaments/display_article.php?article_id=352&tournament_id=10 |author=Mike Panozzo |date=19 July 2003 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212070029/http://www.billiardsdigest.com/tournaments/display_article.php?article_id=352&tournament_id=10 |archivedate=12 February 2012}} Strickland would also complain after Davis took a second toilet break, when only allocated one. Davis later admitted this was used as [[gamesmanship]] against Strickland. Strickland would win the match, and later proceed to the Semi-finals of the event.{{Cite web | title = Michaela Tabb Interview « Snooker Island Blog | author = | work = snookerisland.com | date = | accessdate = 9 August 2018 | url = https://www.snookerisland.com/blog/michaela-tabb-interview/ | quote = }} Davis has also become a proficient [[poker]] player, with successful appearances at televised tournaments;{{cite web |url=http://pokerdb.thehendonmob.com/player.php?a=r&n=404 |title=Steve Davis Profile |accessdate=29 April 2008 |publisher=The Mob Poker Database |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8vDG0Qm?url=http://pokerdb.thehendonmob.com/player.php?a=r&n=404 |archivedate=2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} these included an appearance at the final table of the 2003 [[Poker Million]] together with fellow snooker player [[Jimmy White]], who eventually won.{{cite web|url=http://www.pokerplayer.co.uk/news/features/1755/the_history_of_the_poker_million.html |title=History of the Poker Million |accessdate=4 May 2011 |publisher=[[Poker Player]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGJL?url=http://www.pokerplayer.co.uk/news/features/1755/the_history_of_the_poker_million.html |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Later, at [[2006 World Series of Poker results#Event 41: $1,500 No Limit Hold'em|Event 41]] of the [[2006 World Series of Poker]], Davis finished 579th, winning US$20,617.{{cite web |url=http://www.cardplayer.com/poker-tournaments/197-2006-37th-annual-world-series-of-poker/3229/results?page=29&commit=Go |title=Event 41 – No-Limit Hold'em Championship (Players ranked between 561 and 580) |accessdate=9 May 2011 |publisher=CardPlayer.com |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yYapP0wf?url=http://www.cardplayer.com/poker-tournaments/197-2006-37th-annual-world-series-of-poker/3229/results?page=29&commit=Go |archivedate=9 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} At [[2008 World Series of Poker results#Event 54: $10,000 World Championship No-Limit Hold'em|Event 54]] of the [[2008 World Series of Poker]] he finished 389th, winning $28,950.{{cite web |url=http://www.cardplayer.com/poker-tournaments/2022-2008-39th-annual-world-series-of-poker/14422/results?page=20&commit=Go |title=Event 54 – World Championship No-Limit Hold'em (Players ranked between 381 and 400) |accessdate=9 May 2011 |publisher=CardPlayer.com |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yYbCvEYL?url=http://www.cardplayer.com/poker-tournaments/2022-2008-39th-annual-world-series-of-poker/14422/results?page=20&commit=Go |archivedate=9 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} At [[2010 World Series of Poker results#Event 56: $2,500 No Limit Hold'em|Event 56]] of the [[2010 World Series of Poker]] he finished 131st, winning $5,491.{{cite web |url=http://www.cardplayer.com/poker-tournaments/2922-2010-wsop/253290/results?commit=Go&page=7 |title=Event 56 – $2,500 No-Limit Hold'em (Players ranked between 122 and 141) |accessdate=11 May 2011 |publisher=CardPlayer.com |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ybPXpr7f?url=http://www.cardplayer.com/poker-tournaments/2922-2010-wsop/253290/results?commit=Go&page=7 |archivedate=11 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} At Event 22 of the 2011 Grand Poker Series he finished 8th, winning $2,049.{{cite web|url=http://www.cardplayer.com/poker-tournaments/3357-2011-the-grand-poker-series/979567/results |title=Event 22 – H.O.R.S.E. results |accessdate=13 March 2012 |publisher=CardPlayer.com |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/669eQKBS3?url=http://www.cardplayer.com/poker-tournaments/3357-2011-the-grand-poker-series/979567/results |archivedate=14 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He is also a keen [[chess]] player and was for a while the president of the [[English Chess Federation|British Chess Federation]]. In 1995, he co-authored a book, ''Steve Davis Plays Chess''. ==In other media== Davis has become known for his coolness and impeccable conduct in high-pressure situations.{{World Snooker|active|13165~2233683,00|accessdate=1 April 2010}} His initial lack of emotional expression and somewhat monotonous interviewing style earned him a reputation as boring. As a result, the satirical television series ''[[Spitting Image]]'' gave him the ironic nickname ''"Interesting"''.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/lancashire/sport/cue_sports/2003/09/24/sdavis_spot.shtml |title=Mr Interesting...On the Spot |accessdate=14 April 2007 |publisher=BBC Lancashire |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb4n?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/england/lancashire/default.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis himself now plays upon this image and says it helped him gain acceptance from the public.{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/snooker/2325251/Interesting-Steve-Davis-still-playing-for-fun.html | title='Interesting' Steve Davis still playing for fun |work=The Independent |location=UK| accessdate = 14 May 2011 | date=8 November 2007| first=Robert | last=Philip}} It led to him co-authoring a comedic book, ''How to Be Really Interesting'' (1988), with [[Geoff Atkinson]], the front cover of which shows Davis mocking his perceived dullness, dressed in boxing regalia holding a cue.{{cite book |last= Davis |first= Steve |last2= Atkinson|first2= Geoff |title= How To Be Really Interesting |publisher=Penguin Books Ltd |year= 1988 |isbn= 0-14-011306-1}} Davis appeared as a commentator for the BBC's snooker coverage and as a guest on television quizzes such as ''[[They Think It's All Over (TV series)|They Think It's All Over]]'' and ''[[A Question of Sport]]''.{{cite news|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0205506/ |title=Steve Davis |publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]] |accessdate=2 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGJm?url=http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0205506/ |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He appeared in a baked beans advertisement in the 1980s (featuring snooker commentator [[Ted Lowe]] with the pay-off line ''"really interesting"'' and Davis 'assessing' his beans on toast as if it were a snooker situation, and chalking his cutlery).{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/in_depth/2001/world_snooker_championship/1210950.stm |title=Davis: An "Interesting" legend |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 April 2001 |accessdate=25 January 2008 |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb69?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/in_depth/2001/world_snooker_championship/1210950.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In 2007, his image was used as the epitome of "reliability" in a series of advertisements for [[Irish Life and Permanent|Irish Life]].{{cite web|url=http://www.irishlife.ie/selectsnapshot.html |title=Snapshot of our Select investments |publisher=[[Irish Life and Permanent|Irish Life]] |accessdate=25 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb5F?url=http://www.irishlife.ie/selectsnapshot.html |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He featured in a spoof online viral promoting the [[Nintendo DS]] game ''World Snooker Championship Season 2007–08'', in which he parodied a [[Nicole Kidman]] Brain Training advert.{{cite news|url=http://www.marketingweek.co.uk/analysis/viral-turns-snooker-ace-into-kidman/2058302.article |title=Viral turns snooker ace into Kidman |publisher=Marketing Week |date=18 October 2007 |accessdate=25 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGJu?url=http://www.marketingweek.co.uk/analysis/viral-turns-snooker-ace-into-kidman/2058302.article |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In 2010, Davis made a cameo appearance in ''[[The Increasingly Poor Decisions of Todd Margaret]]'' as himself. His other TV appearances include a guest slot on the Christmas 1981 edition of ''[[The Morecambe & Wise Show (1968–1977)|The Morecambe and Wise Show]]''. He has published numerous other books, five relating to snooker: ''Successful Snooker'' (1982),{{cite book|last=Davis|first=Steve|title=Successful Snooker|year=1982|publisher=Littlehampton Book Services Ltd|location=London|isbn=0-85097-437-2}} ''Frame and Fortune'' (1982),{{cite book|last=Davis|first=Steve|title=Frame and fortune|year=1982|publisher=Arthur Barker|location=London|isbn=0-213-16840-5}} ''Steve Davis: Snooker Champion'' (1983),{{cite book|last=Davis|first=Steve|title=Steve Davis : Snooker Champion|year=1983|publisher=Pan Books|location=London|isbn=0-330-26864-3|editor=Radford, Brian}} ''Matchroom Snooker'' (1988){{cite book |last1= Davis |first1= Steve |last2=Griffiths |first2=Terry |last3=Taylor |first3=Dennis|last4=White |first4=Jimmy|last5=Foulds |first5=Neal|last6=Meo |first6=Tony|last7=Thorne|first7=Willie |title= Matchroom Snooker |publisher=Pelham Books |date=May 1988 |isbn= 0-7207-1826-0 }} and ''The Official Matchroom 1990'';{{cite book|last=Davis|first=Steve|title=The Official Matchroom 1990|year=1989|publisher=[[Hamlyn (publishers)|Hamlyn]]}} two relating to chess in 1995 with [[David Norwood]]: ''Steve Davis Plays Chess''{{cite book |last1= Davis |first1= Steve |last2= Norwood |first2=David |title= Steve Davis Plays Chess |publisher=B.T. Batsford Ltd |date=September 1995 |isbn= 0-7134-7813-6 }} and ''Grandmaster Meets Chess Amateur''.{{cite book|last1= Davis |first1= Steve |last2= Norwood |first2=David|title=Grandmaster Meets Chess Amateur|year=1995|publisher=Henry Holt & Co|location=New York|isbn=0-8050-4224-5|edition=1st American}} He also authored three cookbooks in 1994: ''Simply Fix – the Steve Davis Interesting Cookbook No 1 – Interesting Things to Do With Meat'',{{cite book|last=Davis|first=Steve|title=Simply Fix – the Steve Davis Interesting Cookbook No 1 – Interesting Things to Do With Meat|year=1994|publisher=[[Crosse & Blackwell]]|isbn=0-946555-35-4}} ''Simply Fix – The Steve Davis Interesting Cookbook No 2 – Interesting Things to Make with Poultry'',{{cite book|last=Davis|first=Steve|title=Simply Fix – The Steve Davis Interesting Cookbook No 2 – Interesting Things to Make with Poultry|year=1994|publisher=Crosse & Blackwell|location=London|isbn=0-946555-34-6}} and ''Simply Fix – the Steve Davis Interesting Cookbook No 3 – Interesting Things to Make Using Vegetables''.{{cite book|last=Davis|first=Steve|title=Simply Fix – The Steve Davis Interesting Cookbook No 3 – Interesting Things to Make Using Vegetables|year=1994|publisher=Crosse & Blackwell|location=London}} In 1986, he joined musical duo [[Chas & Dave]] and several other snooker stars of the time (under the name "The Matchroom Mob") on the novelty record "[[Snooker Loopy]]", which was a Top 10 hit in the United Kingdom.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/in_depth/2000/uk_championship_snooker/1024916.stm |title=When Snooker Went Loopy |work=BBC |accessdate=20 June 2010 |date=20 November 2000 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGJm?url=http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0205506/ |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.chartstats.com/songinfo.php?id=13317 |title=Snooker Loopy |work=Chart Stats |accessdate=5 February 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGKC?url=http://www.chartstats.com/songinfo.php?id=13317 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} A year the later they released a follow-up single, the "Romford Rap", though this only reached #91 in the UK charts.{{cite web|url=http://www.chartstats.com/release.php?release=14047 |title=The Romford Rap |work=Chart Stats |accessdate=14 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGKL?url=http://www.chartstats.com/release.php?release=14047 |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Since 1996 he has presented a show dedicated to [[progressive rock]] and the [[Canterbury scene]] on his local radio station, [[Phoenix FM]].{{cite web|url=http://www.phoenixfm.com/the-interesting-alternative-show/ |title=The Interesting Alternative Show |accessdate=29 September 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb5v?url=http://www.phoenixfm.com/interesting-alternative.php |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In 2013, Davis participated in the [[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! (UK series 13)|thirteenth series]] of ''[[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! (UK TV series)|I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!]]'',{{cite web|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/othersports/article-2516716/EDGE-OF-THE-BOX-Steve-Davis-Im-Celebrity-Snooker-fails-attract.html|title=With Davis racking up TV numbers in the jungle and Irvine doing all she can to sell the new format, can Snooker attract audiences away from The Crucible?|date=2 December 2013|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=2 December 2013}} finishing in eighth place. In 2017, he appeared in ''[[Would I Lie to You? (TV series)|Would I Lie to You?]]'' as a guest panelist where he recounted the true story of being fired by the Sultan of Brunei as a coach to his son following an incident with a cheese sandwich. A film about Steve Davis' rise and subsequent dominance of snooker in the 1980s and his intense rivalry with [[Alex Higgins]] was released by the BBC in 2016 titled ''[[The Rack Pack]]'' casting [[Will Merrick]] as Davis {{Citation|last=Welsh|first=Brian|title=The Rack Pack|date=17 January 2016|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2464690/|others=Dennis Taylor, Steve Davis, Alex Higgins|access-date=28 June 2018}}. == Radio and Club DJ career == Davis joined Brentwood community radio station [[Phoenix FM]] in 1996, broadcasting a variety of soul and rock shows during the next ten years while the station broadcast online and on FM under a [[Restricted Service Licence]]. When the station went full-time on FM in March 2007, Davis started to broadcast The Interesting Alternative show on Monday evenings - a show (as of 2018) he continues to present weekly.{{cite web|url = https://www.phoenixfm.com/category/the-interesting-alternative-show/|title=The Interesting Alternative Show|work=[[Phoenix FM]]|accessdate=21 August 2018}} As a result of his regular broadcasting Davis presented a guest slot on [[BBC Radio 6 Music]] in 2011.{{cite news|last=Sherwin|first=Adam|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/steve-davis-gets-interesting-as-a-prog-rock-dj-2274415.html|title=Steve Davis gets interesting as a prog rock DJ|work=The Independent|date=24 April 2011|accessdate=18 September 2017}} He branched out into club work with a more modern sound in 2015 and has regular slots at London bars and nightclubs.{{cite web|url = http://crackmagazine.net/cracktv/music/steve-davis-at-bloc/|title=Steve Davis at Bloc|date=18 April 2016|work=Crack Magazine|accessdate=21 April 2015}} Davis performed with his collaborator [[Kavus Torabi]] at the [[Glastonbury Festival]] in 2016.{{cite news|last=Burnton|first=Simon|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2017/apr/22/steve-davis-snooker-crucible-glastonbury-new-career-dj|title=Steve Davis: 'Since leaving snooker I’ve got my adrenaline rush a different way'|work=The Observer|date=22 April 2017|accessdate=18 September 2017}} == Personal life == In 1988, Davis was named the [[BBC Sports Personality of the Year]] and was made an [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]].{{London Gazette |issue=51365 |date=10 June 1988 |page=13 |supp=y }}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/tv_and_radio/sports_personality_2003/3222684.stm |title=Sports Personality 2006 – Past winners: 1988–1992 |accessdate=25 February 2008 |publisher=BBC |date=27 November 2003 |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb5T?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/tv_and_radio/sports_personality_2003/3222684.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} He was made an [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] in 2000,{{London Gazette |issue=55710 |date=30 December 1999 |page=12 |supp=y }}{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/biographies/biogs/sport/stevedavis.shtml |title=Biographies; Steve Davis: Presenter |accessdate=14 April 2007 |publisher=BBC Press Office |year=2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb0i?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/biographies/biogs/sport/stevedavis.shtml |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and is currently honorary president of the [[Snooker Writers' Association]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/snooker/4454403.stm |title=Crucible Diary – Day Two |accessdate=15 April 2007 |publisher=BBC Sport |first1=Jonathan |last1=Rawcliffe |first2=Phil |last2=Harlow |date=17 April 2005 |location=London |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb5h?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/4454403.stm |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis is a big fan of the French [[progressive rock]] band [[Magma (band)|Magma]], and even organised a concert in London so he could watch them.{{cite news|last=Honeyball |first=Lee |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2004/mar/07/snooker.features |title=My obsession |accessdate=14 April 2007 |work=The Observer |location=UK |date=7 March 2004 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5z8pYGGKT?url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/sport/2004/mar/07/snooker.features |archivedate= 2 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Davis is on the board of [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] football club; he has been a [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] fan most of his life.{{cite journal |last=Nicoli |first=Luke |title=Steve Davis |journal=FourFourTwo |date=November 2007 |page=110 }} Davis lives in [[Brentwood, Essex|Brentwood]], Essex,{{cite web|url=http://insidepool.com/article1106.html |title=Steve Davis |accessdate=14 April 2007 |publisher=Inside Pool |year=2004 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4Hwxb47?url=http://insidepool.com/article1106.html |archivedate= 7 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and divorced from his wife Judith in 2005 after 15 years of marriage. They have two sons called Greg (born 1991) and Jack (born 1993).{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-129783302.html|title=Steve's Cutie|publisher=[[Sunday Mirror]]([[HighBeam Research]])|accessdate=4 April 2012|date=6 March 2005|first=Susie |last=Boniface|authorlink=Susie Boniface}} In 2012, Greg Davis entered the Q School, with the aim of winning a place on the [[World Snooker Tour|professional snooker tour]].{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/snooker/9129790/Greg-Davis-has-waited-patiently-but-he-is-itching-to-clean-up-like-his-snooker-father-Steve.html|title=Greg Davis has waited patiently but he is itching to clean up like his snooker father Steve|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|location=London|accessdate=8 March 2012|date=8 March 2012|first=Jim |last=White}}{{cite web|title=Davis Junior Sets Snooker Goal|url=http://www.worldsnooker.com/page/NewsArticles/0,,13165~2635161,00.html|work=worldsnooker.com|publisher=[[World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association]]|accessdate=8 March 2012}} He was a supporter of the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] for the [[United Kingdom general election, 1983|1983 General Election]].{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/election_2010/8617149.stm|title=BBC News – Election 2010: Political celebrities – then and now|publisher=}} ==Performance and rankings timeline==

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Thomas Nelson Downs | image = Thomas Nelson Downs magician.png | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1867|3|16}} | birth_place = [[Marshalltown, Iowa]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1938|9|11|1867|3|16}} | death_place = [[Marshalltown, Iowa]] | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = | education = | employer = | occupation = | title = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = {{plainlist}} *Nellie Stone (?-1895) *Harriett Rocky (1905-1938) {{endplainlist}} | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }}
'''Thomas Nelson Downs''', also '''T. Nelson Downs''', (March 16, 1867 – September 11, 1938) was one of the most famous manipulative [[magic (illusion)|magician]]s renowned for his [[Coin magic|coin tricks]]. Downs was also known as "The King of Koins".<ref name=obit>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=T. Nelson Downs |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1938/09/12/archives/t-nelson-downs.html |quote= T. Nelson Downs, known thirty years ago in Europe and America as the "King of Koins," died today at his home here. He retired more than ten years ago. ... |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=September 12, 1938|accessdate=2007-08-21 }}</ref><ref>Gill, Robert. (1976). ''Magic as a Performing Art: A Bibliography of Conjuring''. Bowker. p. 51. {{ISBN|978-0859350389}} "T. Nelson Downs was one of the greatest exponents of sleightof-hand and manipulation. Known professionally as the 'King of Koins', he was one of the first performers to specialize in coin manipulation for stage work; he was undoubtedly as accomplished a manipulator with other objects as he was with coins."</ref>
Magic historian David Price has written that Downs "was the first of the great manipulative magicians and probably the greatest of them all."<ref>Price, David. (1985). ''Magic: A Pictorial History of Conjurers in the Theater''. Cornwell Books. p. 177. {{ISBN|978-0845347386}}</ref>
==Biography== Born in [[Marshalltown, Iowa]], he was the youngest of six children in the family of Thomas and Cordelia Downs. His family moved to Iowa from the [[New York (state)|New York]] state. Downs' father, the [[Marshall County, Iowa|Marshall county]] superintendent, died when his son was not even a year old.
Downs never took any training in magic; all his tricks were self-taught. By the age of 12, he became an expert in card and coin manipulation. He further mastered his skills by the age of 17, when he took a job as a railway [[telegraphy|telegrapher]] and had plenty of time to practice with coins.<ref>[[Milbourne Christopher|Christopher, Milbourne]]. (1996). ''The Illustrated History of Magic''. Greentrwood Publishing Group. p. 275. {{ISBN|978-0-435-07016-8}}</ref>
In September 1895, Downs decided to quit his telegraphy job and launch a career in magic. At first, he toured Iowa with his partner, Sam Spiegel, a [[mandolin]]ist. By 1897, Downs concentrated only on the coin tricks — a rare specialization at that time, and established himself in [[vaudeville]], which was a popular avenue for magicians.
The success of Downs career allowed him to get booked into [[Tony Pastor]]'s New York theatre, and to [[London]]'s Palace Theatre soon after that.
At the peak of his career, Downs travelled frequently, and performed at royal courts. While performing his tricks, he could palm up to 60 coins at a time. One of his most famous tricks was "The Miser's Dream", in which he seemed to pull countless coins out of the thin air.
In 1912, at the age of 42, Downs decided to retire in Iowa. After moving back to Marshalltown, he rarely left the area. Not quite comfortable with idle retirement, Downs kept busy by opening a vaudeville house on Main Street, a few blocks from his own home at 7 South 3rd Avenue. He also sold a line of magic equipment. Many visitors, other magicians, streamed to his home to share gossip and the latest tricks as well as to brush elbows with the famous sleight of hand artist. The most famous of these visitors included [[Chung Ling Soo]] (William Robinson) and [[Dai Vernon]].
Downs was a friend with the magician [[Harry Houdini]], however, both were involved in an intense rivalry in private. Houdini had stated that Downs had operated a "fake magic shop" and was in trouble with the federal government for a "swindle."<ref>[[Kenneth Silverman|Silverman, Kenneth]]. (1996). ''Houdini!: The Career of Ehrich Weiss''. HarperCollins Publishers. p. 75. {{ISBN|978-0060928629}} "Houdini talked magic hours on end with his friend T. Nelson Downs (1867-1938), renowned for his palming — "one of the Historical lights of magic," Houdini called him. It was Downs who pioneered the magic specialty act, snatching silver from thin air as King of Koins. A midwesterner by birth, Downs like several other magicians had matured on the shady side of the law. According to Houdini, he had run a "fake Magic Shop," worked for a "fake spiritualist," and been wanted by the federal government for a "swindle." Houdini stayed friendly with these and many other magicians. But except in Downs 's case, a globe-covering sense of rivalry usually led him to belittle them in private."</ref> By 1896, Downs had campaigned against [[spiritualism]], this was before Houdini's crusade against fraudulent spiritualists. In his letters, Downs claimed to have performed a stage escape from [[handcuffs]] several years before Houdini. He also took issue with Houdini's self-advertisement.<ref>Rosheim, Mark. ''Introduction''. In Thomas Nelson Downs. (1999, reprint). ''Classic Coin Tricks: An Unabridged Reprint of Modern Coin Manipulation''. Dover Publications. p. 18. {{ISBN|0-486-40616-4}}</ref>
Downs wrote several books on magic before and after his retirement. His first book, ''Modern Coin Manipulation'', was published in 1900 and is still issued in reprints today. His other books include ''Tricks with Coins'' (1902) and ''The Art of Magic'' (1909).
Downs was married twice. He had a son in his first marriage with Nellie Stone, who died in childbirth in 1895. He subsequently married Harriett Rocky on June 3, 1905.
He retired around 1928. In 1935 he was honored with a testimonial dinner.<ref name=obit/>
==Death== Downs died on September 11, 1938 in [[Marshalltown, Iowa]].<ref name=obit/> He had suffered a stroke, which paralyzed his left side. He was buried at [[Riverside Cemetery (Marshalltown, Iowa)|Riverside Cemetery]] in Marshalltown. His gravestone reads "King of Koins".
==Legacy== The Historical Society of Marshall County features a display about Downs in its museum.
==Publications==
*''Modern Coin Manipulation'' (1900) *''Tricks with Coins'' (1902) *[https://archive.org/details/artofmagic00down ''The Art of Magic''] (1909)

This is a timeline of the history of [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]].
== 1980s == * '''1987''' **Two separate government studies have identified spare frequency space on the [[Ultra high frequency|UHF]] band, prompting political debate about the viability of a fifth UK terrestrial TV channel.<ref name=Timeline>{{cite news|first=Maggie |last=Brown |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/jul/23/channel-five-timeline |title=Channel Five: a timeline |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=23 July 2010 |accessdate=21 November 2018}}</ref>
* '''1988''' **A government [[white paper]] on broadcasting includes provisions for a fifth channel after [[Booz Allen Consultants]] recommends it as an option. Booz Allen claims the extra channel would reduce the current [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] monopoly and also reduce advertising costs.<ref name=Timeline/>
* '''1989''' ** March – The [[Independent Broadcasting Authority]] recommends that the headquarters of a fifth channel should be situated outside London, preferably at a location north of Birmingham.<ref name=Timeline/>
== 1990s == * '''1990''' ** The terms of a license for a fifth channel are set out in the [[Broadcasting Act 1990]]. It would need to be a general entertainment channel with a remit for some public service broadcasting. Additionally, it is estimated that the channel's coverage would reach only 74% of the UK, and a video retuning operation would need to be undertaken.<ref name=Timeline/>
* '''1991''' ** No events.
* '''1992''' ** July – Date of the initial deadline for applications to run the Channel 5 service.<ref name=Timeline/>
* '''1993''' ** The initial round of bidders includes a plan for a network of city-TV stations from [[Thames Television]]. The [[Independent Television Commission|ITC]] does not award the licence to any of the applicants and contemplates not awarding the licence at all.
* '''1994''' ** A second attempt to licence the fifth terrestrial channel begins and several companies apply.<ref>{{cite web|title=Channel Five Bidding Closes|url=http://www.itnsource.com/en/shotlist/ITN/1995/05/02/BSP020595031/?s=Channel+5&st=0&pn=1|publisher=ITN|accessdate=11 February 2016}}</ref>
* '''1995''' ** 20 October – '''Channel 5 Broadcasting Limited''' is awarded the licence.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/the-channel-5-licence-was-the-last-chance-to-offer-something-new-on-a-free-station-the-itc-blew-it-1580312.html|title='The Channel 5 licence was the last chance to offer something new on a|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.designweek.co.uk/issues/19-october-1995/itc-to-identify-channel-5-winner/|title=ITC to identify Channel 5 winner – Design Week|date=20 October 1995|publisher=}}</ref> It is a consortium of four investors — [[Pearson Television|Pearson]], [[United News and Media]], [[RTL Group|CLT-Ufa]] and [[Warburg Pincus]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Tara Conlan |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2005/jul/20/citynews.broadcasting |title=A history of Five |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=20 July 2005 |accessdate=22 November 2018}}</ref>
* '''1996''' ** Channel 5 retunes the UK’s video recorders to avoid interference with video recorders which use the same frequencies as those allocated to Channel 5. ** Engineering transmission tests are carried out at some sites.<ref name=test/>
* '''1997''' ** 2 January – Test transmissions begin for Channel 5 in some areas. Details of these are made available on [[Ceefax]] page 698 for a few weeks.<ref name=test-transmissions>{{cite web|url=http://tx.mb21.co.uk/info/625/channel5/tests.shtml|title=Channel 5: The Test Transmissions |first=Mike|last=Brown|website=mb21|accessdate=17 September 2018}}</ref> ** 30 March – ***Channel 5 launches at 6{{nbsp}}pm with the [[Spice Girls]] singing a re-written version of [[Manfred Mann]]'s hit "5-4-3-2-1" as "1-2-3-4-5".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2T9uZhrh-YA |title=Spice Girls launch Channel 5 (UK) |publisher=YouTube |date=22 November 2008|accessdate=24 June 2010}}</ref> Around 65% of the UK is able to receive the channel. ***Channel 5’s soap opera ''[[Family Affairs]]'' debuts. ***Late night talk show ''[[The Jack Docherty Show]]'' debuts. **31 March – ***''[[MLB on Five]]'' makes its debut as part of the channels’ overnight coverage of American sport. ***Pre-school brand ''[[Milkshake!]]'' launches as a breakfast television block. ***The first edition of ''[[5 News]]'' is broadcast with [[Kirsty Young]] perching on the edge of a desk in a bid to present the news in a more informal way. The channel also provides hourly news updates on weekdays on the hour, every hour. ***31 May – Even though Channel 5 had said that it hadn’t been intending to show live sport at peaktime, it buys the rights to one of England’s qualifying matches for the 1998 World Cup – an away match against [[Poland]]. **Summer – Channel 5 launches on the [[Astra satellite]] in a bid to reach the third of UK homes which cannot receive the channel. **Autumn – ''[[Football on 5]]'', which becomes a regular fixture as the channel purchases rights to [[UEFA Cup]] games and other away qualifying matches involving the home nations, showing the latter for the next decade.
* '''1998''' ** 15 November – The launch of [[ITV Digital|OnDigital]] allows the channel to be broadcast across the UK via digital terrestrial television.
* '''1999''' ** 23 June – Channel 5 axes late night talk show ''[[The Jack Docherty Show]]''. The programme had been struggling in recent times with fewer programmes broadcast each week due to low viewing figures.
== 2000s == * '''2000''' ** 11 September – Channel 5 launches a morning topical talk show called ''[[The Wright Stuff]]''.
* '''2001''' ** 16 July – Channel 5 starts showing Australian soap opera ''[[Home and Away]]''<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1441470.stm|title=Home and Away returns|work=BBC News|date=16 July 2001|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref> after scquiring the rights from ITV the previous year.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/654936.stm|title=Channel 5 'bags Home and Away'|work=BBC News|date=24 February 2000|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref>
* '''2002''' ** 16 September – Channel 5 is rebranded as Five and the permanent [[digital on-screen graphic]] is removed.
* '''2003''' ** Weekday afternoon lifestyle chat show ''[[Open House with Gloria Hunniford]]'' is axed as part of a revamp of the daytime schedule.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2002/sep/24/broadcasting2|title=Hunniford loses daytime show|first=John|last=Plunkett|date=24 September 2002|publisher=Guardian Media Group|accessdate=19 September 2017|work=The Guardian}}</ref>
* '''2004''' **27 February – Reports emerge of discussions between [[Channel 4]] and [[Channel 5 (UK)|Five]] aimed at a merger between the two channels.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/3492276.stm |title=Channel 4 and Five discuss merger |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=27 February 2004 |accessdate=31 May 2013}}</ref> **17 November – It is reported that merger talks between Channel 4 and Five have been called off after complexities arose between the public broadcaster Channel 4 and its commercial counterpart.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/tv_and_radio/4018887.stm |title=Merger off for Channel 4 and Five |publisher=BBC |work=BBC News |date=17 November 2004 |accessdate=31 May 2013}}</ref>
*'''2005''' ** 1 January – [[Sky News]] takes over the contract to provide Channel 5’s news service from [[ITN]]. ** 18 November – It is announced that Five had bought a stake in [[Digital terrestrial television|DTT]]'s pay-TV operator, [[Top Up TV]]. It is said that the investment may lead to the development of new free and pay services on DTT, and other platforms.<ref>{{cite press release|publisher=RTL Group |date=18 November 2005 |url=http://www.rtlgroup.com/PressRelease2511.htm |title=RTL Group announces strategic relationship between Five and Top Up TV |accessdate=4 September 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060704222831/http://www.rtlgroup.com/PressRelease2511.htm |archivedate=4 July 2006 }}</ref> ** 30 December – The final edition of soap opera ''[[Family Affairs]]'' is broadcast. The series ends after 2,285 episodes.<ref>{{cite news|first=Tom|last=Bishop|title=End of the Affairs for Five soap|work=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4532080.stm|date=30 December 2005|accessdate=12 October 2006}}</ref>
* '''2006''' ** May – Channel 5 becomes the terrestrial home of highlights of England cricket’s home matches. <ref>{{cite news|first=Jason |last=Deans |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2004/dec/15/sport.channel4 |title=Channel 4 Test coverage bowled out by Sky and Five |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=15 December 2004 |accessdate=21 November 2018}}</ref> It had been the only bidder for the rights. ** 15 October– [[5Star|5 Life]] launches. ** 16 October– [[5USA|5 US]] launches.
* '''2007''' ** 28 August – A time shift of [[5USA|5 US]] launches on Sky.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/broadcasting/a64300/five-launches-1-services.html | title = Five launches +1 services | date = 5 July 2007 | publisher = [[Digital Spy]] }}</ref>
* '''2008''' ** 11 February – Channel 5 becomes the UK home of Australian soap opera ''[[Neighbours]]''.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2008/jan/21/channelfive.tvnews Five to shift news for Aussie soap hour] guardian.co.uk, 21 January 2008</ref> ** 28 April – [[5Star|5 Life]] is renamed Fiver. ** November – ''[[MLB on Five]]'' comes to an end as part of cost-cutting measures which sees the end of the channel broadcasting live overnight coverage of American sport.
* '''2009''' ** 16 February – [[5USA|5 US]] is rebranded Five USA. ** September – Channel 5 becomes the lead broadcaster of the [[UEFA Europa League]] meaning it canshow the entire tournament, including the final. Previously it had only been able to show the early rounds due to the BBC or ITV having the rights from the quarter-finals onwards. ** 14 September – Entertainment news and chat show ''[[Live from Studio Five]]'' debuts.
==2010s== *'''2010''' ** 13 July – Channel 5’s HD services launches on [[Sky UK|Sky]] and [[Virgin Media]].<ref name="Five HD Sky">{{cite web| url = http://corporate.sky.com/media/press_releases/2010/Five_HD.htm| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100323084336/http://corporate.sky.com/media/press_releases/2010/Five_HD.htm| archivedate = 23 March 2010 | title=Five to Make HD Debut on Sky this Summer | date = 17 March 2010 | publisher = British Sky Broadcasting | accessdate = 13 July 2010}}</ref><ref name="Five HD VM">{{cite web| url = http://pressoffice.virginmedia.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=205406&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1446758&highlight= | title=A Virgin Media high five for High Definition Five | date = 13 July 2010 | publisher = Virgin Media | accessdate = 13 July 2010}}{{Dead link|date=October 2015}}</ref> ** 23 July – [[Northern & Shell]] purchases Channel 5 for £103.5 million.<ref>{{cite web| url = https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/jul/23/richard-desmond-channel-five1| title = Richard Desmond promises Channel Five 'investment, drive and leadership' | work = The Guardian | date = 23 July 2010 | accessdate = 24 July 2010}}</ref>
*'''2011''' ** 4 February – The final edition of ''[[Live from Studio Five]]'' is broadcast. It is immediately replaced by ''[[OK! TV]]''<ref name=OKTV>John Plunkett [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jan/18/channel-5-ok-tv-richard-desmond Richard Desmond brings OK! TV to Channel 5] guardian.co.uk, 18 January 2011</ref> which itself ends at the end of the year. ** 14 February – Five returns to its original name of Channel 5. ** 7 March – ***[[5Star|Fiver]] is rebranded as 5* ***Five USA is rebranded [[5USA]]. ** 18 August – Channel 5 becomes the new home of ''[[Big Brother (UK)|Big Brother]]’’.<ref>{{cite news|last=Andrews |first=Amanda |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/mediatechnologyandtelecoms/8431669/Big-Brother-to-return-this-year-on-Channel-5.html |title=Big Brother to return this year on Channel 5 |publisher=The Telegraph |date=6 April 2011 |accessdate=3 January 2014 |location=London}}</ref> ** 6 December – Channel 5 +1 launches on [[Freesat]], [[Freeview (UK)|Freeview]] and [[Sky UK|Sky]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/media/news/a353410/channel-51-to-launch-on-december-6/|title=Channel 5+1 to launch on December 6|publisher=Digital Spy|date=29 November 2011}}</ref>
*'''2012''' ** 20 February – [[ITN]] regains the contract to provide Channel 5’s news coverage from [[Sky News]].<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/nov/08/channel-5-axe-ok-tv?CMP=twt_gu|title= Channel 5 to axe OK! TV|publisher= ''Media Guardian'' |date= 8 November 2011|accessdate= 23 January 2012}}</ref> ** 28 July – ''[[Football on 5]]'' ends after the channel stops showing live football following the transfer of the [[UEFA Europa League]] to ITV. ** 25 October – 5 +1 launches on [[Virgin Media]].
*'''2013''' ** 28 August – UK television debut of the Australian prison drama ''[[Wentworth (TV series)|Wentworth]]'' on [[Channel 5 (UK)|Channel 5]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Hollingshead |first=Iain |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/10272166/Wentworth-Prison-Channel-5-review.html |title=Wentworth Prison, Channel 5, review |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |newspaper=The Telegraph |date=29 August 2013 |accessdate=17 November 2018}}</ref> The [[No Place Like Home (Wentworth)|opening episode]] of the ''[[Prisoner (TV series)|Prisoner Cell Block H]]'' reboot attracts an audience of 2.4 million.<ref name=DSWentworth>{{cite news|last=Jeffery |first=Morgan |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/news/a520639/channel-5-picks-up-season-two-of-wentworth-prison/ |title=Channel 5 picks up season two of 'Wentworth Prison' |publisher=Digital Spy |date=1 October 2013 |accessdate=17 November 2018}}</ref> ** October – Channel 5’s HD channel becomes a pay channel on the Sky platform.
*'''2014''' ** 4 February – Channel 5 launches Channel 5 +24, a 24-hour time shift of the main Channel 5 service.<ref>{{cite web|last=Eames |first=Tom |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/news/a544785/channel-5-to-launch-catch-up-channel-24/ |title=Channel 5 to launch catch-up channel +24 |publisher=Digital Spy |date=17 January 2014 |accessdate=17 January 2014}}</ref> ** 10 September – [[Northern & Shell]] sells Channel 5 to [[Viacom]] for £450 million.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sweney |first=Mark |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/sep/10/viacom-channel-5-joint-commissions-takeover-deal-closes |title=Viacom and Channel 5 unveil joint commissions as takeover deal closes |publisher=The Guardian |date=10 September 2014 |accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref>
*'''2015''' ** 15 April – [[5Spike|Spike]] launches as a British version of the [[Spike (TV network)|American channel of the same name]]. ** 8 August – Football returns to Channel 5 when it takes over the contract to broadcast highlights of the [[English Football League|Football League]] and the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]]. It launches two new programmes under the revived ''[[Football on 5]]'' banner. The are called ''The Championship'' and ''The Goal Rush''. The programmes are broadcast from 9pm on Saturday evening.
*'''2016''' ** 11 February – 5* is rebranded [[5Star]]. ** 4 May – Channel 5’s HD channel launches on [[Freeview (UK)|Freeview]] and [[Freesat]] following the channel becoming free-to-air. ** 10 August – Channel 5 +24 is replaced by My5, featuring a selection of shows from across the network of channels.
*'''2017''' ** June – It is announced that the BBC will return to broadcasting cricket and from 2020 it will replace Channel 5 as broadcaster of highlights of English cricket. ** 31 October – Male-skewing channel Spike is rebranded as [[5Spike]] to more closely associate itself with its sister channels.
*'''2018''' ** 13 February – [[My5]] is replaced by 5Select. It had previously been expected to launch as 5Prime. ** May – Channel 5’s right to show EFL highlights end after the contract transfers to [[Quest (TV channel)|Quest]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.eurosport.co.uk/football/championship/2016-2017/quest-becomes-new-home-of-efl-highlights_sto6737330/story.shtml |title=Quest becomes new home of EFL highlights – Championship 2016–2017 – Football |work=Eurosport UK |publisher=Eurosport |date=3 May 2018 |accessdate=21 November 2018}}</ref> ** 14 June – [[Matthew Wright (television presenter)|Matthew Wright]] presents his last edition of ''[[The Wright Stuff]]'' after 18 years.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-44480663 |title=Matthew Wright says emotional goodbye to The Wright Stuff |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=13 June 2018 |accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> ** 4 July – [[Paramount Network (UK)|Paramount Network]] launches.<ref>{{cite web |last1=White |first1=Peter |title=Viacom To Launch Paramount Network In The UK In July With ‘Suits’ & ‘The Mick’ |url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/viacom-to-launch-paramount-network-in-the-uk-in-july-with-suits-the-mick-1202406154/ |website=www.deadline.com |accessdate=29 June 2018 |date=8 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Barraclough |first1=Leo |title=Viacom to Launch Paramount Network in U.K. in July |url=https://variety.com/2018/tv/global/viacom-paramount-network-uk-1202837211/ |website=www.variety.com |accessdate=29 June 2018 |date=8 June 2018}}</ref> ** 3 September – [[Jeremy Vine]] replaces [[Matthew Wright (television presenter)|Matthew Wright]] as host of Channel 5’s morning topical discussion programme. Consequently, ''[[The Wright Stuff]]'' ends after 18 years. ** 14 September – After seven years, Channel 5 announces that ''[[Big Brother (UK)|Big Brother]]'' and ''[[Celebrity Big Brother (UK)|Celebrity Big Brother]]'' will end after the current series.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-45519752 |title=Big Brother and Celebrity Big Brother are officially ending |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC |date=14 September 2018 |accessdate=21 November 2018}}</ref>
*'''2019''' **September – After 14 seasons, Channel 5 will show cricket highlights for the final time. The rights transfer to the BBC from 2020 onwards.

{{Infobox album | name = Vanities, A New Musical | type = Cast | artist = [[Anneliese van der Pol]], [[Lauren Kennedy]], Sarah Stiles | cover = Vanities_album.jpg | alt = | released = December 15, 2009 | recorded = August 21, 2009 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Showtunes]] | length = 50:38 | label = [[Sh-K-Boom Records|Sh-K-Boom]] | producer = Joel Moss | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} {{Album ratings |rev1 = [[Allmusic]] |rev1score = {{rating|3|5}}<ref>[{{Allmusic|class=album|id=w205964|pure_url=yes}} link]</ref> }}<!-- Automatically generated by DASHBot-->
'''''Vanities, A New Musical''''' contains the songs from the Off-Broadway musical, ''[[Vanities, A New Musical]]'', The album features music and lyrics by David Kirshenbaum, and a book by Jack Heifner. It was recorded after the musical's Off-Broadway run.<ref>http://www.playbill.com/news/article/132146-Sing-Out-Sister-Vanities-Will-Get-a-Cast-Album</ref> The album was released digitally on December 15, 2009 and physically on February 2, 2010.<ref>http://www.playbill.com/news/article/136521-Off-Broadway-Cast-Album-of-Vanities-in-Stores-Starting-Feb-2</ref> The album features [[Anneliese van der Pol]] as Kathy, [[Lauren Kennedy]] as Mary, and [[Sarah Stiles]] as Joanne.
==Track listing== #"Setting Your Sights (Reflections)" – <small>[[Anneliese van der Pol]], [[Lauren Kennedy]], Sarah Stiles </small> – 2:55 #"I Don't Wanna Miss a Thing" – <small>[[Anneliese van der Pol]], [[Lauren Kennedy]], Sarah Stiles</small> – 3:16 #"An Organized Life" – <small>[[Anneliese van der Pol]], [[Lauren Kennedy]], Sarah Stiles</small> – 4:17 #"I Can't Imagine" – <small>[[Anneliese van der Pol]], [[Lauren Kennedy]], Sarah Stiles</small> – 3:42 #"Setting Your Sights (City Limits)" – <small>[[Anneliese van der Pol]], [[Lauren Kennedy]], Sarah Stiles</small> – 3:44 #"An Organized Life (1968)" – <small>[[Anneliese van der Pol]], [[Lauren Kennedy]], Sarah Stiles</small> – 2:02 #"Fly Into The Future" – <small>[[Lauren Kennedy]]</small> – 3:53 #"Cute Boys With Short Haircuts" – <small>[[Anneliese van der Pol]]</small> – 4:20 #"Let Life Happen" – <small>[[Anneliese van der Pol]], [[Lauren Kennedy]], Sarah Stiles</small> – 3:24 #"Setting Your Sights (What You Wanted)" – <small>[[Anneliese van der Pol]]</small> – 1:23 #"The Same Old Music" – <small>[[Anneliese van der Pol]], [[Lauren Kennedy]], Sarah Stiles</small> – 4:28 #"An Organized Life (1974)" – <small>[[Anneliese van der Pol]], [[Lauren Kennedy]], Sarah Stiles</small> – 2:54 #"The Argument" – <small>[[Anneliese van der Pol]], [[Lauren Kennedy]], Sarah Stiles</small> – 2:01 #"Friendship Isn't What It Used To Be" – <small>[[Anneliese van der Pol]], [[Lauren Kennedy]], Sarah Stiles</small> – 3:55 #"Looking Good" – <small>[[Anneliese van der Pol]], [[Lauren Kennedy]], Sarah Stiles</small> – 4:24

{{Infobox amusement park | name = Warner Bros. World Abu Dhabi | image = [[File:Warner Bros. World Abu Dhabi logo.jpg|250px]] | caption = | resort = | location = [[Yas Island]] | location2 = [[Abu Dhabi]] | location3 = [[United Arab Emirates]] | coordinates = | theme = [[Warner Bros.]] | homepage = {{Url|www.wbworldabudhabi.com/en}} | owner = [[Miral Asset Management]] LLC under a license from Warner Bros. Entertainment ([[WarnerMedia]]) | general_manager = | operator = Farah Experiences LLC
(Miral Asset Management LLC) | opening_date = {{Start date and age|2018|7|25}} | closing_date = | previous_names = | season = Year-round | visitors = | area = 1.65 million square feet | rides = 29 | coasters = 2 | water_rides = | slogan = | status = | footnotes = }} '''Warner Bros. World Abu Dhabi''' is an indoor [[amusement park]] in [[Abu Dhabi]], [[United Arab Emirates]], owned and developed by [[Miral Asset Management]] at an expected cost of $1 billion.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/travel-tourism/warner-bros-theme-park-to-open-on-abu-dhabis-yas-island-in-2018|title=Warner Bros theme park to open on Abu Dhabi's Yas Island in 2018|publisher=The National|date=April 20, 2016|accessdate=January 27, 2017}} The park features characters from Warner Bros's franchises, such as [[Looney Tunes]], [[DC Comics]], [[Hanna-Barbera]], and others. The park is located on [[Yas Island]] near [[Ferrari World]] and Yas Waterpark, and is the third Warner Bros.'s theme park.{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-warner-bros-abu-dhabi-20160419-story.html|title=Warner Bros. theme park in Abu Dhabi set to open in 2018|date=April 19, 2016|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=January 27, 2017}} An adjoining hotel is also being built at the center of Yas Island. The park contains 29 rides, restaurants, attractions, shops and shows. ==History== Plans for the park began in 2007, but were halted by the global financial crisis. Warner Bros. had signed a development contract with [[Aldar Properties]] in that year. Afterwards, the park was to be joint owned by Abu Dhabi Media Company, Aldar and Warner Bros. and plans included 19 rides, a multiplex cinema and a hotel. The partnership would include a Persian Gulf-focused entertainment company for digital content distribution, retail, video game publishing, film financing and film production facilities.{{cite news|last1=Anstey|first1=Tom|title=Work starts on 'multi-billion dollar' Warner Bros theme park development in Abu Dhabi|url=http://www.attractionsmanagement.com/detail.cfm?pagetype=detail&subject=news&codeID=316983|accessdate=27 April 2017|work=Attractions Management|publisher=Leisure Media Company Ltd|date=16 July 2015}} Aldar, because of the crisis, sold many of its assets to the Abu Dhabi government. Miral Asset Management was funded and given other Aldar assets purchased by the government. In May 2015, Miral signed the general construction contract with Belgian contractor Six Construct, thus resuming construction that year. On April 19, 2016, Miral and Warner Bros. announced plans for the park's first phase to open in 2018. At that time, all construction agreements had been finalized with 30% of the park finished. Miral had not confirmed the park's final ride count at the time. Miral announced in February 2017 that ride delivery and installation had begun with many of the 29 rides being tested.{{cite news|title=Testing for rides at Warner Bros Abu Dhabi theme park almost complete|url=http://www.thenational.ae/uae/testing-for-rides-at-warner-bros-abu-dhabi-theme-park-almost-complete|accessdate=April 27, 2017|work=The National|publisher=Abu Dhabi Media|date=February 28, 2017}} On April 25, 2017, Warner Bros. Consumer Products and Miral indicated that the park was on schedule at 60% completion, and revealed information about its six themed areas.{{cite news|last1=McNary|first1=Dave|title=Warner Bros. Unveils Metropolis and Gotham City for Abu Dhabi Theme Park|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/warner-bros-metropolis-gotham-city-abu-dhabi-park-1202394421/|accessdate=April 27, 2017|work=Variety|date=April 25, 2017}} On July 26, 2018, the park was inaugurated by Vice President and Prime Minister of the UAE and Ruler of Dubai His Highness Sheikh [[Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum]], and Crown Prince of Abu Dhabi and Deputy Supreme Commander of the UAE Armed Forces His Highness Sheikh [[Mohammed bin Zayed Al Nahyan]].{{cite news | title=Warner Bros. World Abu Dhabi on Yas Island Inaugurated by Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid and Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181018152815/https://www.warnermediagroup.com/newsroom/press-releases/2018/07/24/warner-bros-world-abu-dhabi-on-yas-island-inaugurated-by-sheikh|accessdate=October 18, 2018|work=Press Release|publisher=WarnerMedia|date=July 24, 2018}} ==Design== The theme park is indoor and fully air-conditioned, as is typical of most major theme parks in the region due to the extreme heat in the summer. The facade features a {{convert|61|m|ft|adj=mid|-tall}} tower inspired by the iconic [[Warner Bros. Water Tower]] in Burbank, California. ==Layout== Warner Bros. World Abu Dhabi is organized into six themed areas; Gotham City, Metropolis, Cartoon Junction, Bedrock, Dynamite Gulch and Warner Bros Plaza. Gotham and Metropolis are based on the fictional settings of [[DC Comics]] super heroes [[Batman]] and [[Superman]], respectively. Warner Bros.'s ''[[Looney Tunes]]'' and [[Hanna-Barbera]] cartoon libraries are represented in Dynamite Gulch and Cartoon Junction, respectively, along with Bedrock, which is themed around [[The Flintstones]]. Warner Bros Plaza is meant to mimic the Hollywood of the past.{{cite news|last1=Lodderhose|first1=Diana|title=Warner Bros To Build Gotham City & Metropolis For $1B Abu Dhabi Theme Park|url=http://deadline.com/2017/04/warner-bros-world-abu-dhabi-building-real-life-gotham-city-metropolis-1-billion-theme-park-batman-superman-1202076927/|accessdate=April 27, 2017|work=Deadline|publisher=Penske Business Media, LLC|date=April 25, 2017}} ==Rides== *Scarecrow Scare Raid *The Riddler Revolution *The Joker Funhouse *Rogues Gallery Games *Justice League Warworld Attacks *Green Lantern: Galactic Odyssey *Superman 360: Battle for Metropolis *Teen Titans Training Academy *[[Zamperla|Tom and Jerry: Swiss Cheese Spin]] *Scooby Doo: The Museum of Mysteries *Cartoon Junction Carousel *Daffy Jet-Propelled Pogo Stick *Tweety Wild Wockets *Ricochet Racin' with Taz *Ani-Mayhem *Acme Factory *[[List of Intamin rides|Fast and Furry-ous]] *The Jetsons Cosmic Orbiter *Marvin the Martian Crater Crashers *The Flinststones Bedrock River Adventure *Batman: Knight Flight ==See also== *[[Warner Bros. Jungle Habitat]] *[[Parque Warner Madrid]] *[[Warner Bros. Movie World]] *[[Movie Park Germany]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord missing|United Arab Emirates}} {{BedrockParks}} [[Category:Warner Bros. World Abu Dhabi]] [[Category:Amusement parks in Dubai]] [[Category:Amusement parks in the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Warner Bros. Recreational Enterprises]] [[Category:Amusement parks opened in 2018]] [[Category:2018 establishments in the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:2018 establishments in Abu Dhabi]] {{Amusement-park-stub}}

{{multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=August 2010}} {{Original research|date=September 2007}} {{notability|date=June 2012}} }} Yetisports is a series of games created in 2004 by Austrian studio Edelweiss Medienwerkst and later by ROOT9 Medialab. ==Yetisports: Pingu Throw== Release date: January 19th, 2004
Platforms: Flash, Mobile, PlayStation Portable, iOS, Android
In this game, the player must click the mouse to hit the penguin with a baseball bat. Depending on when the player clicks the mouse, the yeti will hit the penguin a long distance, a short distance, or not hit the penguin at all. The goal is to hit the penguin as far as you can. It was originally released for Flash and mobile devices in 2004. In 2009 (2010 in the USA), it was also released for the PlayStation Portable as part of its PlayStation minis line. There is also an iOS version. A second iOS version was also released, which is based on the PSP version. Later, a remake was released for iOS and Android featuring updated graphics. ==Yetisports: Pingu Throw SE== Release date: 2010
Platforms: PC
A remake of Yetisports: Pingu Throw featuring updated graphics. ==Yetisports: Pingu Throw HD== Platforms: iOS
An HD remake of Yetisports: Pingu Throw. It is based on the PSP version of Yetisports: Pingu Throw. ==Yetisports: Orca Slap== Release date: February 12th, 2004
Platforms: Flash, Mobile, iOS, Android
In this game, you must aim with the mouse cursor, and once you have aimed, you must click the mouse cursor to throw a snowball to hit a penguin towards a target. If the penguin hits the bullseye, you get the most points. It was originally released for Flash and mobile devices, and later, a remake was made for iOS and Android with updated graphics. ==Yetisports: Seal Bounce== Release date: March 18th, 2004
Platforms: Flash, Mobile, PC, iOS, Android
In this game, you play with 2 clicks of the mouse. The first click starts the yeti windmilling his arms (which holds a penguin), and the second click makes him release the penguin between two glaciers with seals sticking out at regular intervals. The seals hit the penguin higher, which is useful as the penguin will not go higher than 300 if thrown straight up, whereas with bounces it is possible to go substantially past 400. It was originally released in 2004 for Flash and mobile devices. In 2010, the game was remade for the PC featuring updated graphics. Later, the game was also remade for iOS and Android with updated graphics. ==Yetisports: Albatros Overload== Release date: April 29th, 2004
Platforms: Flash, Mobile, PC, iOS, Android
This game is set in Australia. The penguin stands on one side of a see-saw while the yeti stomps on the other end. If the stomp is executed with good timing, the penguin lands on an albatross flying overhead. The player then has control over when the albatross flaps its wings. The closer to the ground the bird flaps, the more efficient it is. When the albatross' energy bar (which slowly recharges when the bird is not flapping) reaches 0, the bird will soon crash. It was originally released in 2004 for Flash and mobile devices. In 2010, the game was remade for the PC featuring updated graphics. Later, the game was also remade for iOS and Android with updated graphics. ==Yetisports: Flamingo Drive== Release date: June 17th, 2004
Platforms: Flash, Mobile, PC, iOS, Android
This game, set in Africa, involves using a flamingo as a golf club to hit a penguin. The angle is set by clicking while an arrow points at various angles, and power is set by clicking while a bar moves up and down. You have five shots per game. There are many game elements that will affect the final score, such as giraffes, which will catch the penguin in their mouths and throw it further if the penguin flies near their heads; Elephants and acacias that block low shots; Vultures that catch the penguin, bring it lower and drop it, if it flies too high; and snakes that bounce the penguin higher if it hits them. There is always the same pattern of animals and trees: A giraffe at 0, an acacia at 1000, and a giraffe at 2000, for example. The pattern can be used to help determine the best angle of the first shot. It is definitely a lower angle, but the exact best angle is hard to achieve. A tiny difference can mean a score on the first shot of 350 or 1000. It was originally released in 2004 for Flash and mobile devices. In 2010, the game was remade for the PC featuring updated graphics. Later, the game was also remade for iOS and Android with updated graphics. ==Yetisports: Ylympics== Release date: 2004
Platforms: Flash
This game is a compilation of Yetisports: Pingu Throw, Yetisports: Orca Slap, Yetisports: Seal Bounce, Yetisports: Albatros Overload, and Yetisports: Flamingo Drive. The player plays through the games in order. The game keeps the score for each game as well as the total score. ==Yetisports: Big Wave== Release date: September 2nd, 2004
Platforms: Flash, iOS, Android
This game, controlled by the arrow keys, is the first of a series of games focusing more on the yeti, instead of the penguin and his attempts at flight. The yeti surfs up and down a big wave, trying to pull off tricks and hit penguins out of the air. The wave gradually shrinks until the end of the game. If you press the Y ("motivation") key, when playing the game, an unseen penguin loudly yodels, which then echoes in the background. It was originally released in 2004 for Flash. Later, the game was also remade for iOS and Android with updated graphics. ==Yetisports: Stage Dive== Release date: September 15th, 2004
Platforms: Flash, Mobile
Influenced by the new media on his travels the Yeti gets into rock music, and to prove his "popstar" credentials, dives headfirst into the mosh-pit where the penguins are headbanging. They struggle to the task of getting the Yeti around the room. The Yetis movements are controlled with the left mouse button: you have ten clicks to get the Yeti as far as possible. This game was released as a "special stage". ==Yetisports Deluxe== Release date: September 2004
Platforms: PlayStation, PC
This game is a compilation of 4 Yetisports games. It includes Super Pingu Throw, which is an upgraded version of Yetisports: Pingu Throw; Ice Bear Attack, which is similar to Super Pingu Throw except that the penguin hits polar bears to get more airtime; Super Orca Slap, which is an upgraded version of Yetisports: Orca Slap that activates a slot machine for bonus points when you get a bullseye, and Pingu Dart, which is similar to Super Orca Slap except that you need to try to hit flashing targets on the dartboard. It also includes a multiplayer mode for up to 4 players. ==Yetisports: Snowboard Freeride== Release date: October 14th, 2004
Platforms: Flash, Mobile, iOS, Android
In this game, the yeti snowboards down a long slope, racing 10 penguins. The slope has many jumps and ibexes that send the yeti into the air, where he can do tricks for points. The point is not to win the race, but to get the most points, though you get bonus points for doing well in the race. Hitting a penguin slows it down for a few seconds, but then the penguin gets angry and moves faster. It was originally released in 2004 for Flash and mobile devices. Later, the game was also remade for iOS and Android with updated graphics. ==Yetisports: Jungle Swing== Release date: April 4th, 2005
Platforms: Flash, Mobile, iOS, Android
This game involves swinging up a series of branches in a tree, jumping with a mouse click. It requires precise timing, as the angle of the jump changes based on when the click is. When the yeti jumps off a green branch, the branch turns gold. When the yeti jumps off a gold branch, the branch turns red. When the yeti jumps off a red branch, the branch falls off and 3 green branches grow on the 3 next branchless spaces. There are only 25 branches at the start, all of which are green, so to get to the top yeti must swing off of 9 different branches 3 times each to get to the top, as well as the 50 branches that must be climbed to get to the top at all. It was originally released in 2005 for Flash. Later, the game was also remade for iOS and Android with updated graphics. ==Yetisports: World Tour== Release date: June 5th, 2005
Platforms: PlayStation, PC
The game is a compilation of 10 exclusive Yetisports games. Single player and multiplayer modes are included for all of the games. ==Yetisports: Final Spit== Release date: July 7th, 2005
Platforms: Flash, Mobile
In this game, the yeti has kidnapped a llama and makes it spit at penguins. The other animals don't like being spat at and spitting them costs points. Missing 10 penguins or running out of time ends the game. Hitting the ox gives you a time bonus. This was originally planned to be the final Yetisports game. ==Yetisports: Arctic Adventures== Release date: July 18th, 2005
Platforms: PC, PlayStation 2, Xbox
This game is a compilation of 7 Yetisports games, however they are quite different from the original games because the games are played in 3D environments as opposed to the 2D environments of the original games. Each game contains 3 levels, and the game can be played with up to 8 players. The game also contains a campaign mode that can be played with 1 or 2 players. The PlayStation 2 version requires the EyeToy camera peripheral. ==Yetisports X: Icicle Climb== Platforms: Flash, PC
In this game, the yeti has 12 icicles to throw into the side of a cliff. There is a penguin next to this cliff, and he jumps up the icicles. The only limitation is the fact that the penguin only jumps 1.2 meters up. It was originally released for Flash. In 2010, the game was remade for the PC featuring updated graphics. There is also a Christmas version of this game called Yetisports Xmas Climb. ==Yetisports Game Pack: Vol. 1== Platforms: Mobile
This game is a compilation of Yetisports: Pingu Throw, Yetisports: Orca Slap, Yetisports: Seal Bounce, and an exclusive game called "Penguin's Revenge". Despite the game being called Vol. 1, no other volumes were made. ==Yetisports: Summer Games== Platforms: Mobile
This game is a compilation of Yetisports: Jungle Swing, Yetisports: Big Wave, Yetisports: Flamingo Drive, and Yetisports: Albatros Overload. ==Yetisports: Penguin Party Island Platforms: Wii
Release date: October 14th, 2010
The game is a compilation of nine exclusive Yetisports minigames, designed to be played with multiple players. ==Yetisports: Christmas Candy Climb== Platforms: iOS
A port of Yetisports Xmas Climb. ==Yetisports Collection 1== Platforms: iOS, Android
A compilation of Yetisports: Pingu Throw, Yetisports: Orca Slap, Yetisports: Seal Bounce, and Yetisports: Albatros Overload. ==Yetisports Collection 2== Platforms: Android
A compilation of Yetisports: Flamingo Drive, Yetisports: Big Wave, Yetisports: Snowboard Freeride, and Yetisports: Jungle Swing. ==Yetisports Penguin X Run== Platforms: iOS, Android
An endless runner game where you play as a penguin. [[Category:2004 video games]] [[Category:Flash games]] [[Category:Flash games ported to consoles]] [[Category:Mobile games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Austria]]
